description:
We took a coworker to lunch at nearby Tlaloc Sabor Mexicano and I was impressed. (SoCal Yi Z. would be skeptical but I've been in the Bay long enough to temper my expectations). The menu is thorough and sounded fabulous. I had a Corn Tostada with Carnitas and it proved to be a great choice.

I'm sure a lot of people take the food back to the office but we decided to dine in. The restaurant has several dining areas and is deceivingly large. We sat in the second upstairs area and enjoyed the lovely natural light. It's a great place for a casual sit-down lunch.
author: Yi Z.

description:
The food is good and their array of salsas are dope. Kind of pricey for a taqueria but it's in the middle of FiDi in SF, so they can price it up. The line is always long so come early or have a late lunch. You order first then the food is taken to you if you eat there. They have some tables inside up the stairs or outdoor seating that is usually packed. 

The reason for only 3 stars? The first cashier is a puta. Like straight up. She was the least friendly. Whatever though, went to the next register who was nicer.
author: Jenna T.

description:
I see other good reviews but my experience here was really bad. 

1 Crispy steak Taco - (bland)
1 Side Black beans (cold and bland)
1 side of rice (cold and bland)
1 Tap water 
+Tax and Tip
$20.00

I know its the Financial District but $20.00 rice, beans, and 1 bland taco is   f**king ridiculous!
author: Bob K.

description:
Good and flavorful food...a bit on expensive end. We got baja fish taco, chicken mole, and fish quesadilla. Everything was flavorful. 
Cool seating on the street...they had a salsa bar with lots of options of salsa. Every dish comes with chips, which were thin and had a nice crunch.service was fast...would recommend this place...
author: Nidhi D.

description:
Breakfast review: 
I've been here for lunch many times but this was the first time I came here for breakfast. The menu is typical breakfast burrito fare but slightly elevated. I got the burrito de papas. It was the right amount of food and very flavorful. Most importantly it was at a reasonable price point. My colleague got the chilaquiles burrito which she enjoyed and said it was the right amount of mild for her taste. The salsa bar is available at breakfast and elevates the burrito as do the chips that come with the food.
author: Sharvari J.

description:
I'm fascinated by restaurants in San Francisco that actually have a ton of seating. Whoever purchased the building for Tlaloc was smart to build up, not out. Well, they also built out since there's lots of outdoor seating in the alley it's located in. Came here for lunch with a friend and arrived around 11:30 AM before the big rush. 

I ordered a carnitas quesadilla, which was delivered to our table upstairs. The salsa was fresh and tasty. Lots of variety for different taste buds. Whatever they used for the tortilla was the best part. Super soft, crispy, and surprisingly flavorful. There was a good amount of carnitas as well. Very filling.

We came here because my friend is a vegetarian, and I love how the menu is divided accordingly. I'm a huge fan and would come back here again. Other Yelp reviews mention the long wait. I don't like to wait a long time for ANY lunch place in FiDi on the weekdays, so I would just say to plan ahead and get here early.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Hidden in alley with outdoor seating and large indoor seating as well. Looks like it is very popular in the area based on the lines. On the plus side, they are fast and all the ingredients are organic. 

I got the chicken burrito and was underwhelmed, the chicken was chewy. Given the crowds and organic messaging, was expecting more for a $15 burrito.
author: Sunil R.

description:
This is going to be short.

The place gets very busy during lunch and it's not worth the wait. The burritos are extremely average, the meat doesn't have a lot of flavor and the size are not impressive for the price they charge.

Probably will come back for early lunch, but definitely not wait in line for this.
author: Di H.

description: These nachos were delicious and the meat was super good. The service was fast and they had plenty of seating upstairs. Their salsa bar and a whole lot of different salsas too. They had a mango salsa and an avocado one that were both good. I also had their watermelon juice which was really good. I think this is a solid place to go for lunch if you are in the area. I will have to try their tacos before making any final determination, however.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
Well now don't I feel stupid?

This place is literally 500 feet from my office, I have been to the place next door, yet somehow have missed this little gem.

For about $6.50 you get one HUGE (crispy or soft) taco, I chose pork as my meat.  Plus a mound of fresh fried tortilla chips with the perfect crispy salty goodness.  The tortilla was fried to order, and maybe next time I will get soft.  It was authentic (but somehow farm fresh tasting & upscale) Mexican goodness.  

On any of the many beautiful SF days there are lots of seats in the alley.  I think there is usually a line - but somehow we missed it, we came about 11:45am.

There is a really nice little salsa bar - right now they have a spicy pumpkin salsa that is crave-worthy.

I will definitely be back - I need to "forget" my lunch form home a little more often.
author: Amy W.

description:
It's hidden away in an ally way, like a secret underground taqueria that everyone knows ABOUT!  The lines are usually out the doorway.  There's a reason for that, the food is so good!  I especially in e the salsa bar section where you can taste different salsas from mild to uber tuber SPICY!  Don't forget the watermelon drink, they are refreshing.

Great lunch spot!
author: Jenny T.

description:
If you are going for the perfect burrito this is not your place. 

I think it is a pretty solid lunch option in the financial district plus if you go there in off-peak hours.

Try their hot sauces!
author: Adam L.

description:
This place is the freshest Mexican food I've tasted in the Financial District. I usually get their super burrito. Both meat and vegetarian are amazing! Their salsa collection caters to all pallets.  I particularly like their avocado salsa. It pairs well with their burritos. 
They are big enough for me to save half did dinner too. 

If ever looking for a nice Mexican place with outdoor seating... check this place out!
author: Snneha N.

description:
I cam here for lunch with some of my coworkers on a Thursday and the line was out the door. Definitely a good sign if people were willing to wait when there are so many food options around the area.

I ordered a pollo soft taco and a carne asada taco. They tasted good and I love how diverse the salsa selection is. But the prices are pretty high, especially when it's Mexican food. It was $6.50 per taco. While it was a big taco, there wasn't very much meat in it. I expected more meat considering how expensive the taco is. 

It's good for the area if you're willing to pay the high prices but there are better Mexican places for cheaper prices elsewhere in the city.
author: Becky H.

description:
Excellent burrito: good ingredients, good flavors, good wrapping, good chips.  There is an open salsa bar, avoid the hot one unless you really mean it.

Don't be intimidated by the line.  It moves quickly.  If you choose to eat on-premise, there are extra seats upstair and the staff will find you quite quickly.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description:
I came here back in April, I met up with a friend for lunch.  I thought this restaurant had Taco Tuesdays, but they did not. I was disappointed because I thought I saw on Yelp they had Taco Tuesday's, or perhaps I saw it on their webpage.  

The lady that took our order was kind enough to give us a deal on 4 soft tacos which was a little bit pricey costing $20, since they were pretty small.  We picked different chicken for our tacos but I couldn't really tell the difference.  We paid up front and decided to go sit upstairs on the second level.  Our food was delivered quickly, which was good since my friend had only a small break from work.  The corn tortillas were really good and not too greasy.  The chicken was tender, tasty and all the toppings were fresh.   

Tlaloc Sabor Mexicano Resturant's interior design and layout is very unique and decorative.  They have 4 levels and at each level they have a salsa bar with several different types of salsas.  With bright colorful walls, quotes on the walls, the atmosphere of this restaurant has a positive vibe.  So sit back, relax, and enjoy the company of a friend for breakfast or lunch.  Or get take out if you work in the Financial District.

Overall, my experience here is about a 4.  I had some disappointments as I mentioned, but the quality of the food was indeed good. The food is organic, fresh, and tasty.
author: Tori Lynn L.

description:
I've been here many times and the food has been consistently good. It's right by my office. But one Thursday I went there n had their al pastor tacos- magnificent 
Also they have the best salsa selection in town- def drop by if you're around the area
author: D. C.

description:
My coworker and I were craving tacos so we popped by here on a sunny day. I ended up getting one chicken taco and it was good but nothing to write home about. The lady at the front wasn't the nicest but oh well, they were super busy so I can understand. We also got a few glasses of sangria - I would come back here just for the sangria. 

I recommend coming here if you want to eat some good Mexican food and get a bit boozy while sitting in the sun. :)
author: Mira B.

description:
I came here for the first time and it was delicious!  I ordered a crispy carnitas taco and it was really good.  I usually order 2-3 tacos, but given the price for 1, I only got one and it was pretty filling.  You also get complimentary chips with a a plethora of salsa to choose from.

I would love to come back again.
author: Rachel L.

description:
If it wasn't for my coworker, I don't think I would have discovered Tlaloc Sabor Mexicano. Located in an alleyway, it is not apparent to passerbys unless you had an intent on visiting Tlacloc. 

First impression: I liked the hustle and bustle of this place. You first walk into an open kitchen and then you are met with two cashiers. You place your order and wait for your order number to be called. 

I ordered the Chicken Mole Plate along with a horchata (to-go). I must admit, even for FIDI, this was a super pricey meal (~$19 :( ) 

To be honest, I didn't like that they didn't have plastic sauce containers readily available on the side. The cashier handed me two and it felt weird to ask her for more especially with the huge line of people waiting. I also waited a while (~10 mins) for my food while I saw people that ordered after me get their food first. I'm going to assume the delay was due to this other party having a huge order.

My chicken mole was good, but it was definitely on the spicy side and less sweet. I thought that they would simmer the chicken in the mole sauce, but I could definitely tell they just scooped the sauce of the chicken. It tasted good, but nothing something I would get again from here. My tortilla was delicious and had a slight chewiness to it. However, the horchata was a tad watery, but it really depends on your taste. In the end, it satisfied my horchata craving. 

Surprisingly, I really enjoyed their homemade salsas. The mango salsa was extremely tasty and the salsa verde complemented their chips extremely well! I wish I could just sit their and have their chips and salsas all day long. 

While this place is on the expensive side, I think it would be nice to actually go up to their 2nd and 3rd floor to have a sit down lunch with friends. I heard that they have salsa bars on each floor, so no need to fight for the salsas on the main floor. :)
author: Eva L.

description: I was really excited to get Mexican food in the Financial District.  This did not suffice.  I ordered two chicken tacos that were both very dry.  There wasn't much flavor to the meet, all I could taste was the cilantro.  The chips were really good, but that's about all I liked.
author: Rachael K.

description: Perfectly average quality and average portioned Mexican food for outrageous prices. Seeing that the burrito was $15 (fifteen!), i assumed it would be large and possible a burrito mojado, restaurant style served on a plate. Instead, this was a small burrito comparable to somewhere in the mission for double the price and half the flavor. The pozole was tasty, but also $15 which anyone from a Latin household knows is just unacceptable. Do not recommend unless you're keen on wasting your money or absolutely desperate for Mexican food.
author: Aarom C.

description: Fantastic mexican food, great environment with lots of light and outdoor seating to enjoy.
author: Pavan G.

description: Tlaloc is always amazing! The ingredients are fresh and you can taste the difference in every bite. This is my favorite Mexican restaurant in the FiDi. My current menu favorites are the prawn burrito, carnitas burrito with spinach tortilla and the salsa bar is one of a kind. If you're in the area you should give them a try it's worth it!!
author: Rhiann A.

description: I use to love this place, quality was good and the options to choose from were amazing. Sadly, the quality has gone down and even the burritos are now smaller but the price has stayed the same.
author: Sarah T.

description:
This is the best lunch spot for authentic Mexican food that is healthy! Only open from 7am to 3 pm and one of my favorites. This is not an everyday thing but definitely when I want to treat myself to an amazing lunch. 

I love that this is farm to table and everything is grown fresh and organic from their farm in Sonoma.

Their salsa bar is on point with so many varieties and my go-to salsa is the pumpkin seed salsa. It's so ah-mazing! 

Must Try:
Quesadilla - pretty much the best quesadilla I've ever had. Fully loaded with meat, cheese, and guac. More meat than cheese. 

Carnitas - some of the best

Vegetarian options galore.
author: Song C.

description:
Wait, I don't understand the low ratings? 

Anyway, a couple years ago I was on the hunt for the best bfast burrito in Fidi. I bookmarked TONS of places and I would go to a new place once/week or so. Tlaloc stood out as the hands-down best (Uno Dos second, for its location and convenience). All of the ingredients are top-notch, you get their delicious chips with your burrito for free, and their salsa bar (garlic and avo are my faves) is the best! 

I had mostly forgotten about Tlaloc until a couple weeks ago when a coworker mentioned it, and realized I had to go back! So glad I did! A friend and I grabbed lunch and we were definitely not disappointed! 

First, the line moves incredibly fast, which was SO nice! Second, there is a lot of seating for a casual lunch place (upstairs and cute tables outside)! Third, everything is farm-to-table fresh so yes pricy but the quality of the ingredients are amazing! 

I ended up getting 2 crispy tacos, (which at $7/ea) seemed steep but this taco was so worth it! Way better than Nick's Crispy Tacos! I was more than full and the chips were the perfect amount of crunchy. I also got a spinach lemonade agua fresca which was the perfect refreshing beverage for this oddly hotish weather! My friend got a carnitas crispy taco and the carnitas was literally the best either of us had ever had. 

Well worth the price. Everything was delicious! I cannot wait to come back, and try everything else!
author: Alison N.

description: Best tacos in town. Big fan of the carne asada.
author: Dan S.

description: I love their salsas so much I had a bad morning and planned my lunch here to make everything better.  I ordered nachos with chile verde pork. What came to my table was nachos with carnitas. I told the server that they had the order wrong, that I ordered chile verde pork, and he told me "that's what you have on your plate, chile verde pork." First of all, I'm a 54 year old Mexican that knows the diff between chile verde pork and carnitas. Second of all, I told him he was wrong and he told me I WAS WRONG and walked away! For $13.95 for nachos with your choice of meat...not only did I not get my choice of meat, but was treated like an idiot by staff! I spent $19 on my lunch and this is the third time I've been here. Not only was what was given to me not what I ordered, but it was too expensive for what I received! The carnitas were extremely salty. I left half my plate and just ate the chips. The most expensive chips & salsa ever. I will never return. There are too many good options in the FiDi for lunch. You lose here.
author: Deb B.

description: Awesome flavors, i think its great their menu is pretty clear n simple. The drinks could be a bit better.
author: Aubrey C.

description:
I am not sure how this place didn't get better reviews. I always get the same thing, the pork platter, and I have not been disappointed! The refried beans are amazing and the salsa bar is great. I have to say though, sometimes even their mild salsas are fiery hot. I love the avocado and strawberry salsa (when they have it).

It gets busy for lunch so get there before 12 or after 1 to get a seat.

I have even had the breakfast here once - chorizo and eggs. It was so much food that I had some for breakfast and the rest for lunch!

I really enjoy that they don't bring endless chips. Unless you order otherwise, a small side comes with your meal. It ensures I don't fill up unnecessarily on chips and salsa.

They're only open early, not for dinner, but it is worth a breakfast or lunch here. Oh, and for breakfast they don't have seating available - take out only.
author: Jess A.

description: I tried to order a regular burrito but add lettuce and jalapeños. They charged me $1.00 for each, resulting in a burrito that costs more than a super burrito which has stuff like avocado (which is socially acceptable to charge extra for).  The lettuce costs $0.01 and the peppers maybe a little more, which is not worth losing a customer over. That is ignorant by itself, but I'm writing a review because the cashier started arguing with me after I commented that lettuce should not be a dollar.  This place needs to allow modifications to a regular burrito without rip-offs and argumentation.
author: nathan k.

description:
Got crispy taco which was almost $7 and only gave me 1 taco. And $1 taco in LA is way better.

Mexican food should be cheap. Come on it's mexican food!!!! 

Never gonna go back to this place.
author: C M.

description:
Do it 

Always a good place for lunch. Plenty of seating inside and out. Varied menu. I love the burritos.
author: Danny S.

description: Had the super burrito and horchata. Both were delicious. Looking forward to going back
author: Michael S.

description:
I first came to tlaloc over 7 years ago when I started working in the FIDI. Food is decent and it used to cost $8 bucks for a chicken burrito. I just went back and it will set you back $14 bucks for a basic chicken burrito that requires the entire salsa bar to add flavor.  

Oh but they guard the salsa containers with a fire breathing dragon and only give you one. Ask for more and they flat out say No. Not worth the price. Save your money.
author: Jag N.

description: Extremely rude service. I asked what was in the vegetarian bowl and was told to look up onto the chalk board because it wasn't on the menu. I was expected to know what their specials were and the girl wasn't helpful at all. $14 for a burrito bowl and rude service, uh no. Never.
author: Nikha M.

description:
Pretty good mexican food.  I ordered the beef torta and it was very good.  Great Acme breach, the beef was reasonably tender and flavorful, and the toppings were good.

This is a busy place at lunch and the dude behind the cash register was efficient.

Next time I will likely try something different to see how good the other things are.
author: Bob F.

description: Probably the most over priced, under portioned Mexican food you can buy in sf. It's mediocre but not bad in taste. Staff delivering food to the tables can walk right through you on their way to deliver food to tables too, so be careful and get out of their way.
author: dutchy s.

description: Super expensive, but super worth it. Very friendly staff, great outdoor seating, and bomb food. If you're in the area and want GOOD Mexican, check this place out!
author: Matt H.

description:
Lunch review. 

Slow cooked pork (special) fajita - 3/5
Pumpkin salsa+

Overall, "A-OK"
author: Mark O.

description: I paid $13.00 for this Pollo Asada burrito. I have never paid so much for a Burrito in my life. The size of my super looked very similar to the regular. The meat was seasoned okay however the rest of the ingredients in the burrito were so dry. This didn't balance the dish out very well. I ordered a Super and I didn't see any guac or sour cream in my burrito. I most definitely wouldn't go back. I pay $7 for my Burritos in the East Bay and they are bigger in size which give you leftovers for the next day. If your looking for a bomb burrito and have time to spare go to El Farolotio 24th/Mission!!
author: Kam H.

description:
Tlaloc is one of my favorite places to eat on my lunch break. My bestie and I come here all the time. 
I love that they have chicken chorizo because I like to stay away from pork. The staff is always friendly and the salsas are the best! The crispy tacos are made to order so the taco shell is hot and fresh when you get it. 
This place is always packed during lunch so be sure to come a little early just in case. It's worth it!
author: Nari M.

description: This place is good.  Spacious as they have 3 floors of tables and a patio out front.  Great for a quick lunch get away.  The price is decent and the food is good.  Negative 1 star because the lady taking my order was a bitch to me, only her tho...the rest of the staff are pretty nice.
author: Kimberly T.

description: I ordered 2 tacos with grilled chicken.  I was charged over $14 and my tacos were super sloppy and wet with bean sauce.  Regardless of neighborhood the taco should remain cheap.  Even a taco in FiDi.  Typically 2 tacos should not be more than 10$.  The soggy taco is a result of the preparation.  I ordered tacos, not soup.  The tacos fell apart and I got bean juice everywhere.  From managements decision to price tacos so high, to the negligence of the person making the tacos this has been a disappointing experience.  In addition they have no signage telling you where to order, so I am standing there being ignored until I waive someone down to ask where to order.  Be warned this is not a well operated taqueria, a simple visit to any other taqueria in SF will show tacos are cheap, there is an 'order here' and 'pay here' sign, and they use a slotted spoon to serve beans so the bean juice drains away.  Sad that such an easy item as tacos could be messed up so thoroughly.
author: Ryan F.

description:
Tlaloc's greatest asset is that it's nearby.  It's got standard Mexican fair it higher than necessary prices.  The wait is fine if you go early, but during rush out it gets pretty packed.  As a tip, they have seating and salsas on the second and third floors, so don't feel like you need to fill up at the bottom.

I've had the tacos, burritos, and salads.  All are fine, nothing tremendous.
author: Denis S.

description: Well I'm new to Tlaloc. My fav Mexican food place was Mercedes on Commercial but they were forced to close. However, Tlaloc has made up for it and then some. The food is tasty and their sangria is some of the best in the area. If you're ever in the mood for Mexican food, this place is definitely a must-try:)
author: Tonya C.

description:
Came here during the busy lunch hour and busy it was! My friend and I decided to wait in line but not to worry - the line moved very quickly. How it works: you order at the cash register so you have some time to decide. They give you a number and bring your food to you. I was struggling with what I wanted to order and finally decided on the steak quesadilla, complete with the works, including steak, sour cream, guac, salsa, rice, beans and cheese (plus it came with chips). I also decided to order the Watermelon Agua Fresca...so freaking delicious and refreshing!

They also have an entire salsa bar! I got the avocado mild salsa and the mango mild salsa. There are so many options but I'm a wimp when it comes to spice (these 2 mild salsas were even a bit spicy for me, but still tasty). 

I really liked the set up of the place...it was very hectic downstairs but once you get upstairs (where the tables are), it really didn't feel like a busy Fi-Di lunch spot. My quesadilla was so flavorful, I was very content afterwards. I would definitely come back here!
author: Ilana B.

description:
Wow.. to the people who wrote "Mexican food should be cheap" - you're an idiot. You get what you pay for. Don't expect to get organic ingredients and eco-conciously raised non-gmo fed, antibiotic free meat for "cheap" in this day and age. I'm going to quote from Tlaloc's web site because I was so impressed when I read it.  I had already been won over by their food, but once I was moved enough to check out their website I fell in love with this place. 

    "Jorge's radical commitment to serving food that not only nourishes your body, but feeds your soul, starts at his Guerneville farm, Sabor Mexicano Farm. An agricultural paradise located in the heart of a protected expanse in Sonoma County, safely ensconced from any pesticides used or other harmful chemicals that can be spread from surrounding farms, his 130 acre farm basks in the California sun across the ridge and rests in its tree-lined shade along its valley. Fully operational, the farm itself grows produce for all of Sabor Mexicano restaurants as well as the brand's food products such as their fresh salsas and homemade corn chips. Rows of all different varieties of rich tomatoes and crisp peppers are organically grown to perfection, as well as cucumbers, squashes, watermelon, cilantro, purslane, broccoli, spinach, corn, apples, cabbage and much more, all carefully cultivated with no GMOs, pesticides or harmful chemicals."

This is the best mexican food I've had during my lifetime here in the bay area. I rate this place so highly not just because the salsa is legit authentic, (yet the menu offers items for those who can't handle "super authentic") but the because the quality of the ingredients goes above and beyond anything I can find in the South and East Bay Area.  

Whole Foods carries the tortilla chips that are made here, and those are just as delicious as well.  There's a true "Farm-to-table" sustainable farming/ ranching /harvesting / consciousness and the meat that's selected for this restaurant is just top-notch.  

I live in the South Bay and have plennnnty of "flavorful" mexican places to choose from, but none of them match the quality and care of the ingredients that go into my meals here.
author: S A.

description: I find it strange that this place has so many negative reviews when there is literally a line out the door every.single.day. during the lunch rush. Get their early or be prepared to wait. The tacos are huge, one taco plus chips and their salsas was plenty for lunch! Their salsas are awesome. Carnitas and steak meats are my favorite for tacos or burritos.
author: Gabriella M.

description: Pretty good tacos. They are big, so two will fill up most people. Salsa bar and chips are included in (I think) all orders. My tacos were wrapped up, so I could eat them without everything spilling out. Yummy and really scratches that taco itch.
author: Kevin M.

description: Overall: This hits the spot for a Mexican restaurant in the financial district. The place gets crowded so I would recommend to come earlier.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I came here with a friend for lunch-we both got the regular burrito (mine with chicken, hers with carnitas). It is a little bit expensive for a burrito but it was large, very filling and definitely one of the best burritos I've ever had! They also have an extensive salsa bar with a variety of salsa flavors and spice levels. Unlike many restaurants, options for mild salsa went beyond the standard "Pico De Gallo" salsa-I highly recommend the avocado salsa. 

When we arrived (roughly 12:45), the line was out the door but very fast moving and despite the lunch crowd, there was no pressure to leave immediately after finishing our food. 

A must try for anyone looking for great Mexican food!
author: Rachael K.

description: This place has super bomb mexican food! They have seafood options too (fish plate/ tacos) for anyone who's pescaterian. Ordered the Fajitas bar catering option for a company lunch for 10 people and everyone loved it! They give very generous portions and we even had lots leftover! All their items also come with a side of tortilla chips. They also have a self-serve sauces bar with 8 different flavors (I highly recommend the mango salsa). The line can get very long during the lunch rush hour, but you can call ahead of time to place your order and pick it up.
author: Victoria T.

description: Boss man took me here for lunch couple times. Pretty average food but all organic and from their own farm which is pretty cool. Got something new every time I went and the food was good, the salsa bar however is where it is at. They have a good variety of salsas to choose from but the whole place can get pretty packed easily even with the ample seating areas.
author: Navdeep D.

description: It's not that the food is bad, but it's sincerely lacking. I ordered the super veggie burrito and there was absolutely nothing super about it.  The menu states that there's salsa fresca AND green tomatillo salsa, but all this burrito consisted of was lettuce, beans and rice. There were trace elements of cheese, guac and sour cream if you look real close, but that was about it. Bland and definitely needed salsa. Glad I asked for a salsa container (they hold those hostage behind the counter so make sure you ask for one). Oh, FiDi...you never cease to amaze me with your overpriced and basic lunch options. Almost $17 for a basic burrito and watermelon juice. Pass.
author: Hana D.

description: The food was really fresh and the salsas were good. The service at this establishment was not acceptable. I originally asked for one item on the menu and then told the cashier that I instead wanted to order a different item. The cashier looked at me as though she was acknowledging my order. Turns out that she was ignoring me or could not hear me over the loud music. When I told her that the order was wrong, she told me that I was wrong and that I was given what I had ordered. She then told me that I would have to pay for the change because the order had been placed. After a lengthy disagreement they just put some chorizo on top of my eggs rather than scrambling them in as I had ordered and the cashier continued to be rude. Save your money, go somewhere else.
author: E M.

description:
A hidden gem indeed!

Tlaloc is a place where you would have never expect to have found in the Financial District. Here, the walls are painted with symmetrical designs contain exposed brick that makes you feel at ease. The atmosphere is bombarded with activity from the other Financial District workers. It is funny to see people wearing suits in such a fun joint. I also enjoy how they use the large warehouse wisely by not crowding each floor with chairs and tables. The three floors contain just the right amount of seating to hold big and small parties. It also has large windows that a lot of natural light to come in even if you're sitting in the corner furthest away from them. I was very happy! The service was really nice and quick as well!

I had a regular steak burrito that came with a side of crispy chips. The chips were salted perfectly which I enjoyed. They also give you little containers to hold their large selection of salsa. I really enjoyed their mild avocado, mild mango and their mild garlic salsa! All were a very delicious addition to my burrito. As for my burrito, I feel like it's a little overpriced for what it was. I felt that the salsa sogged up the burrito really quickly but I was happy that we ate in house with a fork and a knife. The pinto beans and salsa were amazing and the steak was pretty juicy.

I feel like this is a nice escape from a bumbling place like the Financial District. I enjoy the festive atmosphere and their food is pretty amazing as well!
author: Linda K.

description: OK their steak taco is everything. And they are HUGE. I don't know why this place doesn't have better reviews. Mexican food SHOULD NOT be cheap. No good food should be cheap.
author: Briana H.

description: How is this place being downgraded?  When there's a line if obvious locals out the door, as a tourist, you change your plans and go in. Was not disappointed I'm the slightest.
author: Mark P.

description:
Good lunch spot to suffice a Mexican food craving. I met a friend there at 11:45 for lunch and the line was already out the door. There is plenty of indoor seating, which was good on this chilly, SF day. 

I ordered the steak quesadilla and it is HUGE. The salsa bar, as others have mentioned, is great and has a good selection of different levels of mild and hot salsa. It is difficult to spot if you are not familiar with the area but now that I know it is there, I would return. 

I've heard they have good breakfast burritos so I'll try that one day when I want a further walk from work than Uno, Dos, Tacos!
author: Anna M.

description:
Fidi eye candy.

Are you in heat? (from their hot red salsa, maybe?) Kidding! #notreally

This place is humongous. Three floors of noisy conversation between stocks guy on his iphone6, to the handsome boys on table 42, to the two cute girls digging into their taco bowls.

Like I said, Fidi eye candy.

Once you're done drooling after the buffet, I mean, SALSA BAR, sit down and take a sip of your watermelon agua fresca. Smack your lips and proclaim, "so deliciously refreshing!"  Chow down on your taco bowl chock full of lettuce, tomatoes, avocado, black beans, cucumber and prawns! It took awhile to finish this large enselada because I took my time eyeing the buffet, I mean, going back and forth the salsa bar! (ay carumba!)

Either that salsa bar is really, really great or I just need more saborrr in my life.
author: Janice C.

description:
I didn't really know what to expect walking in to what seemed like a hole-in-the-wall restaurant, but sure was glad I stopped in. I had just got done with an intense workout around the corner and was looking to feed my hunger with a breakfast burrito. 

They were just opening and preparing what looked like  the prepped meals that people stop in and pickup from various meal plans for lunch.

The burrito I ordered was a Papas (potatoe) Burrito w/ eggs and I added black beans, tomatoes, cheese and sour cream; just to fluff it up a little bit.

I was fairly impressed by the flavor, however the burrito was a little moist (soggy) so I let it air off and cool down for a little bit. The burrito is not immensely flavorful UNTIL you add the homemade SALSAS! I enjoyed the Avocado Mild salsa and the Mango Mild sauce brought a little extra kick, and then of course they had the Spicy and Medium Salsas. 

They threw in some chips, which I wasn't expecting and I had a pleasant breakfast in their upstairs seating, which was quite plentiful I wasn't expecting the restaurant to expand so high up with seating.

All in all it was a good experience and I would return again, looking forward to trying their specialty chicken burritos. Hope this review helps all who are interested in trying the Mexican dishes these guys have to offer.
author: Austin D.

description: The woman at the register is incredibly hostile.  Check your tab.  She charges whatever she wants to charge according to her mood.
author: Julie L.

description:
Food: 4.0/5.0
Service: 2.5/5.0
Value: 2.0/5.0
Decor: 3.0/5.0
Overall: 3.5/5.0 

Tlaloc does an awesome job with its burritos (I'm particularly a fan of the seafood and fish options), the salsas are good, and the frescas are decent.  The prices are starting to push the envelope for quick FiDi lunches, but I guess the buying power in the neighborhood is high.  It's a breakfast/lunch only flow so I guess it is what it is.
author: Damian W.

description:
The ingredients are fresh but I ordered a salad with shrimp and added black beans ($2 extra) and paid $17 for my salad (?!) which had lettuce, cucumber, a few onions and sad looking tomatoes- and only 4 small shrimp.  4 small shrimp for a $15-17 salad??  Maybe it was an error but seemed very stingy and not something I would order again, especially for lunch.

If I had been in the place I would have complained-- but I took it to go.
author: Julie B.

description: I had the burrito with shrimp and cod and it was really good. Lots of filling and a reasonable amount of seafood. The chips are light a crispy, I enjoyed them. I tried the mango and Verde salsa and both were good. They said mild but there was some heat.
author: Jennifer J.

description: Incredible crispy shrimp tacos. Yummy spinach lemonade. But try to get in line around 11:30am for lunch or 50 people will be ahead of you. But don't worry if you do get their late. The line moves fast and the staff and very friendly. They will keep you laughing in line.
author: Christina C.

description: Got charged $4 for 4 pieces of shrimp. $20 nachos...not worth it.
author: Cheyenne H.

description: I don't understand how this place doesn't have 5 star reviews across the board. Freshest chicken in their taco salad's and the SPICIEST hot sauce. If you like really hot, hot sauce - go here. Would eat this every day for lunch.
author: Antigone S.

description: Obnoxious experience. A very basic chicken burrito cost over 15 dollar. It was VERY off from what i had requested. i didn't want any rice and asked them to toast my tortilla before making the burrito... Instead they warmed up the entire burrito and made the sour cream and lettuce ridiculously soggy and the whole burrito super watery -- the sauce was running down my arms in the office - disgusting!! They cashier was also condescending and decided to charge me a dollar for three pieces of lettuce... I wasn't told that was an extra cost... And I didn't expect the lettuce to be a wilted compost color when i ate it later. I love the idea of farm to table mexican but this place is hiding behind their organic label to markup very basic generic burritos... The guacamole was a neon, very not organic looking color btw.
author: Lera D.

description: Solid Mexican eatery with a decent vegetarian menu. I ordered the nachos with chicken chorizo (my friends are the vegetarians, not me). I would say this place is a 3.5/5. The chorizo was a bit dry and the cheese they used on the nachos did not stick well -- what I mean by that is that the cheese was like a giant wad that didn't "mix" with the beans, meat, chips, etc. I'd come here again if I were in the area, but wouldn't take the trip to FiDi to eat here again.
author: Melani T.

description: Great lunch spot! Love their salads and burritos. We order our lunches here for the office often and they've never gotten the order wrong even for 15+ people at times. Their guacamole is the best and their salsas are awesome but if it says spicy, it is spicy so don't trick your colleagues who can't eat spicy. Tlaloc has very good options for vegetarians, vegans and those on low carb diets. Plus they use organic and local produce. Try their Ensalada de Nopales or Tilapia, Mar y Tiera Burrito, Low Carb Meat Burrito, Nopales Mole Burrito and Quesadillas. Call ahead or fax in your order and jump to the front of the line to pick up. They always have a long line.
author: Jen L.

description:
amazing salsa flavors for an explosion of flavor on any of their signature items.
(not to mention the agua frescas!!)
author: Erick B.

description:
Can't even pronounce this place, but the food was good! You order, pay, and then they bring the food to you. There is a lot of seating upstairs and they have an awesome salsa bar. Lots to choose from. I love that your order comes with chips so you can eat it with the salsa. Most places you have to buy the chips separately. 

I got a shrimp taco and steak crispy taco. The portions were huge, but wish there was a bit more meat.
author: Karen H.

description: Really good Mexican food with fresh ingredients. I went there for a second time recently and discovered the seating area upstairs. Neat space to have lunch and hang out. The outside seating is cool too. They are fairly fast if you are on a time crunch for the work lunch hour.
author: Jeremy C.

description: The burrito mexicano is delicious and vegetarian! A little on the pricey side but I'll be back.
author: Nirati G.

description:
I feel extraordinarily guilty, and unfortunately church isn't open for me to confess.

I feel guilty because my co-worker Catherine bought be lunch at this exorbitant Mexican restaurant. 

I feel bad that it cost her $11 for a burrito when what she really wanted was enchiladas, which they didn't have. 

I feel bad because it was another almost $4 for the horchata for me, and $3 for a coke for her.

I feel bad because even though everything is organic and they sing songs to their cows to make them happy before the slaughter, I really didn't enjoy the small burrito much. Mainly because it lacked flavor, needed more guacamole or sour cream or something.

I feel bad because I didn't like their salsa bar either, which went from completely mild to fire engine hot.

But, since Catherine thought this place was okay, I guess it was okay.

I won't be coming back though. $30 for 2 burritos and 2 drinks, you have to be kidding me.

And Catherine...lunch is on me next time. You choose!
author: Jack R.

description: Just tried it for lunch. Lunch line but it moves fast. The menu has lots of items, tacos and burritos galore. Tried the soft shrimp tacos and ate upstairs. They were delish, served with tortilla chips which I dipped in various salsa. If you can take spicy the inferno rated salsa is a mean kick to your tongue. Highly recommend it.
author: Massimo M.

description:
This place is something special! They are locally sourced and everything is very fresh! The pork is to die for, so tender and flavorful! They are one of the very few places you can actually get a hard shell taco. There is a wide variety of salsas to choose from and all are good, but beware the spice level (they are marked). 

They don't give a huge amount of chips and it comes with the meal which means you won't fill up on them before hand like a lot of places. The prices are reasonable, the service is good, and fast. There is usually a very long line but if you go after 1pm it is not as bad.
author: Luke M.

description: I found the crispy tacos to be very greasy, on more than one occasion.  The grease makes the tortilla shells chewy/soggy.
author: Suzy Q.

description:
Had I come here at any time other than the lunch hour, I think I could have appreciated the food a lot more. Just so you know, it's a complete zoo around noontime as puppyish office workers come here in droves. I was about to turn around in a Fuzio-fused fit when I saw how crowded the patio seating was. But dammit, I deserve a taco as much as the entitled millennials who appeared to hold court with their boastful tones overwhelming even the traffic noise on Battery (photo: http://bit.ly/15QCs4Q). I had never been to Tlaloc before, so I'm sure I was frustrating the impatient twenty-somethings heavily sighing behind me as I was trying to decide what to get. I ended up ordering a pair of tacos, Prawn and Fish, for $5.95 each (photo: http://bit.ly/1eDqIrb), and getting an empty cup to fill with soda.

Maneuvering to the soft drink fountain around the protean Gen Y crowd with their eyes and thumbs glued to their smartphones was, trust me, no small feat. Then I needed to find a vacant table, and out under the unseasonably warm Indian summer sun was a rusted red table where I parked my number stand and sat patiently as suits and hipsters gave me small-mouth hoping I'd up and leave (photo: http://bit.ly/19zop11). My tacos came soft and fairly lukewarm, but on the upside, they were freshly made and tasted pretty good. They just seem rather paltry in size for the hefty price tag. But the FiDi has a luxuriant cost-of-working index, and this one is definitely marked above index...but enough with the shop talk. Perhaps I'll come back sometime before the crowds gather.

FOOD - 3 stars...good soft tacos but not outstanding enough for the exorbitant price
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...did I mention it was a zoo at lunchtime?
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...staff was nice, can't say as much for the entitled clientele
TOTAL - 3 stars...looks like I'll be saving all my love for the Mission
author: Ed U.

description:
best mexican food i ever had in san fran, this is cuality food!!
variety of salsa in their salsa bar, spinach limonade best i ever had. 
today i had a super burrito asada con chorizo in a tomato tortilla!!!
author: Julio A.

description: The mole burrito almost males up for the marked up prices. I get it.... Its an all organic locally sourced burrito, but it shouldn't cost nearly 15 bucks. The salsa bar is especially great, as is the outdoor seating on a nice afternoon away from the office for lunch. The neighborhood is filled with franchised subways, but its also full of more moderately priced burritos. The mole is what keeps me coming back. Oh, and the breakfast burrito. Oh, and the salsa bar.
author: Luis P.

description:
3.5 stars

Tlaloc has good Mexican food, but what really stood out to me was the salsa! I'm not usually the type to rave about sauce (I'm more the type to be wolfing down the burrito) but the avocado salsa in particular was very unique and tasty. As many other Yelp reviews have mentioned, there's a salsa bar that offers 5-6 choices so you are bound to find something you like! I would recommend the burritos or tacos over the salads, which are pretty plain.
author: Connie Q.

description:
Not that many Mexican or burrito options where I am in the FiDi, and I think this is one of the better ones in the area.  Lots of seafood options, interesting sauces, etc.  I've had the shrimp burrito multiple times and I'm a fan.  They do a pretty decent job of moving through the line quickly, but if you don't want to wait, just get there by 11 and take it back to the office.

Yeah, it's a little pricey, but most lunch options are in the FiDi.  You're in SF surrounded by financial firms, consultants, law firms, and established companies.  I agree, $12-15 for lunch sucks, but if you want a $6 lunch, pack it from home, or go to Lee's Deli or Subway.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Tucked away in an alley way, this place secretly packs a lot of space - perfect for that lunch rush.

You go in and order at the cash register. Then, take a number, and find a table on one of the 3 floors or outside. They did not have a menu up on the wall but there were some laminated versions at the front. 

Ordered 2 crispy tacos and an agua fresca... total came out to about $17. Hella expensive, but its SF, so okay. The lady encouraged me to buy two because they were small but I wish I had just purchased the 1 taco. I was pretty full after eating half of both. I ordered a carnitas and carne asada taco. Did not like the carnitas - found it relatively flavorless and chunks were too big for a small taco. Took one bite and ended up taking an entire piece of meat out the taco. Carne asada taco was pretty good! Crispy taco has great texture and flavor but if you let it sit for too long, the sauces seep through the shell making it messy to eat later and significantly less enjoyable in terms of texture. I kind of wish they had drained the ingredients in the taco a bit more so that this wouldnt happen. I could always add more salsa for wetness if desired from their huge selections of salsas. They have a salsa bar on each level so you don't need to stock up just on the first floor.  

Overall, wasn't blown away by the flavor but found it perfectly okay. Line moves quick and, despite the many different seating areas, they are always able to find you to deliver your food. Wish I had more sauce bowls to sample a bit of every salsa they had available. Tried the mango and garlic - both offer a mild kick.
author: Josephine T.

description:
I'll agree straight up with Marco's review below me.


"A mediocre burrito not worth the price."
I'll say VERY mediocre burrito. 

I bought the vegetarian super burrito. It was $10.95. I wanted to order a regular burrito with sour cream for $9.95, but sour cream is a dollar extra - __ -  soo I just went with the super.

The overall flavor of the burrito was very bland. The chips were whatever.

I think the only reason why this place is somewhat decent is because of their salsa bar, I think that sort of saves the place.

$11 for an unsatisfactory burrito. 

Ah well, live and you learn.
author: Shruti D.

description: This place is ridiculoussss and I enjoy the outdoor seating on a nice day. The food & salsas at the salsa bar are both great, and the service is good. I always get the carne Assad taco plate (pictured). A generous amount of guacamole in the taco, and it comes with a side of rice & beans as well as a piece of corn on the cob, which is one of the best parts in my opinion. A basket of chips come on the side with your order. There are three separate levels of the restaurant in which you can choose to sit.
author: Kelcey M.

description:
Hidden spot for breakfast burritos and platters in the Fidi. The chilaquiles breakfast burrito is my favorite and at $5, one of the more affordable ones close to my office. Breakfast burritos all come with chips and salsa too. 

The salsa bar is one of the most varied ones around - pumpkin, garlic, mango, cucumber, tomatillo, etc. 

Lunch is tasty enough, but not as rave worthy. Avoid the bland salads with dry chicken. Seafood and steak burritos or tacos are the way to go. However, spending over $10 on a burrito/taco at lunch, even if it's the going price for lunch in the Fidi, is much less appealing.
author: Judy C.

description:
I had been to Tlaloc many times in my days of working financial district so it was nice to come back and see that I still enjoyed having a meal here. Love the selections of mixed drinks behind the bar. Even the weirder combinations were really tasty as I got to try a number of them since there were 8 in our party. Plenty of room for seating both inside on the multiple levels and outside on the street. Though it does get pretty warm indoors on a nice day. I had to give props to our servers as I wondered if it would be a pain for them to go around looking for table numbers to drop off orders.  I was surprised how efficient they were. They forgot a couple things but the real skill for them is finding customers. 

The food was pretty average as far as Mexican food goes. Nothing to write home about or to run back and try.  They're fast and efficient though, which is exactly what you need when you're trying to get lunch in the hustle and bustle world of the Financial District. If you want a quick decent bite of Mexican food in the area Tlaloc won't let you down but it won't make you want to book a trip to Mexico City anytime soon either.
author: Joco F.

description:
I am not a fan of the vegetarian stuff they have but for meat lovers this place is heaven. Nice fresh food. I would recommend the Super Burrito with Chicken and the Prawn Burrito. The highlight of this place is the range of sauces they have. I absolutely love and recommend the Ginger Mild and Pumpkin Sauce.

Definitely a must try for people working in and around Fi-Di.
author: Sidhesh B.

description: Really awesome location with seating in the alleyway, multi-levels of seating in the building, colorful salsa bar. However, the prawn salad I had was horribly bland, under-seasoned, with a total of 4 prawns. They got my friend's order wrong and she just rolled with it -- a quesadilla instead of nachos. She also mentioned the meat was bland and flavorless. Meh. I'd be willing to come back and try so something else since a salad is not exactly the standard Mexican dish. We'll see.
author: Natasha P.

description: There's a simple rule to taquerias. If the salsa is amazing the food will be too. This has never failed me. I see other reviews bitching about price and saying it's not proper and all I can say to that is this. They're all not from SF and likely from SoCal where a #basic is their norm so they're not savvy to what range there is in this cuisine. Go to Oaxaca and get back to me. Try all the salsas but make your first a pumpkin seed based salsa. Not something you see stateside. Get the Adabado chicken oral delivery method. Be aware it's going to be slammed at lunch because all the bridge and tunnel downtown but go outside of lunch, or before and you're good. Is his an elitist review? Definitely and that's why you're going to go because food like this is worth it. They don't have a line out the door for mediocre convence and anyone claiming mediocrity has no taste and is a sad monkey.
author: R B.

description: This place is my go to burrito spot in the Fidi! The second place is not even close to this place! I usually go with the pina mole which is the bomb! Chips are always fresh! The Salsa bar there has soo many options! Beware of the Inferno salsa! Its a XXX for a reason! I have had the Sangria before which has a perfect balance of fruit and booze. They have an outdoor seating that quickly fills up around 12pm during the warmer weather! The only knocks i have on this place is the horchata is very water the two times I have had and this place is a bit spendy for a burrito! Usually around $12-$15 but its in FIDI so not too surprised!
author: Kyle W.

description:
Service - Probably the worst, everyone here seems to be disgruntled maybe due to the crowd they deal with on a daily basis. When we asked for for here they gave us a takeaway bag.  Anytime you asked and employee for something (like a container for salsa) they would either not answer or give an excuse why they couldn't help you at the moment. This was strange considering we were there at 10:30 and were the only ones. 

Food - had the nopales and mole burrito. The mole was good, tortilla was unimpressive. Overall I expect a lot more, especially for $10.

Space - Everything is very disorganized, it's not really clear where you order. The space is not setup in a very thought out way. Needs more signage.
author: Michael D.

description:
My favorite lunch option I've found so far in SF. Here's why:

-Excellent lunch menu with a pretty diverse selection. The Chicken Taco Salad is incredible and the perfect amount of food. Although, I respect the aggressive folks who don't subscribe to the "light lunch" way of life and attack the various seafood burritos/tacos. 

-You'll pay anywhere from $9-15 and leave happy. 

-They have a salsa bar, and you can actually just sample as many of their salsa offerings as you like. I hadn't seen this before and I think it's awesome.
author: Shane E.

description:
I was skeptical when my coworker told me there was a good Mexican place in FiDi, because I pretty much assume all the really good Mexican food is down in Mission. And, while that might be (okay, I know it is) fairly incorrect, it wasn't really off from the truth here.

I ordered one of their pollo abodabo burritos, picking up some of their spicier salsas (the green tomatillo and red mango ones) to accompany the burrito and chips. And while the burrito was not bad, and was far better with the salsas, the chicken was on the dry side, and the entire thing was just a bit less flavorful than I'm used to with my burritos. For those of you who are into healthier lunch options though, the burrito definitely felt... healthier (and perhaps that was the issue!).

If we're just talking about the food, I'd give them a solid 3, but knowing that I can get far tastier Mexican elsewhere, at half the price, I can't bring myself to come back this way.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - I can't speak for seating inside Tlaloc itself, but there's a bunch of outdoor seating out in the street in front of the restaurant itself. Getting down to a table is a bit more difficult, because the lack of spacing between tables means you'll likely need to jump a curb to get to where you want. And, past that, the two-top tables themselves are not at all conducive to pull into, so you'll likely be eating parallel to it.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description:
The burritos are of solid quality, although a bit bland. Luckily, the outstanding salsa bar is available to kick everything up a notch. The real reasons Tlaloc is worth a few extra dollars over your average burrito though:

1. The Mission is too far away to be a reasonable lunch destination.
2. On a beautiful sunny day, you can catch up with an old friend in the wide and welcoming alley full of tables. The pigeons might repeatedly attack her hair, but its a small price to pay for a little sunshine.

If you don't have any friends, you can dine alone and reflect on the fact that SF is the only place you're likely to see a woman in high heels riding a Razor scooter. Or whatever else distracts me from my sad, lonely life. I mean...YOUR sad, lonely life. 

I have friends. Seriously, I do.
author: Peter D.

description:
Sorry everyone, but I have to differ and say that I think that Tlaloc is a bit overrated.  

A couple of criticisms:

1) I generally find the burritos here to doughy.  Yeah, it is just tortillas right?  But however they do it, it comes on as too much tortilla for me.  That is a non-starter.  And I have this place two chances on this, and it was way too much tortilla each time.

2) The salas are completely underwhelming.  I just find them generally too watery and lacking in flavor.  Yes, again I have tried it twice and came to the same conclusion.

3) Everyone talks about the frescas here.  Way too sweet for me. 

Sorry Tlaloc - Many say you are the best Mexican place in town.  Just not for me.
author: Mark M.

description: went in for breakfast an hour after they opened. You  You order at a counter and I am not sure if they have wait staff. I had to tale the chairs off my table and set the table myself. Ordered eggs with chorizo and potates and hot chocolate. The potatoes really needed salt but they don't have any set out.  They supposedly use some special salt but maybe they were out that day.  Eggs and chorizo were bland but some garlic salsa helped. Refried beans were also bland.  Had to find someone as I was leaving about the hot chocolate.
author: Thomas O.

description: This places serves my favorite taco in SF. The crispy carne asada taco is amazing. It has cheese meted into the taco shell and generous amounts of avocado. They also have a great salsa selection. My favorites are the avocado and cucumber. They are really busy from 12-1 so expect a wait. I usually go around 2 pm when there isn't a line.
author: Christi Y.

description:
The pollo adobado burrito is my favorite burrito in the city. The salsa bar is great and I always love going there. If you like spicy, go for the infierno salsa, but be warned, it's hot!!!

I would go there every day if I could.
author: Ben J.

description:
They do a great job at commercial catering!
If stopping in, call ahead for pickup if it's lunch hour during the week.
The shrimp burrito is my favorite. Anything seafood they do really well! Never over cooked and plump seafood. Seafood burritos are $11-14 regular burritos around $10
The mango salsa is the best from the salsa bar.
author: Cassondra B.

description:
Love the concept of the salsa bar and free sitting.

Order and pay for your food at the counter. Find a table upstairs or out at the patio. Wait for your food to be served. Grab some salsa from the salsa bar. 

Portions here are big and the food is good :)
author: Christina N.

description:
This place is really popular for lunch, with a line out the door. Once inside, I was a little afraid to even eat there. All of the food that they were serving was cross contaminating with other foods (picture containers of items, almost Chipotle-style, but more of them, and splashed about like children were playing in them!). The employees are moving so fast to fill orders that the food was flying off the serving spoons in every direction. It was a Mexican food cesspool behind the counter; Black bean juice was pouring off the serving spoon into the rice. Salsa was all over the counter and sneeze guards, avocados were covered in other foods, the preparation station looked like it had been stricken with a salsa bomb, and hadn't been properly wiped down for at least several hours.

I ordered the Ensalada Roja (steak salad), thinking it would be a bit safer than any of the burrito ingredients I saw forcibly co-mingling.... The salad was almost inedible. The cucumbers were limp and yellowing, the other veggies were wilted, the tomatoes were hard and juiceless, and the lettuce tasted unwashed. The meat was way over-cooked, pounded to oblivion, gristly, and stingy. The salad consisted of about 3 oz of steak on 3 pounds of lettuce in a massive bowl.

The service was fast and friendly, and their salsas were actually pretty good. Other than that, I don't see the appeal to this place. The line out the door is a real head-scratcher.
author: Heather A.

description:
Tlaloc is my favorite Mexican in the Financial District. The service is quick, and the staff is friendly.

They close off Commercial st. And setup a bunch of tables with nice Mexican style chairs. When it's rainy or cold, they have 3 floors of seating. 

The food is more expensive than your average burrito or taco, but The meat os cooked to order, not just sitting there in a warming vat all morning. They also have good spices on their shrimp and pablano  dishes. Not the BEST mexican You'll ever have, but still very good

There really arent any major negatives to Tlaloc unless you are on a tight budget. It does get very crowded around 12:30, but plan your visit accordingly! However, They are able to handle the crowds well.
author: Peter N.

description:
This is a great lunch spot in the Financial District.  I'm giving it 4 stars instead of 5 based on the prices ($14 for a salad is a bit much), but hey, sometimes it's important to treat yourself.

I love the salsa bar (who doesn't?) and the fact that your entree comes with chips.  I've had the tilapia, shrimp and chicken and all 3 are very high quality.  It's also a cute spot with indoor and outdoor seating.  Get here early (11:30 - 11:45) or you'll wait in a long line.
author: Sarah K.

description: Great chicken tacos and salsa. This place gets packed quick for lunch so ensure to arrive early.
author: Crystal O.

description:
First off, Tlaloc is deceptively large. I had predominantly thought of it as a take out place until I realized the additional seating on the many floors above. Good to know during the busy lunch rush that you can probably find a spot upstairs with some patience. 

For a lunchtime burrito fix, Tlaloc will do just fine. A $10 burrito is a little of a slap to the face but it is the FiDi after all. The carnitas are pretty tasty though and you get a nice variety of burritos (i.e. not just regular or super here - mole or grilled cactus anyone?) Lunchtime crowds are intense but folks move orders along fairly quickly in a Chipotle-esque fashion. 
 
The one thing Tlaloc is completely under-rated in is breakfast. It's actually pretty decent. Fresh eggs make a difference be it in a breakfast burrito or a Huevos Con Chorizo plate. Also, you must order the coffee or Mexican hot chocolate. There is a nice warm spice (must be the cinnamon) that make both unique breakfast beverages. Plus you can take it slow and savor your food in the morning here without the rush of humanity come lunchtime.
author: Jon L.

description: SO overpriced. $13 for an uneventful salad. That said, I could DRINK the salsa, it's that good. The garlic salsa and the pumpkin seed salsas are SABROSO! Nice outside seating. (The woman at the register was RUDE too btdubs.)
author: Andrew K.

description: Must try! No regrets BOMB I got the crispy tacos and it came with chips. Mango salsa is the best one
author: Dorian G.

description:
Delicious. Delicious I say! They don't have Enchiladas on the lunch menu, but they made them for me anyway, chicken with Verde sauce, they were fresh, plated well, and the Carnitas was perfect. Seating is nice as well, 2 levels upstairs, and the alley outside is packed.

This is my new go-to stop for good Mexican.
author: Grace S.

description: So my friend who loves Mexican food took us here for lunch on a Wednesday. We were originally going to go and have Dim Sum at the City View but of course, their line was long. So since my pregnant friend loves Nachos, we went here. Here you order first then sit down. You wait for your food. I got the Steak Fajitas while my girls got Nachos and Fish tacos. Among the three, I liked the Fish Tacos the best! My Steak was thin but too Dry for my taste. MEH. The Fish tacos tasted so fresh and tasty! The service was good - the cashier was nice and sweet. She clearly understands the peak time and how hungry people are in line but she keeps a nice smile. The salsa was also available to everyone for free! The guacamole was OK - didn't really remember anything special about it. I would probably only come back here when it's free or maybe I will try another dish. Pork Carnitas, maybe? I'll still give it another try next time.
author: Anna Y.

description: The food here is really flavorful! It's pretty pricey, but in line with the area. The variety of salsas is awesome, but I found a few of the "mild" salsas to be extremely hot on my last visit. Perhaps they were mislabeled or they accidentally put hot peppers in them? The line is always long, but they move pretty fast. There's lots of cool seating indoor and outdoor. I will return as it is convenient from my office.
author: Monique J.

description:
A hidden gem in the financial district, though if you love mexican food, chances are you already know about this place. 

The pollo adobada burritos are the absolute truth, and their carnitas burritos are also very good. While not the best burritos in town, in downtown where your primary burrito alternatives are the Chipotle across the street...and the other Chipotle four blocks away...Tlaloc is a saving grace. 

Their much hyped salsa bar is also really clutch, and offers a nice selection of different types of flavors from mild all the way to caliente. In particular, I was a big fan of the avocado salsa, especially as my burrito didn't come with guacamole, so it completed things perfectly. The mango salsa is also excellent. 

The upstairs seating is nice, as is the fact that they bring your food up to your table and provide large glass cups for water. Just be mentally prepared to drop over $10, because that's just what things cost around here and I just don't know why.
author: Brian S.

description: It's nuts that anyone goes to Chiptole in this city when we have great places like this. Great ingredients, spicy fresh made salsas, awesome seating setup, outdoor seats, great people. Love Tlaloc.
author: Andy D.

description: I'm not sure how I feel about you... The line was out the door.. So it should be good? Well, it was only decent better than that Mexican food truck. It was quick because the cashiers are efficient and friendly. However, some of their burritos don't come with rice.. Umm, so if you want rice it's extra $... The sauce bar has many options. But it was mainly watery sauces. Nothing that impressed me. But what shocked me was that I had about 3-5 fat pieces in my burrito... I will skip this place and opt for the mission!
author: Ann L.

description:
I tried Tlaloc for the first time a few weeks ago and thought it was decent but a bit pricey.  On my first visit, I ordered a chicken chorizo soft taco and carnitas soft taco with the beans on the side.  The chicken chorizo was flavorful and had a nice consistent ground beef texture.  The carnitas was not dry but it was pretty bland and I had to eat it with the beans to add flavor.

On my second try today when I was craving the chicken chorizo soft taco, I placed a take out order over the phone for 2 of them and forgot to ask for the beans on the side.  When I got back to my office an opened up the takeout container, it was mostly beans and light on the chicken chorizo.  As for the chorizo, it was nothing like my previous visit.  It did not appear to be ground up and was in different sizes and looked only partially marinated.  It also had no flavor to it.

So after 2 visits, the food has been inconsistent and I don't see any alignment with quality of food, price and taste with skimpy portions of meat.  I shouldn't have to order the beans on the side to get a larger portion of meat in a taco.

Don't think I'm going to make the effort to go back again anytime soon to try anything else on the menu after this experience.
author: Jack C.

description:
I kind of love this place!

TOSTADA COSTENA ($13)
Grilled prawns, calamari and fish marinated with adobo salsa served with lettuce, guacamole and queso fresco. *droooool. And it comes with chips! The only sad thing is that the tostada gets a bit soggy from everything that sits on top of it. It's quite a hefty meal too - I was starving when I got this and I have maybe 5 bites and almost all of my chips leftover.

ATMOSPHERE
When you first enter, it looks like it's Chipotle-style but it really isn't. There's huge menus on the wall and you order at the end of the counter. After ordering, they hand you two small containers for you to fill with your choice of salsa at the bar in the back. There's standing room between the cashier and the salsa bar for those who order to go. If you're eating in, there are tables upstairs.

My second time here, it was a rainy day so I wanted something close by work. Tlaloc it is! I was happily greeted by a live band singing and playing Mexican music. At first, I was beh because it was so loud and it was a struggle to order. But as I waited for my food, I started to smile. They were really good and livened up the atmosphere!
author: Sandy T.

description:
First of all, this place is in the middle of FIDI, so good luck trying to find parking that's cheap near the Transamerica building. Other than that, do yourself a favor and order to-go. If you go there anytime after 11:15/11:30am, the lunch crowd usually has to wait about 20 min just to place the order. Granted, it's definitely worth the wait. The food is extremely fresh, with all sauces and drinks made in house. I usually get the nopales salad, which is huge. They also make really good burritos (with shrimp). Their tacos are okay, as i think they're a tad bit dry since they don't include a salsa or huac/ cream cheese. 

Also, be forewarned that when their sauces say it's HOT, they really mean it. Go in, it's worth grabbing it to go.
author: Carolina S.

description: I love their crispy carnitas tacos. This is my office's go to mexican place for lunch. The salsa bar is great and the food is always hot and fresh. Their chips are amazing as well. One thing is though, you definitely want to get here before 12:15pm for lunch or you will probably be standing in a long line that goes out the door, although it does move pretty fast. There is plenty of seating inside and if you are lucky, there are some tables outside.
author: Samantha S.

description: Food is always great here. Don't waste your time with the salads -- they've gone way up in price and just aren't worth it. For the same price, the protein plate comes with way more food and has lettuce -- much better option.
author: Amanda W.

description: Fresh, not overly salty, salsa that taste authentic even a tad bitter (which I love) and prompt service. Had the grilled veggie burrito and they held the guac just like I asked. Perfect. Exactly what I look for in a close to work lunch spot.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I finally stopped in here for lunch after hearing about how amazing it was. It definitely didn't disappoint! Not only is the food great, the service is quick, efficient, and friendly. The line was down the street, and it was only about a 10 minute encounter overall (including standing in line).

I got the regular carne asada burrito and it was delicious. I love that it doesn't have rice...makes you feel like you're getting more bang for your buck. I also tried the pumpkin seed salsa (hot) and the avocado salsa (mild) and they had tons of flavor. I didn't think the pumpkin seed salsa was too hot, but the flavor was on point.

I'd recommend it!
author: Grace M.

description:
I was a frequent customer of Tlaloc until I was defrauded by someone at their location about a month ago. I purchased a few burritos to go, paid with credit card, signed the receipt and left. A few days later, I noticed that the amount on my receipt didn't match the amount that I was charged. I contacted management and they made some excuse that they just had a new cashier and the charge was done by accident. I know pretty much everyone that works there and they know me so there was no possible way this could have happened. I also had the other copy of my receipt so I know what I should have been charged. I then asked for my money back and was told that I would receive it immediately. I was willing to let it all go. 

Well.... Fast-forward about 2 weeks later and my money still hadn't been credited to my card. I asked to speak to the owner to file a complaint and was then contacted by the owner's son. The owner's son sent me a picture of the receipt with another person's handwriting changing the receipt amount after I had left. It was absolutely not in my handwriting. I stated this fact and was told that I would be credited the whole amount of my order as a courtesy and that they would look into it further. Fast-forward another two weeks and still no money back. I shouldn't have to file fraud charges with my bank but I guess this is what I have to do when you are dealing with businesses who defraud customers. 

As expensive as lunch is here in San Francisco, you think they wouldn't need to steal from hardworking customers that frequent their location. While the amount was minimal the damage to my relationship with them has been done. Please look at your receipts if you decide to purchase anything from this location. I would also go back and check past receipts because someone at this location is stealing from customers.
author: Ann E.

description:
A mediocre burrito not worth the price. 

What I bought was a super chicken burrito. 
What I liked:
- Plenty of chips come with the burrito

What I didn't like:
- The overall flavor of the burrito was bland
- The rice was super watery
- I had to add salsa to the burrito to make it taste better. 
- 11 bucks is too expensive for a bland burrito
author: Marco M.

description:
From my experience Tlaloc is either hit or miss. Here are some tips so that you won't miss. I recommend coming here after 1:00ppm so you will not be stuck in the line. The line can be pretty long sine it is close to a lot of skyscrapers. 

The first time I went with a standard burrito (not super, here is why). Although there is only meat, cheese and beans, the salsa bar is so extensive that you can spruce up your burrito. Unless you want the rice, the avocado mild salsa is creamy enough to replace the guac and sour cream. Spiciness, add the different salsas. Mango mix with the Spicy Garlic make a mean sauce. Either dipping in chips or smothering it over your burrito, it will be flavorful. You can opt out and just get the super burrito., but paying 12 for a burrito is not cutting it for me.  The meat isn't very flavorful and there isn't that touch of the mexican style burrito you would get from the trucks. The regular is already close to 10. Save yourself a couple bucks. 

1 Crispy Taco is a good choice if you are not too hungry but not full either. It is in between a lunch and a snack. Meat is lean loaded, however not very flavorful.  I believe with tax it was around 5.50.

I had Tlaloc today, and wanted to try something new. Tostada. I did not like. I felt like I was eating a lettuce and guac with light dusting of cheese crumbles. Be safe and go with a Burrito and Crispy Taco. 

The staff are extremely sweet, I love that kind of etiquette.
author: Phuong V.

description:
Wow......

Prices have gone up.  My shrimp salad, cup of watermelon agua fresca, and added beans $17.00!

Quality has gone down.  

Service = same.  The seating has been expanded but their delivery to the tables, leaves much to be desired.  The food arrives out of order, and it's cold.  (My cw's shrimp quesadilla was cold when it hit the table.  She ordered before me, and her quesadilla arrived while I was halfway through my salad!)

Another one bites the dust on our lunch places.........sigh.
author: Fannie S.

description:
I'll give 4 stars since I used a internet deal.  The food is excellent.  The shrimp mole burrito and the chicken mole burrito are both bursting with flavor.  Good sized shrimp and tasted fresh.

I also had a try of the fish quesadilla.  Probably the best I've ever had.  Fish was SUPER FRESH!  Similar to my breath.  Salsa bar is extensive and on the first and second floor.

The ambiance is nice and there is plenty of seating inside and outside.  Chips come along with the meal.

Service is relatively fast, but there can be a bit of a wait during the lunch rush.

The have horchatta, Strawberry and other agua frescas, but I've never tried any.  They seem to be popular.  They also serve beer.

The price point is a little high for me, but I guess for the quality that you get it is fair.  I tend not to pay $10 for a burrito, but if that is what you spend, it is well spent as Tlaloc.

The pumpkin seed salsa was one of my favorites.  I know it may sound weird, but it is delicious, give it a try.

Call ahead and place your order by phone, it is a big time saver.

I had no issues with using my internet deal, that is always a relief.

Everything they do here is done well from my experience.
author: Ty C.

description: Good burrito that won't disappoint. A tad pricy which makes you think twice when heading back.
author: Sugi s.

description:
Salsa bars are what make or break a Mexican restaurant for me, and Tlaloc's gets pushed into the 4 star range because of its selection. 

THE FOOD:

As stated above, it's really all about the salsa bar at this restaurant. I ordered a torta, it came on a bread that was similar to a Dutch Crunch. I wasn't blown away by the sandwich, the meat was a little dry and chewy, but the salsa options make a big difference. anything tastes amazing when it's drowning in avocado salsa. 

PRO TIPS:

Prices are high, but you are in the FiDi after all. A single taco at this place is pretty substantial, it might be all you need.
author: Patrick T.
