description: Really good quality food, area very close to work. 2 Co workers had burritos and I had the nachos and both items were very good. Good quality meat, natural and fresh produce and fresh salsa! Definitely going back to this place again!
author: Jennifer R.

description: LOVE this place.. Their breakfast burritos are to die for... I usually go for the chorizo which is super tasty! They also have a huge salsa bar with about 10 different options..!!
author: Marc G.

description:
Great Mexican joint that has quality, fresh food and a vibe that makes it look like you are sitting in a small village on the coast. I had the fish burrito which I highly recommend. The guac is delicious.

Oh, the other reviews on spiciness of the salsa are correct. They are a bit on the hot side!
author: Doug M.

description:
Why didn't I discover this place sooner?!  

I take it that their speciality here are their burritos.  They have so many wonderful options and a whole menu dedicated to seafood!  Gotta love that!

I usually cannot handle a burrito during my lunch hour.  I will knock out the second I get back to my desk.  No joke.  Sometimes I wish I had a pillow stashed away in my drawers so that I can bust it out after a hefty meal.  

As hard as it was, I refrained from ordering a burrito and got a carne asada plate instead.  It came with a very tender and thin slice of carne asada - delicious, but it could use a little more spices.  Still, it was naturally very flavorful.  There was also black beans, rice, and corn tortilla.  I wish I had chips too, so our waiter very kindly brought them to me.  I was a very happy camper :)

They have such a great selection of salsas.  The mango was probably one of my favorites.  

It may look like a really small restaurant from the first floor, but there are three floors of seating.  I also love the decor.  Everything looks very traditional, and I think the intricate designs and paintings on the walls were hand painted!  

I'm definitely going to follow my nose and come back for more :)
author: Cecilia S.

description:
Tlaloc is a pretty weird place. It's more like a fun house with its weird structure than a restaurant. 

== Food ==

The steak quesadilla here is really weird. It's not your traditional quesadilla... it had a weird pocket like structure to it. It tasted alright overall, but I kind of wished I went with a burrito.

The salsa bar has a variety of different sauces. There's a spicy one that has a really good kick to it.

Be careful with the salsa bar... some of the sauce dishes were really clean. They had some sauce strains still on the inside.

== Service ==

Since this place is structured weirdly, you'll order at the entrance for "here" or "to go". If you get it for "here", you'll receive a number, which you find a table on one of the floors. The kicker is that the waiter doesn't know which floor you're on so said waiter will go through a bunch of floors to search for your number. Slow service in other words and your food may be lukewarm.

== Overall ==

Maybe a good place for "to go" food, but a really weird place for dining in. The quesadilla I got wasn't what I was expecting. The burrito may be the item to get.
author: Steven B.

description: Really good! Got recommendations to go by a few people in the neighborhood and I'm glad i stopped in. I recommend the Tlaloc quesadilla and the Strawberry agua fresca was tasty
author: Stephanie D.

description: really good, expensive (due to location i'd imagine) americanized mexican food with fresh ingredients and decent salsa. the chips are so good. I really like it but it is not a hole in the wall place, but rather a nice place with decent food and a quick line. What more could you want from a buzzy financial district lunch place? If you want "real" mexican then i think that is in another neighborhood but for what this is, I like it.
author: Alex M.

description:
I finally found a decent Mexican spot that's only 5 minutes away.  YAYYY!! 

It's always busy, always a line, so get there early if you're in a rush.  My go to spot for a burrito, taco, or nachos!  Average price is about $10 and will leave you quite satisifed! 

LOVES!
author: Diana M.

description: Delicious burrito but expensive. $13 for a super burrito! I always have to think twice about coming here for that reason alone.
author: Andre O.

description: Best salsa bar ever and a great vegetariand options!! People really friendly!! Love it!! Real México DF style!!
author: Arturo R.

description: Way better than Chipotle.  The pipian mole salsa is amazing.  Only complaint is that I wish it were 20% less expensive.
author: Bertram W.

description: The food is delish, especially that salsa bar.  The cucumber pico is so spicy that it starts my day off better than coffee when I put on my nopales con huevo burrito.
author: Maude T.

description: A bit pricey, but decent food. If you are looking for a hole in the wall taco joint, this is not the place for you. The salsa bar has a wide variety, but you are only given one small bag of chips.
author: Amy T.

description:
Absolutely amazing.

This is the 2nd time I have visited.  The first time I started out easy with just a regular burrito with Chorizo.  Personal preference to give a new place (at least new to me) a chance with something simple.

Today I went for the Mariscada, fish, calimari and prawns.  It's a bit pricier but so delicious.  The calamari was slightly overdone, but that was easy to look past with all the rest of the deliciousness.

Of course the side tortilla chips and the homemade salsa bar just wrap the whole thing up for a great lunch.

It's kind of place you don't want to recommend as that will just make it a longer wait for lunch ;).   If you're into burritos or tostados you have to check out Tlaloc.
author: Joshua D.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  I tried my best to ignore the problems but they kept giving me reasons not to come back.

The first time I went here was great.  Food was cooked well, tasted fresh, salsa bar great.  Expensive for sure, but it was a nice splurge.  Out the door with a chicken burrito for $11, tasted good.  Was happy to return.

Second time I went here I ordered a shrimp and chicken burrito ($13).  Started eating the burrito and there was steak in it, big chunks of it.  As someone who doesn't eat beef (and hasn't for years) I wasn't super happy, so I wrote them an email letting them know this was an issue (their receipts list an email address to contact for questions/comments).

I didn't get a response to that email, but oh well.  Went back again.  Ordered a chicken burrito and chips and the chip bag had one crushed up chip in it.  That was pretty insulting.  Read other Yelp reviews and saw the same crushed up chip experience.  Decided that was enough not to come back.

There's clearly some issues with this place, I can't recommend anyone go here.  For the expensive price tag I would expect higher quality service and at least getting the order right... and maybe more than a few crushed up chips.
author: John C.

description:
If you are looking for the best tacos in San Francisco, then come here.  Do not come here at noon because it is too crowded and you have to stand in a long line -- although it moves fast. Come at 10:30 a.m. and order a crispy chorizo taco.  No, order two crispy tacos because once you finish the first one you will wish you had another. They are reasonably priced at $4.50.  They also make their own chorizo and the ingredients across the board are organic and personally grown. That makes all the difference. Plus the tacos are put together beautifully, are with beautifully seasoned chorizo, and with guacamole and a healthy dab of sour cream. 

I normally would not give this place five stars because it is a stand up and order at the counter place but they bring the food to your table promptly and so it is close to a sit down experience.  But, the food and friendly staff are so exceptional, I have to give it five stars. 

Do not try just the tacos, everything they make here is outstanding and authentic.  Each day they have a special that is tantalizing.  

Do not miss this place!
author: Bill L.

description: I hadn't been here in a very long time and I had the craving for something fresh and after reading the menu and seeing they had queso fresco I had to come here. Being that I am pregnant and have so many random cravings i just wanted a plain toastada with sour cream, beans, avocado and queso fresco. I got the veggie one and just didn't get the salsas on top and I was very satisfied. I also got a horchata and it was good.it was expensive but very good.
author: Irma R.

description:
PROS: Their food is made with organic produce from the owner's farm. They do not use lard.

CONS: Their food is way overpriced - $10+ dollars for a regular burrito. Their prices have steadily rose while at the same time the quantity of meat in their burritos has dropped considerably... reminds me of the "Where's the beef?" commercial. Also, they have a very noisy establishment. So, I recommend calling in to place your order for pick up (you also might want to confirm they got your order correct before leaving - I've been burned a couple of times).
author: Sara Z.

description:
My favorite place for chips and salsa!  The salsa bar is great.

With the own farm and organic foods, Tlaloc is a favorite amongst my office.  There are plenty of options in FiDi, but I choose this place most often.  When the weather is nice, its great to sit outside and enjoy a little sun.  The chicken chorizo burrito is what I get everytime, but everything on the menu looks delicious.  I've never heard any complaints from my lunch buddies.

They also do catering.  I've organized a taco bar for 30 people and it was delicious.  They delivered everything to my office.  it was a big hit and will definitely be ordered again.
author: Jason S.

description:
$10.75 for a "super" burrito?  Thats ridiculous, especially when its not very big, has little cheese and guac.  PS - the "salsa fresca" is just chunks of tomato with no flavor.

FiDi is a barren wasteland for burritos; if you must have one for lunch, just do Chipotle. Don't waste your time and money at this place.
author: Josh G.

description:
Low carb burritos!! A happy dance is in order, bitches!
**shimmy, shimmy, shake**

You seriously have no idea what it feels like to do Atkins and suffer these carb withdrawals. Sometimes you just wanna punch random strangers in the face for no reason like, "Goddammit! Will you stop eating that deliciously-flaky croissant so f$cking close to me?! I can SMELL it, you asshole!"

But Tlaloc rescued me. They have an entire low carb menu with protein-rich salads topped with shrimp, chicken or carne asada. OR, light and fresh low-carb burritos wrapped in high fiber, whole wheat tortillas. The burrito is sans rice and beans of course, but their juicy chicken, tasty veggies and wide array of freshly-made salsas make up for it. I've also had their carne asada salad with came with a huge portion of steak. On my next visit - sangria!

Side note about the salsa: It rocks. They have pineaple salsa, mango salsa, tomatillo green salsa, rich chile ancho salsa, and lots more. You can fix as much as you want. I couldn't have chips with my salsa, but it's okay cause I poured that mofo all over my burrito. Oh yes. 

I love how they have three levels of seating. Tlaloc has extremely high industrial ceilings and they've made great use of the space. There's even an elevator that takes you from the basement (where the bathroom is) up to the 3rd level. I love sitting on the 2nd level and watching the kitchen workers run around like busy little bees serving the hungry lunch crowds. And on a sunny day, there are tables set up on the street outside - the street is closed off to traffic, so you're dining streetside. Very European :)

Okay, one more happy dance.
**shimmy shake shake**

"Woot woot!" to the 10th power.
author: Mariela D.

description:
SO, working in the FIDI, there aren't too many good Mexican food options -- on Yelp, I think the highest rated place was this and Chipotle. So I decided to come here!

Some of the fare is more traditional vs just tacos and burritos which is nice, they also have seafood options!

I've come twice so far and just had the normal burrito just to try their basics out.
YUMMMMMMMMMMMM. Hits the spot completely, and not too greasy or fatty where I feel like crap after I finish it. Good mix of ingredients in there (vs too much rice like when you eat at Chipotle). It might drip through when you start eating but they have 2-3 layers of foil wrap so it usually doesn't happen.

OVERALL: good burrito and HELLA BOMB ASS SALSA. They give you two small containers so you can pick and choose from the salsa bar. YOU MUST GET THE GARLIC SALSA.. (it is kinda hot though, if you can't handle it, mix it with a mild one)

UGHH I could just come here for the garlic salsa and be happy.

I think the burrito is around $8 and comes with chips+salsa. Kinda pricey for Mexican food but this IS the FIDI. Well made and organic though, so it's pretty fair in my opinion.
author: Emily C.

description:
I've eaten here about 4 times and I love the food. I haven't done a review yet, but after what I saw today 5/4 I had to post a review. 

I was at Papalote a couple weeks ago and saw the cook use his hands to grab meat and put it on the grill and then grabbed his tools and didn't wash his hands. 

WELL I SAW THE SAME THING HERE. 

While in line we watched the cook doing his thing. He had drawers of meat under the stove. He would reach in and grab chicken, shrimp or whatever with his bare fricking hands and toss them on the grill. After that he grabbed tortillas, plates cheese, utensils and so on. NEVER WASHING HIS HANDS. We saw him cover his hands i Shrimp/Prawns and then grab a couple tortillas and toss them on the grill. 

What if someone was allergic to these things that you are putting on their burritos? What if you don't heat up the outside of the tortilla enough and the juice from the meat gets them sick? You can kill someone. 

I would fire the cooks or find someone that knows how to follow basic cooking safety procedures. 

I'll give a better review later about the food, but this needs to be addressed.
author: Mack L.

description:
Hi, it's your friendly neighborhood burrito whore here. 

Tlaloc looks like a Chipotle or some other Mexican chain, but their food is taqueria-worthy. Not the grease-stained taqueria with the orange-tiled floor, the blaring Tejano music and the glassy-eyed patrons eating bowls of menudo Sunday morning, but a more upscale taqueria that appeals to a wider audience. And I don't mean wider as in wide load; Tlaloc promotes their food as natural, local, blahblahblah we're in San Francisco.  And you can definitely taste the difference. 

I know that "healthy" isn't always synonymous with Mexican food, but don't be frightened. Nothing suffers; the flavor is still great, but you don't say to yourself, "damn, that was kind of salty" as you guzzle your ninth glass of water. 

I usually get the chorizo (either pork or chicken) burrito and it's great. There's a nice ratio of meat to the other stuff, and the chorizo is very flavorful (yes, even the chicken version). The pork chorizo is a little less sweet and a little more smoky than what I'm used to, but it was good.

And the salsa bar . . . ah, the salsa bar. There's a good mixture of mild, medium, and spicy salsas for the whole family. 

Yes, it is a little pricey for a taqueria, but remember you're in the Financial District. But I don't mind paying a little extra for something that's tasty, filling, and that I know isn't clogging my arteries.
author: Jeff R.

description:
Now, I don't feel they have the flavor right for non-meat burritos. I had a beans and rice
Vege here once, and I am having a grilled beef. Okay, but nothing special. Stick with the meat ones--chicken, beef--maybe mole. Those are, in my opinion, exquisite.
author: Christopher B.

description: Proof that Yelp is complete and utter b.s. This place has amazing service and the best tacos I have ever had and I am from Mexico City, MEXICO.
author: Andreas M.

description: Yum! This place is in our work lunch rotation. Love the burritos. I can drink a glass of their green sauce... they need to bottle it-- I'd buy it. It gets busy but service is always good.
author: Ranjeev H.

description: Both Avacado and Pumpkin Seed salsas were great.  Pollo Asado super burrito was decent to good.  Only issue was the price is very high.  $16 tab for super burrito and a fountain drink
author: j s.

description:
A little pricey, but hey, c'mon people. This isn't the Mission. Across the street you're gonna pay 13 bucks for a salad!  

Fresh, organic, farm to table ingredients. Delicious homemade salsa bar...I've tried the mango and garlic and both are amazing.  

You can bet your sweet biscuit I will be back. Often.
author: Angela N.

description:
Farm fresh to table.  They grow their own stuff, so you know you are supporting local farmers, but you are also paying for it by the higher price.

First off, their breakfast burritos are Incredibly Yummy and filling!  I usually go for the Chileaquiles or the Huevos con papas burritos.  

They also have a salsa bar with fantastic varieties of salsa that's hard to find elsewhere (pumpkin seed salsa!) but will say most are too spicy for me.  The mango one is about all I can handle so it'd be nice if they'd offered more mild ones.

For lunch items, I found the prawns burrito pretty tasty and def plentiful with the shrimp.  Shrimp and crispy fish tacos were also good.  The other items, esp the nachos, I found just average.  All meals usually come with a side of chips.

And you should also try the Mexican hot chocolate if you have a sweet tooth.  Lots of cinnamon that adds a nice kick.

Lots of indoor and outdoor seating but make sure to grab a seat before the lunch crowd swarms in.
author: C A.

description:
(See picS)

I continuously come back for their good and most recently was their burritos. Now I know why many come here. It was delicious, great wrap with lots of meat and beans and veggies.

Also tried the Tostada Costena and all were very fantastic!

The good variety of salsa was amazingly hot and spicy! Great lunch spot!
author: T L.

description: Pricey! The food is great, gets crazy busy around lunch time so getting your food takes forever!
author: Nikki K.

description:
Not my cup of tea. I'd much rather do a burrito bowl from Chipotle for a workday lunch. The ingredients are fresh and authentic but somehow it ends up being a bit bland in the flavor department. 

I've had their fish burrito, chicken mole burrito and their enchiladas and none of them were noteworthy. They all had muddled flavors and I had to add a lot of sauces to liven them up. 

The only reason I'd go back is because I literally work across the street and sometimes my Mexican cravings are quite intense.
author: Priya S.

description: This is one of the few places available in the Financial District to find a decent burrito. The place is clean, open space, ample seating both indoor and out. They had a recent remodel and redecoration which has worked in their favor. The prices are a little on the higher side, but the quality is evident. They are open to substitutions and changes to your order (certain fees apply). The salsas are great, but even the mild ones are spicy, so beware. Tlaloc always has aguas frescas available, so don't miss the horchata or watermelon.
author: Carolina R.

description:
Gorgeous day out in the FiDi, naturally everyone heads out of the office for lunch. This place certainly has a line at 11:40 am that spills out into the sidewalk. I had never been nor heard of this place prior to yesterday. An ex-coworker would always rant and rave about this great place that does shrimp in the burritos and I was always curious. Finally she took me! 

We thought we were being smart by getting there early but nope, like I said there was still a pretty massive line. I suppose the trick is to call in your order ahead of time, and then you can bypass the line and head directly inside to pay and pickup your food. First I noticed that the inside of the restaurant went up about 2 more additional stories, all floors have additional seating and a salsa bar (which is FANTASTIC btw). There is also cute seating outside in the alleyway. We ordered our food and sat down on the third floor. I went with what my coworker recommended which is the tierra maria burrito which contains your choice of meat (steak or chicken, and I chose chicken) with shrimp, sour cream, rice, black beans, and guac. I thought it was going to be too much to finish but the portion size was actually perfect, or maybe I was just starving! 

Let me start off by talking about the salsa bar. It's another thing my coworker kept talking about, and let me just tell you their salsa bar is EXTENSIVE and delicious! They have just about every salsa you would want with every different spice level.. I sampled the mango (mild, with tomatoes) and the avocado. Even though the mango stated that it was a mild sauce, it certainly has a kick to it. The avocado was my favorite because it was very light and creamy and surprisingly packed with flavor. The burrito came out at last with a perfect portion of chips. The chicken, the rice and the beans in the burrito were all ridiculously good on their own but the added flavor of perfectly cooked grilled shrimp REALLY made that burrito a straight up home run for me! I devoured that baby like I was never gonna eat another burrito again. No regrets! Shrimp is expensive, man! You gotta finish all of it! I should mention, I also got the watermelon (juice?) which had chunks of deliciously sweet and refreshing watermelon bits floating in it. 

Overall, you really can't ask for a better lunch choice, especially when you're craving really good, really authentic Mexican food. Which I often am :D 

What I recommend: tierra maria (meat & shrimp combo) burrito, any of their fresh squeezed juice! I'm curious to try the spinach one next.
author: Mariko M.

description: Pretty good Mexican food.  Clean establishment, efficient staff.  They make several of their own unique salsas.  I like the three-level seating for the lunch crowd.  A little pricey.  But overall pretty good.
author: LyonQueen P.

description: Had a delicious prawn quesadilla. They put a lot of guacamole on it which is great. I also love the idea of a salsa bar with so many difference choices. The price was also good and wait was not long despite the huge crowd.
author: Fiona J.

description:
Very nice lady took my order. They were officially into lunch menu, but she took my order for breakfast(eggs and chorizo) anyway. She also ran downstairs  to the kitchen to get me fresh coffee.

Perfect creamy refried beans, potatoes, and a tasty eggs and Chorizo scramble. Came with chips, which I used to work my way through the salsa bar. All the breakfast plates are $6.50. The coffee and Mexican chocolate was a bargain at $1.69.  The house made agua frescas looked great.
author: Joel H.

description: There is nothing I don't like about Tlaloc. I have been going every year for my birthday for the past 3 years, including one year I made my company cater it for the office. MUST HAVE the spinach lemonade!
author: mannie r.

description:
I've only been to Tlaloc once and I will not be going back.  When I went I  had a burrito that was around $9-10.  If you like burrito's from the Mission, then you will definitely not like this place.

Pros:
- Organic meat is used
- Salse bar has some good salsa

Cons:
- Burritos are not good
- Takes an extremely long time to get food at lunch
- Difficult to find a seat at lunch
- The workers seem to be annoyed at everyone
author: Dipesh G.

description:
I ordered the chicken mole burrito. It was good, but nothing to write home about. I got a bunch of salsas to try, and liked them... although there was a lack of spice in most of them. 

I found myself feeling a little jealous of the folks with the crispy tacos. I'll get those next time. 

My cucumber Lemonade was great, very refreshing, not too sweet or too tart. 

Seating outside was perfect on the sunny summer day with my co-workers.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I have eaten lunch here three times and it has become one of my favorites. I have ordered three different things.

I had a super burrito with chicken. It was very good.

I had the chicken fajita platter and it was also very good. 

I had the carne asada platter and it was also a winner. 

The platters come with a nice bowl of brown bean soup, side of chips, your choice of flour or corn tortillas, and rice. There is also grilled corn on the cob with spicy sauce. Plus, there is a excellent sauce bar with a wide range of sauces.

Overall, they use fresh premium ingredients and a nice mix of seasonings. You can also try there special fresh drinks. I really enjoy their fresh strawberry beverage.
author: Mark D.

description: This place gets packed at lunch time as does any other place in the Financial District...but it is worth the wait. Delicious Mexican Food!!!! Plenty of seating in doors and out and you can see them making food as you wait in line so you can be confident in what you are about to eat :)
author: Irene M.

description: Good food, nice outdoor seating. You can think of this a local, slightly more authentic Chipotle alternative.
author: Param V.

description: I heard about tlaloc from a friend and I work 1 block away, in the financial dostrict. I went there for the first time last week and had the burrito mexicano, a vegetarian burrito with nopales (cactus). It was soo amazing! Most Everything they serve is organic and grown on their own farm! It is super busy and only open during lunch time so I am going to call ahead next time. They have a bunch of seating set up out front. It's so cute.
author: Soleia L.

description:
The food was very filling here. I got a burrito and definitely couldn't eat it all! 
It's in a very parisian feeling alley way with tables all around.

I also got some of their freshly squeezed juice (watermelon) which I highly recommend.

Although there's a long line the staff moved everything pretty quickly.
author: Alicia M.

description: This place is pretty good for a quick, decent Mexican lunch. I like the outdoor seating. The meats have been on the over-cooked/dry side both times, but the convenience factor is high.
author: Josh B.

description: Love love love everything about this place! From customer service to their system to their nice sit down space to their service to everything is PERFECTO!
author: Jazzy H.

description:
Really friendly service and a great salsa bar!
Food is decent for a quick bite during your lunch break, nothing to out of the ordinary.
author: Marisa K.

description:
I found the ordering process at lunchtime a bit confusing, but hunger will do that to you.  Veggie burritos were good, salsa bar was excellent.  Chips were good but unmemorable.  I liked that there was available seating.  Overall, I'd give the lunch experience 3.5 stars.

Now...  let's talk breakfast.  I was on my way to Peet's for a latte and a  scone, when I saw a sign that said "Chilaquiles."  If you know me at all, you will know that this stopped me in my tracks and made me beeline it into Tlaloc.  They even agreed to make them with green sauce for me.  #swoon.  

I was so fixated on the chilaquiles with green sauce part that I was confused (see: hunger makes me stoopid) when they handed me a bag with what looked like a burrito.  Turns out the offering was a chilaquiles breakfast burrito.  I'll pause while you contemplate the gloriousness of such a thing...

Yes, it was muy delicioso.  I believe birds sang and there may have been a rainbow.  It's 2:30 now and I'm still full.  That is a good deal for $5.  Gracias.
author: Andi T.

description:
Love, love, love this place!!

A good friend of mine, who is a SF restaurant connoisseur, recommended this place for lunch.

I'll start by saying, lunch time is extremely busy over here, so once you get familiar with the menu items, go ahead and pre order by calling ahead of time, and pick up once you get there.

There are plenty of great items to choose from, however, I always go with a burrito. The best thing about this place are all the different sauces! They even have this delicious mango salsa, which is one of my favorites! 

This is a definite go-to place!
author: Tanya A.

description:
Tlaloc offers some great varieties and the flavors there always produce an "mmmm" from my palate.  Love, love, love the shrimp nopales burrito, and for my fellow myfitnesspal users out there it is on there.  Another favorite full of great flavor is the pollo adobado burrito.  Simply delicious.  I'm a big fan of their side sauces, too.  The mango salsa is the best imo, but everyone seems to love the "challenge" of the infierno, which I don't see as a challenge at all.  Anyone should be able to take it.  This is my favorite lunch spot with co-workers to date. 

It would earn a 5th star from me if I found their breakfast burritos the go to place in FiDi.  But, to be fair, I'm still hunting down the best breakfast burrito in FiDi.  For now, Tlaloc does rank #1, but it leaves a lot to be desired.
author: Nick J.

description: Love getting the grilled veggie burrito here. Their roasted garlic salsa is a great addition, but you feel like you're breathing fire afterwards. :)
author: Kate C.

description: My colleagues and I were craving Mexican food so we decided to order some lunch for pickup today. The guy that answered the phone was kind of difficult to understand so I was skeptical as to whether I would get my food right. We get there to pay and pickup the food and the cashier whom I presume may had taken our order read our order wrong. I think he was new because he needed help from a lady standing next to him. He finally reads the right order and I pay. I give them a small tip. I get back to the office and my order was wrong. I ordered a crispy chicken taco and I got a crispy taco which I think was vegetarian. When you're craving something and it's not right.......stomach is not happy!! Then I realized that he gave me the wrong change as well. He shorted me $1.00. The bill was $35.76 so I gave him $100.76 to get back $65.00. I thought he gave me three $20 and five $1.00. My mistake for not checking. Not the end of the world....but when your order is wrong and given the wrong change plus you tipped, now it's irritating. It's worrisome when the register tells you how much you owe the customer and you still get it wrong. That just tells me you're not paying attention. I would suggest them training this guy more on taking orders and on giving change back to customers. The food is tasty here but they get one less star.
author: Tinker B.

description: I have been going to Tlaloc a couple of times a month for years because it is close to work.  The food is good, although a bit pricey for Mexican to go.  This week, I called ahead to order Chicken Nachos, my favorite.  The man to whom I spoke told me my order would be ready as soon as I got there.  Usually, they tell me it will be ready in about 10 minutes.  I made the two minute walk over to pick up my order and there it was, already on the counter waiting for me.  It was not until I brought my order back to work and opened it that I realized I was given an order of Chicken Nachos that had not been picked up earlier by another customer.  The food was cold and congealed.  The counter man sold me an old order for $13 to avoid having to toss it in the garbage and make a new order for me. Tlaloc has lost a good and regular customer over this bad business call.
author: S L.

description: Like their prawns burrito and salsa but pricey at around $14.00 each. Ordered online and trust them omg 3 out of 5 orders went wrong especially the vegetarian order with all meat in there. We went back to change no sorry no smiles but complained about us with other staffs in Spanish. Won't go again unless this place gets picked for our lunch club.
author: Daisy M.

description: BEST BURRITOS EVER!! I got the Super Burrito with chicken and I scarfed it so fast, I couldn't help myself.. It was soooo delicious!
author: Grace B.

description:
Good: Food has great taste, ingredients are good quality, salsa bar is scrumptious, menu has tons of interesting and unique choices.

Bad:  After relentless price rises the cheapest burrito on the menu is now more than $10, which is a little steep.  Food can also be a little salty at times.
author: Pink L.

description:
HEY ESSAY, MUY BUENO BURRITO
(3.75 starts)

No se puede ir mal con huevos revueltos envuelto en una tortilla.. Google that.

ANDALE!! ANDALE!!
decided to step away from the office and find a new place to try in the FiDi that services a quick breakfast. when i mean quick, it means go there,no line, order, and bounce. never thought i'd order a Breakfast Burrito, i'm not much of a Burrito person but decided to try Tlaloc because their breakfast menu is pretty cheap. 

I was tossed between ordering a Breakfast Plate ($5.50) or Breakfast Burrito ($4). I thought taking back the burrito to my desk would be cleaner then a plate. Yah what was i thinking. I went and ordered a Breakfast Burrito.

FRIJOLES CON HUEVO BURRITO - obviously, nothing special. keeping it simple. Organic Farm eggs Scrambled, and refried beans with white corn, and salsa. Muy Deliciousio. El burrito era bueno para lo que es. Come on, $4, can't complain. 

FYI, it's a hotmess to eat. I'll have to try the Breakfast Plate next time i go for breakfast. I also checked out their entire menu, and i'd love to sit and eat there over a few shots of liquor. 

The good thing, they were actually Mexican Americans serving Mexican food. Good stuff!!!!

*Price - breakfast cheap
*Portions - fair and respectable
*Ambiance - clean and cute, hidden location i'd never check for food
*Service - pronto

Will i be back? Yes... next time for Papas con Huevo or Huevos Revueltos


Until the next review.....
author: Jane A.

description:
I don't always write yelp reviews.... but when I do, it's after a fish quesadilla from Tlaloc!

I go here twice a week. Best Mexican food in FiDi. I'd also recommend the chicken chorizo burrito/quesadilla.
author: Akaash B.

description:
There are few Mexican options in the Financial District, so already Tlaloc has bonus points for that. The mariscada burrito was quite tasty, studded with moist shrimp and flaky, sweet fish. I appreciated the variety of drinks available and enjoyed the unsweetened green tea. It's rare that a restaurant has chilled drinks which have neither alcohol nor sugar. Some patrons don't want to guzzle empty calories but would prefer a beverge other than ice water. The complementary salsa bar is a nice touch, with the mango (mild) being a standout. 

So, yes, there are good points but also some bad ones to counterbalance them. First of all, the food has a tendency to come out lukewarm. I once ordered a shrimp and nopales burrito and the entire burrito was tepid. The shrimp was also slightly translucent and undercooked. Thankfully I didn't get sick, but it was vaguely unsettling. And while the mariscada burrito was delicious, filling, and not too greasy, it was missing the calamari that was advertised on the board. And speaking of the board, the pricing is not only high but obfuscated. What kind of menu board doesn't show the cost? There's simply an ominous dot where the price would usually be. Two burritos and two drinks totaled over $30. The sticker shock was not cool. It seems prices have gone up since I was last here too. 

I do not unreservedly recommend this place but I wouldn't avoid it. My opinion on Tlaloc is as tepid as their burritos sometimes are.
author: Busy B.

description:
Located at a convenient place near Financial District.

Price is a bit expensive, but tastes great!

I like the salsa bar. You can try variety of homemade salsas!!

Try to go before 12PM (like 11:30AM) or after 1PM to avoid looooooooooooong lines and crowds.

There are seats inside and outside the restaurant.

Inside the restaurant gets pretty loud.
author: Sunny S.

description: I work in the Financial District and have eaten here regularly over the past five plus years. Generally, the experience is consistently good. They use high quality ingredients, offer fresh chips and a delicious salsa bar. The staff is always friendly. Last time I went in, I bought lunch for two colleagues, so ordered three burritos and paid with my Amex. Call me old fashioned, but I never tip on takeout. When I reviewed my credit card statement, I saw they added a $3 tip to my order. I've contested the charge with my credit card company, but I really have a problem with this. It is dishonest, presumptuous and totally inappropriate. Make sure you watch your credit card statement if you go here.
author: Mike S.

description:
a co-worker brought me here for lunch saying their mexican food is good.  He's mexican so I thought he'd know the best spot.

food:  good but not too authentic.  pricey.
salsa bar is good.

service is pretty good since it can be really busy during lunch rush.
author: Learnee L.

description:
This is our office Mexican outing lunch go-to. They have a lot of seats and a great salsa bar so everyone can pick what they like. They also have a vegetarian menu (though that is easy to accomodate at Mexican restaurants) which makes me decision a lot easier. 

Specifically I love the cactus taco salad + black beans + rice (pardon me for not know the official term). It comes in one of those excellent large taco shells and all the ingrediants are fresh .
author: Raina B.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!

There is a sister restaurant called Cancun in Berkeley where they have 14 different kinds of salsa. But the mole burritos here are soooo good. I ate here two days in a row. 

If only this place was a little cheaper. Burritos are about $9-10 but will put you in a food coma right away.
author: Sophia L.

description: Very friendly staff and awesome food. I love the veggie crispy tacos and spinach lemonade.
author: Alfonso H.

description:
If you like nontraditional burritos and want a nice little alleyway to sit in on a sunny day in the Financial District, this is your place. 

If you go at peak hours, don't be deterred by the line. It WILL be long, but it WILL move quickly. Bring a friend, chat, and you won't even remember that there was a line.

I got the Fish Burrito today ($10.80 after tax), and it was quite good. The fish was moist and flaky, the flavors were strong, overall a solid burrito. All burritos come with chips, so I tried the mild tomatillo salsa and the mild mango salsa. Unlike many other reviewers, I was not a fan of the mango salsa. 

BEWARE: The Regular Burritos DO NOT have rice in them! The Super Burrito does, but the Regular Burrito does not.
author: Talia G.

description: Over-hyped. There really isn't any "great" Mexican food in the FiDi, and this is edible, so I go occasionally. Nothing about the food justifies the long line that forms around noon; I hear people swear by this place and secretly think in my head that its such a shame they've never experienced great Mexican food. Overall, a "meh".
author: Ryan P.

description:
I'm torn between two stars and three stars, because they are so inconsistent here.  The only thing you can depend on is not really knowing how your burrito is going to turn out and I order the same pawn burrito every time.  Sometimes the burrito tastes good and other times like today it tastes dry, cold, and was smaller than usual.  

I've been coming here probably once every couple months in the last several years.  I come back mainly because it is close to my work and it is decent Mexican food.  But when they charge close to $11 for a prawn burrito, it should be consistently good or at least consistent.
author: Mac S.

description: The food is great.  Its tasty.  Its authentic.  Salsas are great.  So why not five stars?  Hmmmmmm.  How to say this.  Its, its, its, its, its,  ....   its, its, its, its, ... its all because of one person.  There is this $%$%&@#$@ lady that talks like a #$%$@#$#$.  Yes, the food is sooo good.  No, I do not have anything else bad to say about the place.  But to put it simply, if I walk in for breakfast, and she is the only person working the cash registers, I go elsewhere.  I suspect she is the niece of the owner, or something to that effect.  She knows everything, lets you know it, has no life, is snappy, judgemental, shallow, ugly (on the inside), and darned it why is there not another good Mexican place within an eight block radius from here? Ironic because there is an older woman who also works the cash register during luch who is a real sweetie.  Wait, turns our Bistro Burger around the corner is serving the best enchiladas this side of the Ferro-Cortina. Too hip, gotta go!
author: Juan J.

description:
AMAZING salsas. I go to this place just for that actually. 

I had a quesadilla from this place and it was amazing. It was very little quantity though. I think they gave me half a quesadilla. Because there were only two slices that looked like half a tortilla's worth. So even though the food was delicious, it seemed overpriced as I paid $9-10 for half a quesadilla. 

I have also had the nachos here and they are okay. 

But the amazing salsas will make any food taste good.
author: Saumya B.

description:
Was brought here for lunch by one of the bf's friends. Didn't know what to expect and what was good since I never got a chance to check out Yelp first.

The bf and I got the mole poblano burrito ($8.50) and the pollo adobado burrito ($8.75). After taking a bite out of both burritos, I didn't think there was much flavor. It was average tasting, but nothing screamed out at me like, "I want to come back and eat this again!"

What did scream out at me for a return visit was the watermelon agua fresca. That drink was DELISH! I tasted the mango flavored one and it was more artificially sweet than the watermelon. I could see myself downing cups and cups of the watermelon agua fresca. Not sure how the strawberry one tastes.

The place was pretty crowded for a weekday during prime lunch hour. We had to head all the way up to the balcony for seats and as we were leaving, people were still standing around for a table. There's seating on the first floor where you place your order and then more seating on the mezzanine (2nd floor) and balcony (3rd floor).

The bathroom is in the basement and there's a small water station in between the 2nd and 3rd floor. The salsas are very tasty, but I find the chips mediocre.

I still enjoy my hole in the wall burrito place, but if your fiending for a different spin on burritos, come to Tlaloc.
author: Janel Y.

description:
Salsa bar is awesome. All the salsas actually taste different which I think is a feat in of itself. Don't pay too much attention to the spicy ratings because we tried a hot that was milder than the milds - and none of them were unbearably spicy. 

I had a chicken chorizo burrito and a carnitas burrito - I have to say I liked the carnitas better. 

The tacos portion-wise aren't worth it because you get way more food if you get a burrito vs 2 tacos and it's around the same price. 

There is outdoor seating but it can get hot if it's sunny. 

Also the vegetarian burritos actually have vegetables in it versus being just meat burritos sans the meat..

Overall I would say really good taste.
author: Gee H.

description:
I feel the need to separate my reviews of this place for breakfast and lunch as they do vary a bit. Food tastes extremely "fresh" and the salsa bar is indeed quite good no matter when you go but...

Breakfast: This place is amazing during breakfast. For $5 you get an extremely filling breakfast burrito and staff is super friendly. You can easily find yourself paying $3.50-5 for a comparable breakfast meal in the FiDi that isn't nearly as tasty, invigorating, and filling. I'm seriously full for almost the rest of the day on one of these. Easily the best breakfast burritos in the area. 5/5

Lunch: This place gets 4 stars on food alone as they're pretty delicious although a bit too wet. However, service is worse and more importantly, for  $10 it is just insane for what you get and I can't in good conscience recommend or pay $10 for a lunch burrito, FiDi or not. I'll have to give this place a 2.5 for lunch.
author: Kyle P.

description:
Apparently, this is a best keep secret for breakfast in the Financial District...especially if you are looking for something beyond pastries and egg sandwiches.  It's definitely a take-out place...but there are tables. 
Fresh, tasty...and organic eggs! Que mas se puede querer! Love the salsa bar too!
author: Marlo G.

description:
Tlaloc is my go-to spot when I have a craving for a burrito in the financial district. Typical to FiDi standards - it's overpriced! Burritos tend to run about $10-ish + tax. I  typically order the Vegetarian or Carne Asada burrito on a whole wheat tortilla. Both are tasty but nothing to rave about. My experience with the the staff is they want you to get in and out!  I've never found them to be extra pleasant or rude, but I've only been here during the lunch rush. 

The salsa bar is by far the best perk of this restaurant. The staff is generally pretty stingy with the salsa cups (they only give you two). When you ask for a 3rd cup they give you a look as if you've asked for their 1st born child! There's an array of salsas and ALL of them are super tasty and fresh. The burritos would be somewhat boring without the amazing salsa (the avocado is my fav). 

If you're in the area and don't feel like making the trek out to the Mission, this is probably the best (most authentic) Mexican food you'll find. Just make sure you DON'T FORGET THE SALSA!
author: Krystal C.

description: Was with a large group of people hastily pushed through the ordering process like cattle. Missed my opportunity to order a drink as I looked around for a Mexican Coke which they apparently don't have. Instead, had to get back in line and pay $2.75 for a shitty tasting fountain Coke. Cashier was rude about it. Mediocre burrito. Didn't enjoy my experience here.
author: David G.

description: One of my favorite Mexican restaurant in FiDi. I must say I have to agree with other reviews; it's expensive but you pay for what you get. I've been going to this place since 2012  and when I come to this place for lunch; I always either get the vegetarian quesadilla (which I personally recommend); the burritos and tacos are good. I've never had a bad experience like other reviews with crushed chips. The best time to come to this place is 1045am - 11th am because it gets pretty crowded during the lunchtime hour. Overall I love this place and I already recommended it to ton of people. ;)
author: Jaiesha C.

description:
Pretty disappointed in this place. I went on the recommendation that their crispy shrimp tacos were "amazing" so I ordered one and a quesadilla. When I got back to my office I found my shrimp taco and a carnitas quesadilla. I was specifically trying to avoid pork - otherwise I would have just walked over to the Wexler's truck. 

Their garlic salsa was good and unfortunately I had to keep pouring that on my taco in order to get away from the flat flavor. Their shrimp was mediocre and their carnitas weren't crispy nor were they flavorful. 

For $11 I can get an amazing lunch in the city - I gave Tialoc a chance and am never heading back.
author: Analisa S.

description:
Ok, the person behind Tlaloc's chicken chorizo is a genius. It's just as amazingly flavorful and spicy as the real thing, minus the snouts, hooves and other porcine mysteries that go into regular chorizo. 

And the warm pumpkin seed salsa??? Makes the accompanying tortilla chips totally worth the calories!
author: Eeeeestar T.

description:
My office once got Tlaloc catering for a build-your-own taco lunch.  All I remember from that meal was that the carnitas was out of this world delicious.

Fast forward about a year and a half later, I decided to head back to Tlaloc on my own to get those delicious carnitas.  Orale Orale doesn't serve any pork dishes, as far as I've seen (wtf?), and Chipotle isn't exactly the most convenient for me either.  I had a craving for carnitas and Tlaloc was my target.

I decided to just get the carnitas plate to go, and man was it worth it!  Yes, it's a bit pricey for $13, but this plate is large enough to split into at least 2 meals.  The pile the carnitas high, and it comes with well-prepared beans and rice.  You also get a few tortillas and tortilla chips, so it's a whole lot of food...awesome!

The carnitas was just as good as I had remembered it to be, well-seasoned, tender, and not too fatty.  I really should have exercised self control and saved half for later, but it was so good I ended up eating it all in one sitting (woops!).  

The one gripe (and it's pretty minor) is that they only gave me 2 "to go" mini cups for salsa.  I didn't think to ask for more, so I'll try that next time.  The garlic salsa was absolutely divine, with great roasted garlic flavor but with a nice spicy kick to it too.  I want to try all of their salsas so I'll have to work my way through that salsa bar.

In any case, I think Tlaloc has some of the best Mexican food in my area of the FiDi.  Sure, it's a tad pricey, but the quality of the ingredients is high and it just tastes really good.
author: Naoko M.

description:
My coworker and I come here at LEAST once per week to grab lunch. It's always bustling and crowded, but the line moves fairly quickly. My favorite is the mole w/ prawns burrito. Consistently awesome :)

+friendly service
+decently priced for the area
+large menu (and you can customize your order)
+delicious fresca! (strawberry, horchata, watermelon, and usually another that varies)
+delicious salsas

Ample seating upstairs! Also, can't wait to try their sangria sometime!
author: Joanna M.

description:
I was craving Mexican food one particular Friday and so I naturally thought of tacos at Tlaloc. It had been a long time (four years??) since I had gone and I always enjoyed the food there. Well something has definitely changed and I don't think it's solely my taste for keeping my diet healthier than before. 

Because I was STARVING  I opted for two tacos. I got one chicken soft taco and one crispy. I was really looking forward to my meal. 

After fifteen mins of waiting my plate came. The tacos definitely looked different from how I had remembered. The tacos, especially the crispy one, were swimming in oil and the crispy taco was overloaded with sour cream. I don't recall ever having such a greasy oily taco from Tlaloc, even the crispy ones. I understand a little oil is needed but this was excessive. The crispy taco was so oily it wasn't crispy anymore but resembled a very oily soft taco. Darn! 

I was absolutely starving so I ate the whole thing right up. But darn you, Tlaloc. You made my diet splurge one hell of a splurge. Lose the oil!

On a positive note, the salsa bar selection was great, just as I remembered it.
author: Rosie S.

description:
I love this place! It has the best salsa bar I have tasted so far. They have a lot of choices and different spice levels for every preference. My favorite is the mango salsa :) :)

I usually go here before 12pm to beat the lunch rush. The burritos are delicious and very filling and the quesadillas are great. Even the vegetarian one. My favorite burrito is the Mole Poblano Chicken Burrito. It is DA bomb. Add your favorite salsa and it gets even better.

For my drink I always get the watermelon agua fresca. Soooo good! Once you place your order, they give you a number and you can get seated. They have dining areas outside, interior street level, and 3 on the upper level. All interior dining areas have their own salsa bars which is very convenient. Especially when you come to know your salsas very well and need to see them often. From these levels and below, you can see the cooks prepare food. How cool is that? Always a plus when I can see and feel good about how my food was prepared.

One con - the metal chairs. I always get my coat stuck on a corner as I pass, and they are not very comfortable. They do have a small area that has more comfortable chairs . I suggest you sit there if you find available seats.

Definitely one of my favorite spots.
author: Shell I.

description:
I haven't made my way through the menu here very much at all, but I know that they have a crave-worthy carne asada burrito. What else do you need?

A salsa bar? You got it. If you get your food to-go they give you a couple of mini containers for salsa, I like to throw a couple of limes in one and put something like mango salsa or avocado salsa in the other. The food is already good, but the salsa bar really adds something. Oh, comes with chips too of course.

The last couple of times I've been my burrito has been JUICY. Little pool at the bottom of the foil, juicy. So snag some napkins on your way out. Tip: Come right at 12 and you'll find no line, come later and you may well find a line out the door!
author: Alyssa G.

description: I would eat the chorizo breakfast burrito everyday of my life if I could.  I have been coming here for years and I have never had a bad experience.  Lunch is good too, although sort of expensive, but breakfast is the real gem.
author: Chris F.

description: This place has good food that is over priced. My biggest complaint is the last three times I have been there they have screwed up my order. And its so jam packed in there you cant check. So you get back to your office and its all screwed up. Third time is a charm they say. So I won't be back. At least during lunch rush hour.
author: Misty M.

description:
Oh Tlaloc, you are alright and I want to like you more, but I just can't.

Pluses: fresh & local ingredients, awesome salsa bar, free chips with burrito

Minuses: regular burritos don't have rice.  

Yes, you read that correctly.  I noticed that "rice" wasn't listed in the list of ingredients for the regular meat burrito but assumed it was a menu mistake because rice was includes in ALL other burrito descriptions (fish, vegetarian & super meat burritos all have rice).  So I accept that I probably should have known it wouldn't have rice, but how can you call something without rice a burrito??  My chicken & bean WRAP was pretty good, but without the rice it wasn't very filling.  For me, burritos are almost always two meals worth of food but this one definitely was not.  

If you are on a low-carb diet, then definitely check out Tlaloc.  Otherwise I'll probably stick to Pasilla or try a super burrito next time.
author: Liz H.

description: Fresh, authentic, gluten free friendly, with generous portions.  Call ahead and skip the lunch rush hour line.
author: Laura K.

description: I don't know why this place has only 3.5 stars on average as the staff are incredibly friendly, they make an amazing huevos rancheros breakfast and fantastic crispy tacos. Also I don't know if most other customers know this but all of the food served here is from the farm that is owned by the restaurant owner so literally the eggs are same day fresh as is the produce. I hope you will try this place and give it a chance as I really feel like it deserves more stars!
author: Andrew p.

description: Yum Yum Yum!  They serve chicken chorizo tacos, which are highly recommended.  But the thing that draws me back over and over is their salsa bar, which is top-notch!
author: Vanessa L.

description: So cal ex-pat: no me gusta. Okay okay it's not horrible and it's good for a grab-and-go, well actually the line is really long. But you get a lot of food? I probably wouldn't go again.
author: Jacqueline M.

description:
Food is common at best.  Salsa bar does enhance the experience.  Definitely over priced for the value.  However, it is fresh and they get 1 star for that.  Nothing extraordinary.  I have tried about 6 different things hoping each time would get better, but it does not.  So the best summation would be:  They did not ruin anything nor did it suck.  It is solidly, consistently, average-ly decent.  Not great.

But what I hate about Tlaloc is I always feel ripped off by them.  They always short the meal, like they are cutting corners to save a buck.  they charge $2 extra for the chile quiles plate because it includes potatoes.  The cashier says if you want the potatoes you must order the plate not the burrito.  Fair enough.  I like their Chile quiles.  Not bad. Fresh.  You can't fail with fresh.  I pay $2 extra and no potatoes.  In their place was a tiny amount of tomatoes.  She just said pay $2 for potatoes then does not serve them!!! really?  not even a subtle rip off that I would miss.

Today - not my choice, I insisted on sushi but my husband wanted Tlaloc (we work together), the fajita plate was supposed to have corn and the salad advacado.  Shorted on both accounts. So they list all these things on the menu, charge you for them and then short you.  $11.75 for an average size salad mind you.  Has the obligatory 6 shrimp but all other ingredients we have at home - romaine, tomato, cucumber.  Not a great value.  BUYER BEWARE.  WATCH WHAT YOU PAY FOR AND MAKE SURE YOU GET IT.  I hate that kind of dishonesty.  Its condescending and sneaky. Don't be cheap, change the menu if you do not mean it.  If you are out of something, say so. I might not order it then.  Either they are deceptive or stupid. Not good business.

Adios, Tlaloc!!!!
author: Marcia P.

description:
wish I could give it 2.5 stars, but 2 good experiences vs 2 meh = 3 i guess.

Breakfast burritos - unique, fresh departure from the typical eggs+cheese+potato+sour creamacado+pig.  Definitely worth trying if you're not fighting off a night of bad decisions.

Lunch - to pull no punches, the seafood burritos are expensive and blah.  They don't taste bad per se but they leave you not caring when they're done.  The chicken burrito (verde mole?) i had there was good.

Salsa Bar -  very legit.  Best quality and variety in the district and they rotate a specialty flavor or two.   Hot means hot by the way, which is awesome.

TIP:  skip the "special".  Usually it's a rehash of something already on the menu for $2-3 more.
author: Matt P.

description:
After my coworker raved about their amazing food, I decided to go check this place out for myself. I ordered a Shrimp fajita which ran me $16!!! That and the fountain soda being $2.50 were my first red flags. The cashier also didn't give me any salsa containers and I had to ask for them while cutting into a very long line of people. 

I made it over to the salsa bar in the back after squeezing through a crowd of people all waiting for their orders, loading up with the Mango and Garlic salsa since that's what everyone is raving about at this place.

Let me cut this story short and say that the fajita was awful. The shrimp tasted like plastic and the tortilla was dry. The garlic salsa also tasted like a bunch of garlic powder and tomato sauce mixed together. 

Needless to say, I was not happy. That's $16 down the drain. Will not be coming back!
author: Bella S.

description: One of the best burrito places around the financial district. The line is long, but moves quickly. The burritos are unconventional, but great, and they have great horchata and salsa.
author: Zach H.

description:
I absolutely love this place. It's a great go to lunch spot in the fidi with great crispy tacos and a diverse selection of salsa.

Only downside is that it does tend to get fairly crowded during lunch time and it is a little difficult to find a place to sit.
author: Gregory K.

description:
Pros: 
AMAZING selection of salsa! 
Fresh ingredients

Cons:
Expensive
Bland 
Long wait

Got a carne asada super burrito wasn't too impressed. It didn't really have the taste of a burrito you would get from a good taqueria. Plus it took long time, cost over $10, and wasn't that big for a $10 burrito.
author: Petar B.

description: Great place for a no frills sit-down lunch spot in the FiDi.  The food is above average and you're definitely going to pay FiDi prices, but the redeeming qualities are the upstairs seating and the bountiful salsa bar.
author: Travis J.

description: I love the food but they always get to go orders wrong. They usually forget a whole meal. but today they just forgot all the extras we paid for. which really sucks. make sure to double check your order before leaving.
author: Madie H.

description:
I was blown away by the flavors, the ingredients, and the huge portion sizes. Farm-to-table Mexican in Fidi is to good to be true... which is why you should expect a line. It took forever, and next time I might order ahead.

Commercial St. is a pretty little alley closed to traffic with a view of the Transamerica building. You can have your food sent to a table, or carry out.

The folks at the counter were so nice and helpful. They recommended the fish fajitas. Got my fish fix, and there was so much food that I had leftovers for dinner.
author: Alyssa B.

description: Went here for lunch after a colleague suggested it. I was excited to try this place after I learned that their sister restaurant is a place I have frequented in the last 15 years or so. Ordered a regular chicken burrito and my colleague ordered a shrimp quesadilla.  We each shared our plates and both were excellent. Well worth the long line and food coma I was in for the next couple of hours.
author: Zannie S.

description: The restaurant is clean and staff is very friendly.  I definitely like the "farm fresh" factor, as they raise their own chickens/eggs.  I had the Mole Verde Burrito for $10+tax.  It was tasty, a little dry, nothing to rave about.  Portion is good.  Salsa bar is great! (which is why it's 3 stars, instead of 2).  They had an Xtra Hot cucumber salsa that was awesome.  My taste buds say that, overall though, it's a little too pricey.  You can get a decent burrito at Chipotle for $4 less.  I'll go back and try a different burrito, or a crispy taco.
author: John L.

description:
I generally come here once a week to eat. At first it was pretty amazing, but since then it's grown on me.

The quality of the meats is undeniable. My favorite is the carnitas, but you should try the chili verde chicken or pork.

Gripe #1: The tortilla steamer. I've seen this at a handful of places. No burrito shop should invest in this satanic device. Tortillas beg to be charred on the grill. -1

Gripe #2: The cheese 'strips'. Who wants a melted band-aid of cheese stuck to once side of their burrito? Proper cheese should be shredded and sprinkled throughout the charred tortilla off the grill. -1

Sometimes my burritos are cold. -.5

But they have great chips & salsa +.5

I mean, I get it. They do a ton of business during lunchtime (get there early, or a little later) and these are some of the ways they save time. Seriously though, a tortilla steamer?
author: Harold C.

description: Don't really have anything bad to say about this place. Yummy food and great salsa bar. Their spicy salsas are ACTUALLY spice. I love mixing the mild guacamole salsa with the spicy ones to get the perfect amount of spiciness.
author: Simmi K.

description: I don't know what planet these other reviewers are from but this is a really great Mexican lunch spot.  They are consistent with their dishes and everything is always fresh. Great guac, great salads, great tacos.  There is a variety of awesome salsas too.
author: Christina G.

description:
This is amazing food. 

Try the Pipian Mole Burrito and then the Mexicana Burrito. The salsa bar is also amazing. 

Both are so delcious. You really need to go here and eat this food.
author: david j.

description:
I got their regular carne asada burrito and was rather disappointed in it. I admit that I ordered a pretty boring thing, and their menu had a lot more interesting options. But still, the burrito was just barely ok. The meat was very thinly sliced so not much juiciness there. 

Here's the biggest issue I had, ALL their salsa are packed with cilantro. 

Now I love Mexican food. I come from Los Angeles, grew up on taco trucks, could eat Mexican food for weeks straight and never get sick of it. 

But I LOATHE cilantro. Just can't stand it. I hear it's a genetic thing, disliking cilantro. But it's not too tough to avoid it in Mexican food. And most places have salsa with and without cilantro. Not here. There's a big selection of different salsa but EVERY SINGLE ONE was loaded with cilantro. Such a bummer. So this review is for all my cilantro-hating brothers and sisters. If you're looking for even ONE non-cilantro salsa or hot sauce here, you won't find it. Not even a single bottle of tapatio or tabasco in sight. 

Also, the prices are on the higher side, but I guess that's in line with every other fidi lunch spot.
author: Hannah S.

description:
The food is average and rather expensive given the average ingredients.  I recently ordered a vegetarian tostado salad which I was thinking as I was eating, not the best choice; very little flavor, and then I found a fly in it.  I wrote to the restaurant and they never acknowledged or replied.
That sucks on several levels.
Won't waste my time or money.
author: Bambi B.

description:
Solid burritos with a ton of options. They're fresh and while they might not be AS tasty as the super fatty ones at many Mission taquerias, they still taste better than the average burrito you'll get across SF with half the amount of grease.

You can call in your order... no need to wait in the ridiculously long lunchtime line. If you are dining in, there are two more levels of seating above, each with their own salsa bar. Win!
author: Richa A.

description:
I was over in SF visiting for business.  Come lunch time I wandered around and came across this place.  Took a look at the menu and said Super Burrito, that's it.  

I ordered it with steak and black beans to go.  $11 total w/ drink.  Waited about 5 minutes for my food.  Got some salsa and sat down to eat.  First bite in, i could taste everything, not just rice or beans, but steak, salsa, cheese, beans and rice.  It was a pretty big burrito, but I ate every bit of it.  It was fresh and sooo good.  I wish I had one right now :(

It was delicious.  I've had a lot of mexican food in my time and this was by far one of the best burritos I've ever had.  

If i'm ever back in SF, i'm definitely making my way back here!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Salsas were the best part of my meal.  The portions were relatively small for the price.  Food and flavors were rather ordinary.  Really underwhelmed by the whole experience.  Felt like the restaurant goes for the "fresh" and organic angle, but it really took away from the authenticity of the food.  

There are far better mexican places in the city.   Maybe it was because I visited during the lunch rush.  I'll try again at a different time.
author: Derek L.

description:
what the f*ck chuck?? did tlaloc change ownership? i went in today for my fav mole with shrimp burrito. adding a tiny scoop of sour cream was a dollar, which is a bit ridiculous but whatever. an average-sized fountain soda was TWO-FIFTY! that's just nuts. in all, my burrito and a soda came out to nearly $16. give me a break.

the food itself was also fairly gross today. the mole was... different. and not in a good way. even worse, the chips were cheap, stale store-bought chips - not the light, crispy and deliciously salty chips they used to have.

so, prices went up. quality went down. looks like i'll be searching for a new go-to burrito joint. sad.
author: Connie S.

description:
On a temperate day you'd be hard-pressed to find better lunch surroundings in the FiDi than you will in the hidden alley that Tlaloc occupies. Tables and chairs are set up on the street and after ordering your food you can take your tiny cups of salsa and have a seat outside while you wait for your lunch to arrive. 

Occasionally pigeons can be a nuisance but if you are careful not to drop chips on the ground near where you are sitting they're more likely to leave you be.

There are better (and cheaper) burritos in the city but when downtown Tlaloc is one of your best bets. Salsa is excellent - be sure to sample widely.
author: Miriam W.

description:
A TALE OF TWO BURRITOS
 
"It was the best of MEXICAN food in the FiDi, it was the worst of nada, it was the age of the delicious HUEVOS CON PAPAS BREAKFAST BURRITO (made with fresh ingredients for $3.50), it was the age of the tasty MOLE POBLANO BURRITO (with grilled chicken, mole sauce, black beans, rice, salsa and queso), it was the epoch of belief, it was the epoch of incredulity, it was the season of 6 kinds of SALSAS (including mango, avocado, and cucumber), it was the season of CHIPS, it was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair, we had everything before us, we had nothing before us, we were all going direct to heaven, we were all going direct the other way - in short, the period was so far like the present period, that some of its noisiest authorities insisted on its being received, for good or for evil, in the superlative degree of comparison only." ***
 
(***Apologies to Charles Dickens).
author: Amy C.

description:
I went to Tlaloc this morning for the first time in about 7 years because a friend told me they have good breakfast burritos. She was so right!

The Huevos con Chorizo burrito is the perfect size and comes with eggs (of course), house made chorizo, refried beans with white corn and salsa. Yum yum yum yum yum. $3.75 plus tax.

I took mine down to the Ferry Building and ate it on a bench overlooking the Bay. Perfect morning.
author: Brad L.

description:
I have only tried there hard tortilla tacos once. I swear it was so freaking good, the best tacos I have ever had, the meat was seasoned so good. I can't wait till I go back!!!

The line was out the door which was a good sign to me, it went down pretty fast. The lady who took my order at the register was very rude though, I know there is a line out the door but chill out lady, she seemed like she wasn't even listening to me order and when I asked for beans in my taco she rolled her eyes. I waited maybe 5 min tops for my order.

I ate outside at the available seating they had, a little unsure because of the stupid lady at the register, I took my first bite. Its like an orgasm in your mouth lmaooo! Its all I can say to describe how great these tacos were. Im glad I decided to try Tlaloc and will definitely return for the food and will disregard the stupid lady at the register. She is the only thing that stopped me from giving Tlaloc a 5 star rating.
author: Madeline E.

description:
***Good***
Food is good and worth coming back to. The building is 3 stories with lots of seating indoors and out. Lots of salsa options.

***Bad***
Hours of operation aren't ideal. Generally caters to casual lunch with coworkers only.

***Recommendation***
Prawns Burrito
author: Nick K.

description:
I dont know why I took forever to write this review- but here goes:

This has to be the best Mexican restaurant in FiDi ,SFO. 
I always get the "Pallo Adobado Burrito" & i have never been disappointed with the taste.The Burrito comes with some chips on the side.All in all it is a satisfying lunch and totally worth the money! The Salsa Bar is another reason i love going to Tlaloc. The Mango Salsa & the Avocado salsa are pretty mild and very tasty.

The waiters & the ladies at the billing counters are so sweet,courteous and always smiling..!! 

If you are in FiDi and you havent tried Tlaloc as yet - you are missing out on something! 

Quick Tip- the mango salsa is always in demand so they run out of it faster,so if you plan on going for lunch : 1:00 is a good time.
author: Monica M.

description:
Really somewhere between 3-4 stars.  I like the food and the salsa bar is great.  But it's just too pricey for the food they serve.  Though they give you a decent amount.

I know that I complain a lot about prices, especially lunch time prices in Downtown SF.  Some people say to just accept that it's going to cost you $10 for lunch there.  Maybe so, but because it's accepted doesn't mean that it's worth it for the taste/value.
author: Ken L.

description: Tortilla soup. Mar y tierra burrito. Mango salsa. I love this fidi lunch spot.  Too bad they don't open for dinner.
author: Helen L.

description: I am a huge fan of Tlaloc, especially of their seafood burrito. The seafood is so fresh and the prawns are always cooked to perfection. This is now my favorite place to get a great lunch in the financial district.
author: Yvette K.

description:
Don't get discouraged when you arrive if the line is out the door and into the alley (which it most likely will be if you stop by between noon and 1 on a weekday). You should move pretty quickly. Me and my buddies were a good ways out the door and got our orders in ten minutes later. These guys are good at moving customers through the line and equally as adept at getting you your burrito in a timely manner, so don't fret if you're on a schedule during your lunch hour.

The menu also may seem a little expensive when compared to something like Chipotle (depending on your choice), but you can taste the quality you're getting for that premium, and you don't have to wait that much longer either. The menu is pretty diverse, including fajitas, seafood options, regular burritos, tacos, salads, a vegetarian menu and a low carb list of selections among other things. Plan on spending ten bucks, give or take two. It all depends how much you want to eat, and wether or not you want to pay for some prawns perhaps.

They have a pretty decent self serve salsa bar to garnish the burrito (or whatever you go with). I went with one of the hot ones and the avocado salsa and both were pretty good. The actually burrito I got was the grilled beef it was fantastic. Tasted fresher than something I would get at a place like Chipotle and it came with a half basket of chips.
author: Taylor C.

description:
The garlic salsa here is like crack.  If they sold it, I would buy it by the jar.  

My favorite thing here is the grilled chicken salad.  Love the salsa bar, the fresh aguas, and the breakfast burritos too.  Only drawback is the noise if you eat in.  Very noisy at lunchtime!
author: Shanthi G.

description:
I went here with a co-worker and was impressed at the large seating (especially in the financial district) and the ambience of the decor. I was also scared to find out their prices. Prices are actually pretty good and it does not stray too far from the average food place in the FiDi. I ordered a chicken mole taco (the first chicken mole taco I've ever had) and noticed they served nopales. I asked for Nopales in the taco and she said of course and charged an extra $1.75. My taco was only supposed to be $4.75 so it was a hefty priced taco. Let me tell you though, it was worth every penny.  They gave me chips on the side and gave me as much Salsa as I wanted. 

I would go back!
author: Enoch L.

description:
A less efficient version of Moe's (Read: Chipoltle, if you're not from the east coast), with a better menu and less of that fast food vibe. 

Ordering was extremely fast, even with the line that went out the door.  The lady at the checkout wasn't the friendliest person in the world, but with the large number of customer's she's trying to push through in such a short period of time, it is almost understandable. The food itself was on par with the fast-food chain Moe's (slightly better than Chipoltle), but their menu was about as diverse as you can get when you're serving the same seven ingredients, just wrapped differently, such as with all Mexican food. I walked out with two "Super Burritos", two small bags of chips, and a large fountain soda for about $19 plus tip. They have a nice selection on their salsa bar, and I would sugest the garlic salsa, if you are a garlic lover.
author: Steve G.

description: Pretty good!  I think this is a great place to go in, grab a taco, and get out the door for around $6.  Not a bad deal, and they have a pretty awesome salsa bar, and outdoor seating on those beautiful Bay Area sunny days!
author: Mel G.

description: I LOVE this place!  I went back to back days and got the same thing ... as a matter of fact, of the three times I have been there I've gotten the same thing!  I LOVE the tacos with carnitas.  Let me re-phrase that - I love the taco (no s at the end).  One taco is plenty for this girl - especially at lunch time!  It is so full of meat, sour cream, and guacamole; not to mention grease from the meat, cheese, and shell - but that's not a complaint from this girl!  While I have only had the tacos, I've been with others who have ordered the quesadilla (which she said was too greasy) and someone else ordered a super burrito which looked good and they were happy with.  The place gets busy but they get you through the line quickly and your food comes out timely as well.  I usually try to go on really nice days so I can sit outside in the alley.
author: Betty D.

description: The qusadilla with carnitas is freaken bomb. Add some green sauce to that and you are in business. However this is a bit on the pricey side for mexican food, but standard for FiDi. Also, lunch hour is crazy packed.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Working in the FiDI, you have so many choices of places to eat. However, there's slim picking for Mexican food, and you don't see to many suits always eating at Mexican food places. 

I went to Tlaloc today to meet a friend. Been wanting to try this place, and what better excuse to meet half way of where we both work than Tlaloc!! 

I was warned they had HOT salsa bar.....I love all hotness!! Wasn't as spicy as I thought it would be, but maybe my friend has a sensitive palate and didn't pick anything spicy. Good excuse to try again! 

Huge selection of amazing burritos, tacos, etc. There's low carb options as well. They claim they farm their own organic food. It definitely is as fresh as it comes. 

there's plenty of seating, three levels worth as well as outdoor seating in front. The line moves quickly during lunch rush and service is amazing! Eat outside, enjoy the fresh air, and watch one of the workers "shoo away" the pigeons when people are done eating and walk away. 

Today I ordered a regular chicken burrito. My friend ordered their prawns burrito. My next visit I want to try their chorizo because its their own recipe....I LOVE ME SOME CHORIZO!!! 

If you're looking for some good Mexican food that uses fresh ingredients, this is your place. If you Mexican food that makes you feel bloated after wards, continue to eat at your hole in the wall.
author: Gwen K.

description:
I went to Tlaloc pretty consistently about nine years ago, and went back today for the first time in about seven years. What I found true today is pretty much what I found back then.

The salsa bar is clutch with various levels of heat that are more than zero to ten. Lots of subtle uses of chipotle and avocado.

When they aren't to slammed the food is great. But during a rush like today I got a shrimp burrito that had way too few shrimp and a mole that was more like a tomato soup than anything else. I agree with Kim too about the "buck" factor--this was not a nine dollar burrito by far. If I wanted to pay too much for a great burrito I'd go to Little Chihuahua or Green Chili Kitchen.
