author: Paul C.

description:
Taco Tuesday on July 5th?  Better up the order to soak up the booze-belly left over from my patriotic partying yesterday.

With all the drinks yesterday, I splurge on the prawn soft tacos and sour cream & the crispy taco staple...  pretty stoked until I count TWO Shrimp TOTAL. For 2 tacos, there are 2 shrimpy shrimp? 
Tlaloc you are better than that.  

For those not smarter than a 5th Grader- If you have 2 tacos and you get 2 shrimp = each mini corn tortilla generously loaded with ONE shrimp.

Lucky for my hangover I gave the finger to frugality and still ordered my fav crispy taco. After the major scrimp on shrimp, I was my own hero. MORAL OF STORY... Don't fix what  isn't broken... Mango-up with the Crispy Carne Asada... & damnit go big, go home... or just go hungry.
author: Courtney B.

description:
Absolutely delicious burritos. Nothing against Chipotle, but Tlaloc is definitely a class above. That said, it's in a higher cost tier as well, hence no fifth star. This place really is awesome, but since a little pricier it belongs in the "occasional" bucket rather than the "staples" bucket. That said, if you haven't been here, you'll no doubt love it (if you approach knowing that it costs more than typical burrito spot).

Especially good when it's a nice day and you can sit outside in their large seating area! And don't forget the salsa bar!
author: Peter C.

description:
Ambience:

Went for lunch during the workweek and tried their pollo adobada burrito.  The first thing I noticed was the plethora of spelling errors on the menu (the menu literally spells every word wrong: Pallo Adabada Burrtio").    Also had to wait about 15 minutes to get my burrito for takeout and it wasn't even that busy.  This is nearly inexcusable for a service business catering to a predominantly corporate audience.

Food:

The best way to describe my burrito is: "the sum-of-the-parts is much greater than the individual pieces"  (like most burritos).  Norcal-people (I understand Socal burritos to be slightly different) like to jam tons of things in their burritos (guac, sour cream, etc), and because of this, subtle flavors tend to get lost quite easily.  I really enjoy good adobada (tacos el gordo :), but here it didn't taste any different to me than a standard pollo asado since all the other ingredients pretty much drowned out the flavor. If this was a $5 burrito place, it would be stellar, but I paid nearly $10 for a burrito and a small portion of chips.

Would I come back?  Sure, the food is actually quite good, just nothing to write home about.  Next time I hope to try something a bit simpler to get an "honest" taste of the flavors, especially since FiDi has a lack of good mexican food.
author: Hannah C.

description:
What can I say - I work a block away and my only other options(for mexican food) are made in a truck and contain bits of plastic or have a reputation of making customers sick to their stomachs.  So I was glad to have found this place in a sunny side-alley off of Sansome.  Until I ate their food - then I was REALLY glad.

I should mention that all I really get are the burritos(with a few exceptions that were a good while ago), so here's a burrito review:
It's a little pricey(bout 8-9 bucks), but COMPLETELY worth it.  All ingredients are quality.  Delicious(one of my faves in SF, actually) and not so big that you turn into an unproductive blob after lunch, but they certainly fill you up.

SALSAS - great salsa bar, but get ready for some KICK!  Even the medium salsas give my face a sinus-clearing pink hue, but they are tasty, just beware if you have an aversion to spice.  And +1 for the most ingenious salsa spoons ever invented. 

Oh and yeah, they are SUPER quick.  I imagine other plates probably take longer, however my future-viewing power isn't 100% accurate... so... maybe not?  probably tho.


I've basically been here a few dozen times and the only time I had a bad experience, it was because a pigeon decided to take a dump on my head.(!!!)  The food was still pretty good that day tho.
author: John T.

description:
Yummers:
Sangria. Oh my goodness. I could have sat there and drank sangria all day and not even care that the wine comes out of a box. It had strawberries in it. I have to do that next time I make it myself. 

To eat with this sangria (cus you just can't have sangria by itself) I recomend the pineapple salsa. Don't really care what you have with it, as long as you have the pineapple salsa. No, wait...don't it's awful. YOU DO NOT WANT THE PINEAPPLE SALSA. There. Now I get it all. Muahahahahah! Err...

Seating is limited, but we went for a late lunch. Burritto is good, but not as good as sangria and pineapple salsa. If I could life off of sangria and pineapple salsa, well...I doubt I would loose weight, but it would taste mighty good...(but I won't, cus sangria hangovers ...suck.)

That is all. Stay away from my salsa, but if you're nice I'll share my chips with you....
author: Danielle L.

description:
First things first ... a warning to everyone who is thinking of getting nachos...DON'T.  It's not nacho cheesy cheddar cheese ... but rather dried white crusy cheese on what becomes stale chips...

Instead, turn your attention to their seafood burritos and get yourself a juicy, large-portioned prawn burrito.  Then, head over to salsa heaven and fill up one of those containers with the INFIERNO SALSA (a little goes a long way....to hell...)  and don't forget to refill your cup with water when you need it (which will be FREQUENT)  Man, it hurts so good...

SALSA BAR RULEZ...and so does their prawn burrito.  OH!  ANND there's upstairs seating...2 extra floors!?! CHAA!?
author: Kat C.

description:
I want to love you, Tlaloc, I really do. But I'm just not impressed with your bang-for-buck factor (or lack thereof). Both the veggie torta and veggie quesadilla left me wanting more. Especially after at least $8.

Don't get me wrong, they were tasty, but less than filling. I could eat at least two of their quesadillas (And this is coming from a girl who gets full way before everyone else. Maybe I inadvertently went on days where I starved myself beforehand? Probably not, I like eating). I'll keep coming back to you though, because you are close to work and it's decent Mexican food. I'll just have to suck it up and deal with the prices. Or stop being a fatty.
author: Kim B.

description: Good tacos, love the different salsas and great service.
author: gina b.

description:
Overpriced, but still pretty good.  My one complaint with the carne asada is that I had to cut it myself.  If you're going to give me tortillas and all the fixin's, don't make me cut my own carne asada.

I'm still feeling the burn of the very hot salsa.  Hope everyone on the plane tonight enjoys it too.
author: Mike F.

description:
Okay, so I'll admit that I frequent this place because they have plenty of outside seating and on sunny days, it is a treat to be able to sit outside for lunch. 

I like the fact that they have a huge menu to choose from so you can always get something different; I have yet to order the same thing twice. 

They have shrimp fajitas or tacos or burritos. Their shrimp dishes are quite tasty. Their burritos are huge and my co-worker was not able to finish hers. This place has really decent food for a satisfying meal. You can get lunch here between $10-$17 dollars. 

Oh! They have a pretty good salsa bar. Do try their mango salsa. 

And you can people watch as you eat your lunch.
author: Elaine L.

description: A gem in the FiDi especially if you're looking for a breakfast burrito made with organic eggs and in-house chorizo... $5 bux! Why complain about obesity when limiting portions is an actionable step to eating less and maintaining a healthy weight. Breakfast burrito + chips + in-house salsa + $5 bux! Support local, fresh ingredients...can't beat that, especially in the heart of FiDi.
author: Linda P.

description:
I really wanted to give this place 3.5 stars but without half stars, I'm rounding up.

I used to always go to Cancun in Berkeley, and I don't quite remember this place being so fancy (i.e. having so many options/choices).  Call me a simpleton, but sometimes, too many choices is overwhelming.  I just wanted a burrito.  With meat.  And I don't like mole.  So you can see how this place could be overwhelming with an equal amount of space voted to vegetarian, seafood and non-vegetarian/non-seafood items.  I was so confused - where's the meat?  It took me a while to find it...

I got the chicken adobado or something like that; honestly, I was so flustered at the registered, I just ordered it.  It was good, a solid three star burrito in my book.  But I LOVE the salsa bar, the mango salsa in particular.  If only those little containers were bigger...

The outdoor seating is also perfect on those few warm sunny days in SF...
author: Wendy L.

description:
Relaxing place to dine during *non-lunch rush hours*.  Great place to eat outside on those rare warm San Francisco lunch hours.

Food is fresh & flavorful.  I'd classify it as 'upscale Mexican'.  

Nice ambiance ~ love the high ceilings, skylight, brick walls, and colorful artwork ~ check out the upstairs dining area.  Good 'gourmet' salsa bar + service is efficient & friendly.
author: Cathy K.

description:
My all time favorite Mexican Burrito place! 
Every time I go, I order the spinach tortia chicken burrito. 
The salsa's are awesome - my fav is mango salsa! yummmmm!
author: Parminder Nayyar C.

description:
Tlaloc is the SF Financial District version of Cancun over in Downtown Berkeley.  I'm glad Tlaloc is nearby my office, but I wish it were a little more like it's Berkeley counterpart.

Tlaloc has 2 stories of seating above the ground floor, which is really nice to have that kind of capacity in the Financial District -- convenient for a rainy day.  Their selection of burritos, tacos, and other dishes is similar (identical?) to the Berkeley location, and I'm glad they have an assortment of dishes with nopales (cactus), which you don't see on too many menus.

One of the fortes of Tlaloc are the mole sauces -- they're flavorful and delicious, so if the description sounds good to you, chances are you'll like it.

Sadly, the salsa bar at Tlaloc is not as extensive as at Cancun.  Maybe that's coloring my review too much, but it's so nice to have twice as many options ;)  Still, there's some good ones to be had.

Tlaloc is A-Ok, definitely worth making a lunch stop.
author: David W.

description: Best super burrito of my life, and I thought San Francisco didn't do Mexican food. Man, was I wrong... this place continues to blow my mind.
author: Krista K.

description:
I heart this place.  Last time, I had the crispy chicken taco.  The menu listed it at about $8.00.  I remember thinking "8 bux? They must have left the 's' off 'taco'--I'm sure I will get two for that price."

NOPE.  T'was ONE TACO.

However, it was scrumptious.  If they were not so HIGH and I wasn't surrounded by co-workers, I woulda went back for another.  

YUM.
author: Virgo M.

description: I don't understand the hype about this place. I've given it 3 tries now, ordering something different each time, and each time I've been disappointed. The tostada and salad I had were both soggy and bland, the tomatoes hard, and lettuce slightly better than iceberg. The prawns in the salad were grilled well, but they forgot the avocado after I specifically asked for it. They lost a star for that alone. The vegetarian burrito was the best of the items I had there, but there are far better burritos in the Mission for much less. My guess is that the salsa bar and the decor are the real draws.
author: Nik S.

description: I'm not going to mince words here.  Tlaloc's carnitas are the best I have ever tasted, including my own - which I never thought could be topped.  I don't know if it's the Nieman Ranch meat or just the slow cooked perfectly seasoned technique, but I have yet to find better pork anywhere in the Financial District (or the City) that even comes close.  I always order the crispy taco carnitas "ala carte' and the amount of carnitas on the taco (literally ON it, not IN it) is enough to fill me up until a later dinner.  It is plenty of food for one person - and cheap!  I know of no other Mexican restaurant in the area that will load up that much delicious carnitas onto a crispy tortilla FOR UNDER 6.00 BUCKS!  I love this spot and I have recommended it to countless friends and associates for a lunch time meal.
author: Angela I.

description:
Eh - I wouldn't really go here if it weren't right behind my office. 

The burritos are alright - but in a city with amazing and cheap burritos, alright is like a D. They aren't very big, and they are like $10! A $10 burrito that doesn't fill me up through dinner -crazy. And they have signs up that say they get their produce from their own farm. I asked a staffperson once where the farm was, and they said Mexico. Maybe they were wrong, but if not false advertising - a sign like that makes you think it's local!

But yet, I go back because it's right by my office and the pilgrimage to papalote just takes too much time.
author: Sue A.

description:
Roasted pumpkin seed salsa?! Yes, please... It is earthy and spicy, not spicy like burn your mouth spicy, although they have that kind of salsa too, if you are into that, I mean full of spices. The garlic salsa is great too. It is garlicky without tasting too 'I'm a marinara sauce masquerading as a salsa'.   I was not a fan of the avocado dip, as it was too watery for me. I am told that is the way it is supposed to be. It was just a matter of preference for me. I had the carnitas Super burrito. Holy smokes! Trust me when I say this, BEST carnitas ever! And continue to trust me when I tell you, I have had my fair share of carnitas to be a bit of an expert. The guacamole was fantastic too. It tasted very fresh. The rice and beans inside the burrito were flavorful and the texture was perfect. I am also a bit of a tortilla snob. I like them homemade and these were about as homemade tasting as I have ever had. 

One of the best things about this place is all the spots to sit. They have outdoor dining, in addition at least 3 or 4 levels of dining. Each level has a salsa bar and a water jug. Very convenient. 

With so many different things to eat there, you will not be disappointed. I highly recommend checking it out.
author: Nichole G.

description: Yummy Mexican food and super close to where I work. They have a solid salsa bar and cute outdoor area! Very pleasant. Pretty pricey but what isn't down here
author: Mimi D.

description:
Usually Mexican food is a little heavy for me, but Tlaloc really hits the spot.  Headed here for lunch with a couple of co-workers a bit afternoon and hopped in line, which moved quickly.  We ordered and headed upstairs (they have outdoor seating in the alley, as well as three levels of seating - pretty cool!)  Each level has a salsa bar and pitchers of water - which you will need after some of the spicier salsas.

I ordered two grilled fish tacos and my co-workes had the grilled prawn burritos.  My tacos are awesome, fresh flavorful fish with lovely toppings and my co-workers' burritos looked great as well.  Each of the entrees came with chips so we grabbed some fixings from the salsa bar (mango and cucumber were both awesome additions) and made a leisurely meal of it.  Overall very tasty and I left full but not overly stuffed, which is a good thing!  I'd come back for lunch again or for afterwork happy hour, especially on a nice day to sit outdoors amidst the cobblestones.
author: Jaimie M.

description: First visit rounding up from 3.5 to 4. Solid burritos, convenient location, and good value. I had  the regular  and my wife had the mole, both were very good. Interesting salsa's that as someone else pointed out, actually do taste different.
author: Gregg S.

description:
I didn't know Berkeley's Cancun had a sister over here!

The good: fresh-tasting food, organic veggies, awesome salsa bar, huge light-filled space with pretty Mayan-style murals. Lots of veggie options.

The less good: Burritos are smallish, beans are bland. Also, the world's best salsa bars (e.g., Cactus, Sol y Luna) have cabbage salad.

Bottom line: If you like your burritos grease-less and you've adjusted to the nutty prices of lunch items in the FiDi, this place can't be beat.
author: Mike B.

description:
Yes, the past reviews are right:  The salsa is amazing.  The burritos will cost you $10.

Why come here for the salsa?  Because if you love garlic, then come here and experience the perfect marriage of a garlicy salsa.  Delicious!  Just remember to bring a breath mint for after wards.

As for the $10 burritos: Yes, these won't have me visiting the place weekly, but on occasion when I want a deliciously fresh burrito I'll be back in the Tlaloc lunch line.

The food is tasty, yet pricey, the salsa bar is fantastic and the outdoor seating is a plus.  Also, the margaritas are tasty, but the pitcher of sangria totally missed the mark.  It was refreshing but really lacked any essence of alcohol.
author: Lisa R.

description: Awesome salsa bar, authentic mexican food. Good for small team sit down lunches. Order whatever is on special (displayed right as you come in).
author: Bryan L.

description:
Once again this place is a little bit pricier than most other burrito places. But considering it is located in financial district, it is not much of a problem. 

The burrito here is great, and I can confidently say that their burrito is the best in financial district.
author: Jun W.

description:
If you want really good Mexican food in San Francisco, head to The Mission.
If you crave really good Mexican food and are in the Financial District, this place will do. The salsa bar is delicious and creative (I love their cucumber salsa, and the mango one).
 I have three recommendations: 
1. If you love having breakfast - a real, eggs, black beans, big breakfast -  this is your place. I don't think anyone else in this neighborhood comes close.
 2. If you come for lunch, order the shrimp burrito. Fresh seafood seems to be their specialty.
Finally, 3. be prepared to stand in line.
author: D Z.

description: This is truly one of the best farm-to-table restaurants I've ever experienced.  Super fresh, authentic, delicious Mexican with fabulous salsas!!! I was only in town for a couple of days and I loved the food here so much that I went as often as I could. The tacos are savory and they don't skimp on the filling.  The emphasis is on fresh, locally-grown ingredients and friendly service.  Go early because during lunch hour there is a line out the door.  Love this place and highly recommend for lunch.  If the weather is beautiful plan on sitting outside; they bring the food to you.  Thank you Tlaloc.  I am a true foodie and you are what I consider a true foodie restaurant :)
author: Barrie H.

description:
I can't believe after 3 months of working literally 2 blocks away I just got to have lunch at Tlaloc! My friend Jen. N recommended this spot to meet for lunch today and I being always game for trying new Mexican food was up for the challenge. 

The three things I loved most were: 
1. The Salsa Bar - The different salsas were impressive and the two that I choose were muy bueno! All looked delicious and fresh 
2. The flavors inside my Prawn Burrito - At $9.50 I was expecting a bit more than a burrito and some chips thrown on a plate, however the flavors and black beans were perfect. 
3. Seating on multiple levels with Salsa Bars on them! I found it easy and efficient especially during the lunch rush. 

A great lunch spot with a ton of options will have me coming back for more and more in the future!!
author: Heidi S.

description:
I mostly love this place.  The soft chicken mole tacos are the thing I keep ordering over and over again -- so yummy!  Their tostada salads are quite excellent too.

One thing they ought to change, however, are the chairs.  The tips of them get caught on whatever you're wearing and it's not only annoying but treacherous to move about in this restaurant!
author: Jill T.

description:
Ambiance: Busy lunch hour. Indoor and outdoor seating.

YUM: Carne asada quesadilla! This is one of the top 5 quesadillas I have ever had! The meat was tender and the cheese was melty.

Money Honey: $8.50

Service: Fast considering it was lunch time in the financial district.

Notes: Portions are not big, but the ingredients are fresh. Try the cucumber salsa/relish. It's really good!


Eat it. Really like it. Repeat.
author: Jenna s.

description: Wow how things change. These guys use to have the best carne asada but no more.  I went in today to order a super burrito.  It never came. When I brought it to their attention they gave me a burrito and sent me on my way.  Got back to the office only to find out it was cold and sitting out and not what I ordered.  So I brought it back and they made me a new one.  No offer to comp or discount my meal. The second burrito was mediocre.  Carne asada tasted like boiled meat. The super burritos have decrease in size while the price has increased.  I will not be coming back to this establishment.
author: H Y.

description:
More burrito places?  Yes, there are quite a few here in FiDi and my coworker was on a mission to find the best one.  So my 2nd burrito in as many weeks.  Works for some people but I'm already ODing on burritos.  I'm more like a once every couple of months type.

This place is tucked away in a little alley that you would probably never notice unless you knew it was here.  And don't be fooled by the seating outside, that's for the Mixed Greens place across the street.  They may try to lure you in through the seating but turn up your nose and continue on to Tlaloc.

Burritos were pretty fancy.  Spinach or tomato tortillas?  Whoah.  It's a little overwhelming.  The burritoas are pretty tasty but my favorite thing is the salsa bar.  But be careful, one of the salsas is hot and smoky hot, and the other salsa is hot and like habenero hot.  Both have the same "hot" label.  

And no, I didn't try anything other than burritos.  I'm hedging my bets that if I want good Mexican food, probability of that happening is higher in the Mission, which is close to where I live.  Too many disappointments in FiDi....
author: Jean K.

description:
(Stars based on my first time)

WOW. I have never been this taken away by any crispy taco before! I'm at my office right now wanting to scream out because this is sooooo good! And I've only had a couple of bites!

Oh haha I forgot to tell you...I'm eating a crispy taco with carnitas meat. OH man the meat is so juicy, tender and packed with flavor! My taste buds are going crazy I think I'm going to cry :)

I took with me 3 different types of salsa

- Mango: wow! this is so sweet, it's yummy
- Garlic: mm and a how lot of taste, vampires beware!
- Pineapple: again, also sweet and fruity, yet has that mm so good salsa punch!

I'll have to try something else there and edit this comment. I can't just put 5 stars without trying more of the menu. But in terms of having this for the first time, it has to be my fav. mex. joint to go.

Oh and PLEASE if you beg to differ, let me know what you think is better so I can go there and try it out too!
author: Quinallison D.

description:
This place has hands down the best salsa bar.  They are generous and use real ingredients so the salsa is not watered down.  Also this place has the best breakfast burritos in the financial district.  I always order mine without beans and they are mmm mmm so tasty.  Five stars for the breakfast.

They use fresh ingredients in their burritos so you always feel you are getting something healthy and hearty.  Also they have amazing prawns and shrimp which is hard to find in the burrito combination.

The seating is also great.  You can sit outside in the sun or upstairs.  The prices are a bit on the high side for a burrito and sometimes they run out of sangria.  It kinda sucks when you walk all the way there and they dont have sangria.

Overall I highly recommend it.
author: Samantha S.

description:
I live in the Mission.  I eat from the taquerias around here all the time.

But I don't crave any of them the way I crave Tlaloc.

Their tacos are amazing (I get carnitas or carne asada).  Their carne asada super burrito is my go to choice.  And their plain quesadillas are fantastic too (must be the cheese).

As for the salsas, I love them all.  But my favorite is the garlic salsa.  So good, nice spice, and it goes perfect with my burrito.  It also ensures that my boss will not come near my office for the rest of the day.

Last but not least, their aqua frescas are delicious and fresh.  The strawberry in particular is like eating a bowl of strawberries.  Literally.  There's easily 4-5 sliced strawberries floating at the top.

It's overpriced compared to the Mission, but it's also the FiDi.  You have to understand that. 

And it's a hail of a lot more satisfying than a Mixt Greens salad from across the alley.
author: Courtney N.

description:
I love the salsa bar!

I'm not usually in the Financial District, but when I find myself in the area after running some banking errands, I always pop in for a taco (or two if I'm huunnngggrryyy) and I pour two or three (or maybe four) different salsas on top. That infierno salsa + the garlic salsa!!! Yum.
The staff there is really efficient and friendly.
While I've had better Mexican food, this place is fresh, fast, and reliably tasty. I would have given them just 3 stars, but when they have their yummy, chunky fresa... ahhh... That fresa deserves a star! Actually, come to think of it, I actually went down there one day specifically to get a fresa. lol. Sad.
author: marianne c.

description: Love this place. Go here for an easy lunch in the financial district. Recommend the carnitas super burrito.
author: Charles S.

description:
I love this place!  

So I figured after my 200th time there, I should post a review.

Fast food Mexican places are a dime a dozen.  Every now and then you find a special one, like the super authentic ones you find in San Diego, and I am sure are hidden in the Mission or somewhere (message me if you know of any!).  And this place.  It's greatness does not lie in a couple of handed-down-from-generations recipes, but rather in their execution of the standard Mexican fast food items.  They grow thier own vegetables -- who does that?  And they use the finest Bay Area meats, I believe Neiman Ranch.  Everything is crazy good.  And healthy.  And doesn't feel like a brick in your belly afterward.

The people are also really friendly.  As friendly as people can be with a line of customers out the door to serve.

Also, on the employees, the faces there NEVER change.  So either it is a family place with a huge family of people all around the same age, or the owners really take care of their employees.  Nice to see.

BTW - Kudos for providing real napkins.
author: craig F.

description:
I have to say, that my prior experiences with Tlaloc have been great. Today was a totally different story. I understand that, like me, everyone else thought today would be a great day for Mexican food - it's Cinco de Mayo!  And I figured they would be a little busy. But this was inexcusable.

I faxed in my order for the office (9 items) and they called back relatively soon. I had asked for food to be ready 12:00p, but that was cutting it to close so they asked if 12:30 was ok. I agreed, and asked Cupid Courier to be there at such time. I got a call, not from the restaurant but from Sean to inform me the food would take an additional half hour.  So that puts us at 1p. 1:30p rolls around, I have hungry staff and I'm kinda over this whole celebration thing. Sean arrives food in hand - but asks if everything is there, seems kinda light. I go over the receipt and they have left off one item. Turns out, half the order was missing! 

Not wanting to burden Cupid with standing in for the angry customer I have now become, I hop in a cab to straighten this out. When I walk up to the register, I ask to speak to the manager. I watch as she brings my order to someone (I assume the manager, but who knows), they point to a bag sitting on the sidelines, and she starts double checking to see if the items I said were missing are in the bag. Turns out that the item not on the receipt was not being offered, so they replaced it with a burrito. Hmm, no phone call? Oh, right - no phone call that the food is going to be late, no phone call that half the order was not given to the courier, and no phone call that they replaced an item. Does anyone else see a pattern.

I used to order from Tlaloc for company lunches. I used to eat there somewhat regularly. They have now lost a customer. I don't care how good the food is, it tastes very different cold.
author: Michelle R.

description:
I just finished my Super Carnitas Burrito. I am a little disappointed that we live in a world where $10 burritos are the norm....that being said, this was a pretty darn good burrito. (I don't usually use the word "darn" but this is a family site...) 

The Carnitas was flavorful, the ingredients were fresh and they have a pretty sweet salsa bar. Overall this is a pretty reliable burrito joint. 

There was a bit of a line, but it moved pretty steadily and I didn't have to wait long for my food. I can easily say I will be back for more!
author: Ken V.

description:
Good clean fresh tasty food. not sure if this is real mexican food.but i like it.
they seem to have reduced the number of salsa's. not all salsa's are in all floors.
author: yelper l.

description:
I went to Tlaloc for lunch today and was happily surprised by this Mexican restaurant. 

This place provide a wide selection of dishes and even feature a "Low Carb" menu that are basically dished with no rice and beans that are replaced instead with salad and/or veggies.

I was there during rush hours and the line moved fast (waited less than 10 mins to place my order). It was also easy to find a table since they do provide tables on three levels. They don't have any outside seating however.

Staff is efficient and they will find you even if you are "hidden" on their last floor.

I've got a chicken breast burrito that feature a whole-wheat tortilla, grilled vegetables, mushrooms, lettuce, salsa fresca, and grilled tomatillo salsa. Grilled chicken was great and everything was yummy!
The dish comes along with a few tortilla chips that were very crispy.

==============================

Pros:
- Line is moving fast, even during rush hours in Financial District. Much more efficient that Mixt Green which stand accross the street.
- Tables available on three levels.

Cons:
- This place was chilly. A heater during the winter would let us remove our coats while eating :-)

Cedric's favorite option:
 - Chicken Breast Burrito (Low carb menu) for a new burrito experience. Very filling!
author: Cedric L.

description:
Come to Tlaloc if you are looking for tasty but pricey Mexican food. At least it was a nice, sit-down establishment with 2 floors and outdoor seating. Unlike the taco truck by my work, they actually had a variety of options to satisfy every craving! Great vegetarian choices too which was a plus. My main gripe was that NO prices were posted on the menu for some reason (just said AQ, or "as quoted"). What's up with that? It's not a seafood place! 

I ordered the grilled veggie burrito that consisted of a spinach tortilla, black beans, cheese, guacamole, salsa, rice, and chunks of veggies. It was one of the better burritos I've had...wasn't laden with cheese nor overstuffed. The components were spread out nicely so that I wasn't just eating beans or rice in a bite. The salsa was amazing too! It also came with a side of fresh tortilla chips that were perfectly crunchy.  Overall I thought the meal was delicious, filling, and healthy!

I LOVED their wide selection (7-8) of salsas too but be warned...their "mild" was pretty spicy in my opinion. The flavors were pleasantly robust in the 2 that I sampled but I thoroughly enjoyed the mango salsa. Having salsa as toppings makes a world of a difference! They also delivered our plates of food to where we were seated and provided clean utensils. Not your typical hole-in-the-wall Mexican place so it was a change I welcomed with open arms.

2 medium fountain drinks, a burrito, and my friend's prawn quesadilla came out to around $25...yes, definitely overpriced especially when I live in the Mission District and can get dirt cheap Mexican food but still pretty damn good. I would come back since you do get what you pay for!
author: Karen Y.

description:
Tlaloc is a decent place to grab some Mexican food if you're in the mood. It's not the greatest Evar, but it works for me. The food is definitely fresh and a very good quality. 

I would say it's also probably the best place to get Mexican food within a half mile radius. (Mercedes, if it still exists, is overpriced and just, low in quality in my opinion; Taqueria Zorro, just no)
author: John G.

description: I guess I don't get the appeal of blowing 14 bucks on a burrito.
author: david p.

description: I take my friends here when I want to make a good impression. Amazing food in an incredible space -- my very favorite lunch spot in the financial district, hands down. Never disappoints. My only request is that they had longer hours -- I'd love to be able to come here for breakfast or dinner too.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I just went to Tlaloc for the second time and made the mistake of getting carnitas, which is why they are only receiving 3 stars.  The place is pretty cool, nice atmosphere. They have three levels of indoor seating and a lot of outdoor seating.  

I would not necessarily say it is authentic Mexican food, but it is a lot closer then Chipotle is.  The menu is very large and good for all types of people.  If you are to go I would recommend getting the carne asada or chicken, which I would give four stars.  The carnitas was very fatty and made me cringe a little while eating.

The positive thing is they have a very good salsa bar that offers about 6-8 different salsas that make the burritos that much more delicious and all the burritos are under $10.
author: Johnny A.

description:
Good variety of plates and salsas. It's a large place, almost cavernous which is cool.  

Some plates can be a bit bland - like the chicken taco.  Burritos are pretty good. A bit pricey for what it is but still a decent mexican restaurant.  

Never been for dinner - just lunch.  So keep that in mind.
author: King K.

description: I felt it was a bit pricy for a lunchtime counter burrito ($11) with no table service, but the ingredients and flavors were really good, so you get a premium product. Also the salsas were quite tasty. The delivery to the tables was poor. The guy stacked plates with food on top of each other squashing the food. Not acceptable. However the lady at the counter was very nice and helpful. My carnitas burrito was super flavorful with large tender chunks of marinated pork. I've had bigger burritos, but left feeling satisfied. The little side of chips was meager. Like 6 chips. I wanted more. Especially with those amazing salsas. All in all, a mixed bag.
author: Brian C.

description:
I'm a fan.  Yup.  A fan of their crispy tacos, specifically their carnitas crispy taco, with their cucumber salsa.  YUM.  Heaven on these lips.  Their carnitas is always delicious, with flavorful crispy edges, tender juicy meat, stuffed into their in-house made crispy taco shell, with jack cheese, sour cream and guac.  Your choice of salsa from the awesome salsa bar (the cucumber salsa is my weakness).  Yummy.  One taco is enough to fill me up and I have a hefty appetite.  Two tacos are enough for a hungry guy... trust me.  I went today with a bunch of peeps from work, most were big guys with good appetites, and they couldn't finish three... and they were really trying.  

People, yes they can be a little pricey, but c'mon...  it's not taco bell, and it's not some divey taqueria, they make quality food.  It's worth a try.  I should mention, they have outdoor dining, and three levels of interior seating.  All levels equipped with a water station, and salsa bars.  AWESOME!!!
author: Kelly K.

description:
10.50 for a "super burrito".  it looked like a regular to me.  
this place is too expensive ! and the burrito is not tasty at all. 

i rather go to the other mexican joint that's on Washington street. this place is worth it.  its cheap and you get a real super burrito. 

never ever again will i go back to this horrible place.  they only  need to pull a gun at you to rob your wallet.
author: Liza B.

description:
I ordered breakfast burritos for the office from here. They were VERY YUMMY and cheap! The 15 burrito order was a bit delayed but whatever.

Can't wait to try more things from here! Looks pricey though =/
author: Jennie S.

description:
The premise is simple: serve delicious Mexican food using only fresh ingredients. Tlaloc pulls it off quite effortlessly. The lunch crowd can be intense, but the wait is not bad at all. It's definitely one of the best places to get a Mexican-food fix in the Financial District (but then again, anything is better than Rubio's.) 

They do have an extensive salsa bar, so fill up each plastic container and dip your chips in a delicious salsa bath. 

I will say that most of the prices are listed as "AQ" or "As Quoted." I know that it is meant to be based off the the seasonal prices as they buy only fresh ingredients, but I really don't know what the difference is from one day to the next. So price is really something I cannot comment on, in all actuality.
author: Bryan B.

description:
Alright, listen up fidi-foodies, this place is a mos-def must try!

Coming here on a random day I was craving for Mexican Food, I ordered a crispy fish taco and a crispy chicken taco. Total price for my meal was about $12.00 but they give you chips and salsa. Friendly atmosphere, the first time I got lost and had to call the girl for some directions due to the fact that I realized I had walked in a circle. 

But nonetheless, I was in love with my tacos and devoured them, within 30 minutes. I usually don't get tacos because I'm more of a nacho person, but this place made me think twice about tacos. 

I would order the crispy chicken taco again. As for the fish taco, it was good, but a bit greasy. I usually get the cucumber salsa, it's spicy but really tasty. The taste of the salsa is unique and all the flavors complement each other nicely. 

Overall, I would come here again and I would order another crispy chicken taco. It's in a hidden area so I suggest google it. 

Tips: -Don't go when it's rush hour, line goes all the way to the street. you would have to wait to order and wait for the food, and if you're hungry that's not a good combo.
- Order by phone and just pick up within 10-15 minutes. 

happy eating! :)
author: Liberty C.

description:
Burritos=good
Salads=great
chips=decent
the chairs they use (inside and outside)=suicidal.  They have these annoying rubber guards on the tops of the chairs, which cause people to get their pockets, bags, etc stuck on the chairs.  its pretty freaking annoying.  the ones outside are a little better, but not much.  feels like youre sitting on sharp metal (oh wait, you are).
author: Timothy S.

description:
OK, so I've been here 3-5 times now and I almost always get the same thing-the whole wheat healthy chicken burrito! It's so delicious, yet pretty basic and semi-healthy, but I don't see it being that nutritional because it's so large!  

The #1 reason I love Tlaloc so much is solely because of their salsa bar.  The mango salsa and the avocado salsa choices are beyond amazing! I don't even know how to describe them. PURE HEAVEN! I can't use the tiny ramekins you're supposed to use for them.  I always use the water cups; I could drink their salsa on a regular basis. It's THAT good.  The only thing I can't get over is how EXPENSIVE this place is.  Somehow, I always spend over $10! That's an expensive lunch, hence why I don't come here that often.
author: Jenny W.

description:
3.5 stars!

I knew I could expect a certain level of deliciousness from Tlaloc because I'm a frequenter to its east bay sister Cancun.

What's great about both Tlaloc and Cancun you ask? Two words. Salsa. Bar. I love the mango salsa and the cucumber salsa.  The infierno salsa strikes fear into my stomach but if you're brave enough you'll be sure to get hooked!

The plan was to meet up with Kat C. for some lunch and since we knew we were coming to Tlaloc she phone ordered ahead for expediency since the lunch time rush can be crazy.  I decided to go for the Pollo Adobado Burrito (grilled chicken breast with black beans, rice, salsa fresca, and queso fresco) in a wheat tortilla.  Every order comes with chips too!  The burrito itself was delicious - the chicken was moist and flavorful.  

Tlaloc is a bit on the pricey side but it's a nice treat every once and awhile.
author: Kim-van T.

description: We decided to try out Tlaloc for catering an office lunch. $8/person for the Taco Bar if you do pick-up instead of delivery, so about $180 (after tax) for 20 people. Taco Bar comes with your choice of meat(s), corn and/or flour tortillas, tortilla chips, and a variety of taco fillings - beans, Spanish rice, peppers, cilantro, guacamole, shredded cheese, and salsa. They give approximately 3 tortillas per person. I think they just filled up each serving tray until full, because we ended up feeding about 25 people and still had leftovers. The chicken is cubed and has a barbequed/grilled flavor, and the carnitas are very tender and juicy. As for the salsas, we stocked up on the mango salsa because it is just too delicious - the perfect combination of sweet and tangy.
author: Shar M.

description:
I walked here the other day with a friend. She ordered a chicken quesadilla and swore it was good. 

I went here yesterday to try this "good" food. I ordered a carne asada super burrito. I think that it was just "A-OK". The ingredients were fresh and the meat was nice and tender, not chewy which is MAS IMPORTANTE. 

I think it would have been much better if I had a bottle of Tapatio sauce. 

The chips are good, not too oily or salty. 

I want to go back and try the crispy taco which I've been told are similar to a chulupa.
author: J-nine I.

description: I don't think I've ever had a chorizo breakfast this scrumptious.  And the Salsa bar was up and running by 8am.  The rest of the menu looked tempting too - I'll have to come back and visit the seafood selections.
author: seth g.

description:
Rounding up to 4 stars, but barely (the mango salsa and pumpkin salsa did the trick and got you extra credit, Tlaloc).

No, can't do that on second thought. 3.5 stars, the prices are a bit too high so I cannot give them 4 stars.

Menu options are vast. Huge fan of the wide selection. The grilled chicken and vegetable burrito in the wheat tortilla is my favorite. But the fish taco, no cheese, soft shell, is excellent as well. Good job with the tilapia, guys. 

The breakfast burritos are solid as well, although I would advise against this many carbs at 8am.

My gripes: (1) the corn quesadillas could be SO much better than they are, what a disappointment. Too greasy. (2) the nachos are OK (but I am spoiled by the fantastic nachos at Sancho's in downtown Palo Alto). (3) Sometimes service can be very very slow. 

But overall, the combination of many good burrito options and the great salsas make this place a solid 3.5 stars even if the prices are a bit too high for what you get.
author: Ravi A.

description: Went here for lunch today and was pretty happy with the results.  There is always a line out the door at this place and now I know why.  It's a bustling kitchen area you see as you walk in with all sorts of meats, sea food, fish, and veggies being prepared to order.  Once you make a selection - and there is plenty to choose from here - you order.  I chose the Crispy Prawns Tacos (2) loaded.  Each taco is around $5, and you will need to order at least two for a meal.  They are worth the cost.  They fry the corn taco shell like I have never experienced before with a generous scope of prawns that were cooked to perfection.  Add in the sour cream, guacamole and salsa and these babies are good to go.  You can also chose from a wide variety of home made salsas, and when I say homemade - these look to be someone's secret recipes...everything from mild to XXHot - didn't get to that one, but the garlic mild has a nice kick to it.  I also tried the Guacamole salsa, which looked like a puree version - but very light and a nice contrast to the Garlic mild.  Each order comes with house made tortilla chips - these are great.  The fountain was down a couple of choices, but I made due with a nice root beer - free refills!  Seating is on several locations and the waiters do their best to find you either inside or outside as quickly as possible.  i don't envy these guys and gals that have to figure out where you picked to sit.  Highly recommend if you like the authentic Mexican with a modern spin twist on some of the entree items.  A little pricey for lunch $15 for 2 tacos/chips/soda, but it's worth it.  You will be happy you stood in the line and waited.
author: Steve A.

description:
Pros: outdoor seating, great on sunny days! polite staff, AMAZING mango salsa, great veggie and chicken burritos, and fresh fish tacos. 

Cons: on the expensive side. The shrimp ceviche is so spicy it's overpowering (this coming from a girl that loves her some spicy).. you cant taste anything else but the chili. Toooo much, friends. We need to tone that down! Also, their happy hour ends at like 4pm or some crazy ish like that. I thought most people get off work at  5-5:30? :(

I come here and will keep coming here on beautiful days and/or when it's time to reward myself =)
author: Tejal D.

description:
My office colleagues raved about this place so I anticipated it being spectacular but was in for a huge dissappointment. 
I had the chorizo burrito which was small compared to most burritos. Aside from that it had an odd lemony taste to it...not sure if it was the salsa in it.  About an hour after eating it, I had an awful stomach ache (which seldom happens to me). The only good things were that the staff are extremely friendly and the restaurant is super clean. I'll stick to my mama's chorizo from now on!
author: Ann T.

description:
Oh snap. For a self order taqueria this place is crazy expensive. I came here last friday with my coworkers and we got severe sticker shock. I ordered the daily special which was mini al pastor tacos with salsa and white beans. Being a fan of al pastor how could I pass this up. It was the friday before memorial day so I had to get a beer to with my meal. When i got to the counter, the lady to told me it was $18 dollars. WTF. The daily special was $11 and the beer was $6 and tax. It was a nice day so we sat out side and ate our food. The min tacos were delicious and the beer was refreshing. 

My friend ordered carnitas nachos and they were thoroughly disappointing. The carintas was tender but had zero flavor. I tried a few pieces and every time I was expecting the delicious sally flavor. But nope, I was let down every time.
author: Jeff P.

description:
A friend called me during my lunch break and I told her I was eating the Best Veg Burrito ever.  I lied.   But I really don't think I lied on purpose.  It was just that my *I Need Spicy Food Now* hour had come and gone, yet unsatisfied. And at the very minute I was talking to her, I was only three bites in.  Starvin marvin... hot salsa splatters everywhere from my frantic bites.

Ok, it tasted fine, tasted fresh, wasn't all Rice/Beans.   But somehow, someway, I ended up unsatisfied - and for $9+ I wanted to be blown away.    Veg burrito (spinach tortilla, nice touch) -$ 8.50, really 9.31 after tax.  Who-hoo.  I hate paying up for mexican.  

Salsa Bar:  Good variety... I tried three of them.  The hottest, maybe called Inferno XXX or something similar, actually WAS SuperHot (and I have a high tolerance.)  But, sadly, it had no flavor other than Hot.  Pass.  The other two I tried were ok.

There are three floors (and I think a salsa bar on each,) plus seating in the alley.  My salsa splatters are on my office walls, so can't comment further on *eating-in-ambience*

I was there around 1.30 and the place was busy, a bit chaotic.

Truth be told, not sure what came over me today as I never order a burrito, much less a veg burrito.  I'm strictly a carnivore / taco or fajitas  gal.  So I'll probably try it again, have the $5.45 crispy carnitas taco and see how it goes.
author: Meg W.

description:
I can only review the veggie super burrito. Don't know what any of their meat tastes like. Burrito's are sort of my thing... but I think just about all of them in the City are crap. Seriously, crap.

But my veg burrito at tlaloc was good. Good guac, and not too much of it (I don't like feeling like I'm eating a slime burrito). I mean, I guess it would be really hard to mess up a vegetarian burrito, but it won me over. I left stuffed and happy.

What are the other options in this area? El Faro? Yea, if I can avoid feeling like all of my organs are trying to escape through my anus, I will. Mission accomplished at Tlaloc.
author: jared c.

description:
Going to the FIDI is like going to another country for me - I have no idea what to do or where I am going.  So, when I was going to meet a friend for lunch there, I just randomly picked a place that had a bunch of reviews from people that I knew.

If the day had been less cold and blustery, we would have sat outside (food always tastes better outside!), but as it was the people shivering over their huge salads from Mixt Greens did not look very comfortable.  Tlaloc has 2 upstairs seating areas, and the one at the top is nice because it's sunny and quiet, so you really feel like you have gotten away from the asphalt jungle.

I had the crispy fish taco, which I thought was a tiny portion for the money, although it tasted pretty good.  We also had some guacamole and chips, and a watermelon agua fresca.  It was all ok, but nothing I would find myself craving.  The salsa bar was a nice touch.

I would come back to try one of their breakfast items, but for now I am at a loss for a good lunch spot in the great unknown of the FIDI.
author: Liz S.

description:
Carnitas burrito is deliciously savory without feeling overly laden with lard. And the burrito is smaller than my head, which makes it edibly finishable without feeling laden with burrito.

Salsa bar is big, but "hot" is kind of an overstatement. When getting the salsa, go up a notch.

Outdoor lunch seating is great, minus the plentiful pigeons.
author: Rob T.

description:
Tlaloc is possibly my favorite Mexican restaurant in the city. They have the freshest tasting burritos, and the salsa bar is amazing. I wish they would sell their mango salsa in stores!

I highly recommend the carnitas burrito or the steak tostada - my two favorites!

Tlaloc is also perfect on a nice day because they have a ton of outside seating. However, don't shy away if it's cold because there are three floors of tables inside as well.

You may end up paying an extra dollar or so but it is definitely worth it for fresher, healthier, better tasting food in a nice environment.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Shrimp Burrito and Shrimp Taco Salad bowl ALL THE WAY. BBq'd sseasoned shrimp. YUM. And they have quite possibly the best salsa bar ever. Variety in salsas and actually legit on the descriptions.. so for you super spicy salsa lovers (like myself) the habanero salsa totally has a KICK!! Also love the avocado, mango, and cucumber salsas.

Totally a favorite lunch spot during a long day at work.
author: Shafaq C.

description:
Pretty impressed with this place. 

This restaurant is tucked away in a small side street which they close off for lunch to provide outdoor seating for their customers. 

This is probably not your typical burrito place. The food is a bit expensive compared to the average prices of regular Mexican food, but they care about their ingredients. So, to get the organic items or free range chicken, you have to pay the premium, but this stuff is probably way better for your body anyways. So, the price didn't phase me. 

I really wanted to get the carne asada super burrito, but I decided to try something new because I always get that every place I go. After discussing with the cashier, I decided to get a Pollo Adobado Burrito with a garlic tortilla. I usually don't get chicken too, but hey, I was trying something different, so might as well go for the whole nine yards. 

The chicken was very moist, and it was marinaded in this red sauce which gave it a ton of flavor! The red sauce was a little spicy, but so delicious. The garlic tortilla was very flavorful as well. It complimented the burrito very well. I think my favorite part was the salsa bar! It was... AWESOME. So many different kinds!! There was a mango salsa, avocado salsa, pumpkin seed salsa, inferno salsa, and more. I tried the avocado salsa and a medium spicy salsa (I forgot the name). The medium spicy salsa was not my favorite. I didn't really like the smokey flavor, but to someone that likes that type of flavor, I bet they will love this salsa! The avocado one was so delish! It was kind of creamy, spicy, and had a kick of cilantro. That was my favorite out of the 2. I wanted to try each kind, but there was about 8 kinds, so I guess I will have to go back! The burrito also came with a side of chips which was nice. 

I am definitely a fan and will come back again. Perhaps on a sunny day to sit outside while eating this delicious food.
author: Ayaka S.

description:
Ok...so i've been eating here for about 4 years on and off. That should tell you that it'spretty good Mexican food. Not Taco Bellish nor Rubio's. More authentic but with a quicker service slant. The salsas are amazing from take the paint off your car hot to just right ( at least for me). The menu has lots of selections. I love the Mar y Tierra burrito. Get it with the carnitas for the 'Tierra part" the Mar part is shrimp.Very very well done my friends....If you eat outside the tables are a bit rickity and the pigeons periodically do some low alltitude fly  byes looking for a bit of shrimp or an errant tortilla chip that happens to fall on the ground, but other than that your sitting in a sun drenched gorgeous site amount the gentry.
3 stars because the soda machine (self served) is too close to the salsa bar and napkins and cutlery. Everyone is banging into each other. Which can be good on a warm summer's day.
author: Anthony P.

description:
I heard about Tlaloc for the delicious lunch that they serve,well so I heard.Well I also heard they serve breakfast also. Why on earth would anyone want to eat this in the morning...crazy me that is.

This place is colorful.What I like is that you can see them prepare your food.The place seemed clean and they also have seating upstairs too.

I decided on getting the Chorizo Con Huevos:scrambled eggs with
chorizo,homestyle potatoes,refried beans, warm tortillas and salsa.

My meal was prepared quick and decent tasting.I did suffer a bit because it was a little spicy for me in the morning,but overall I thought the prices were  fair,service nice and meal was tasteful. 

I think this place is worth the try regardless if you come here for breakfast or lunch.
author: Dani D.

description: Yum!! Went here for lunch with my coworkers and by 11:45 the line was already out the door. Luckily, the line goes by so fast! Once you place and pay for your order, you find a seat and your food is brought to you. I got the super burrito even though I'm usually more of a taco girl and it was sooo good. The salsa bar is amazing and adds the perfect touch. I'm definitely planning to go back to try their crispy tacos. One of my new favorite places.
author: Rachel N.

description:
This place is one of the best in San Francisco, 
Mexican food so delicious !!!!!
Thanks for the best Mexican food  prawns quesadilla, mmmm!!!
author: Hans G.

description:
Delicious and affordable Mexican food with super fancy salsa bar (I love the mango salsa!) and low carb options! The items on low carb menu are basically the same things on the regular menu with lettuce instead of tortilla.

Great for meeting friends for lunch in downtown or a quick pick-up when you have to eat lunch at your desk. The line gets a bit crazy during the lunch rush hour, so get there early.
author: Su K.

description: Dayum! Where the heck did this place come from??!! Went here for lunch on a work day and had a 'mariscada burrito' and a beer with a co-worker. We sat outside and it was a beautiful sunny day. The burrito was super unique, stuffed with fish, shrimp and grilled calamari, simmered in a tomato & garlic broth. The right amount of rice and beans was likewise wrapped in the garlic tortilla. Could have served a few more chips with the burrito, cause the salsas from the salsa bar were fantastic. garlic seemed to be a permeating theme to their cuisine, which wasnt a bad thing. Will def be back.
author: Adrian S.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE!

Great healthy selections, plus they have always accommodated any variations or special requests that I make.  The low carb chicken breast burrito with grilled vegetables is amazing.

The food is delicious and the service is fantastic.
author: Erika S.

description: It definitely feels less authentic than, say, la taqueria but the food here is really tasty and fresh if you don't mind that sort of "tex-mex" feel. I like the tables out front in the alley, and the fish tacos, though messy, never disappoint. This is one of those places you can actually order seafood and not feel sketched out. Prawn burrito is also a fav when i'm feeling super hungry. Horchata was just okay for me. I love my horchata.
author: Nikki M.

description:
This is how the story goes, got there at lunchtime, around noon. I've heard great things about this place...guess those people were smoking crack.

Stood in line & watched the burrito assembly line as we waited. $8 for a burrito (my thoughts "better be good"). Got a few cups of salsa on the first floor; big mistake! Carried the salsa all the way up to the third floor, luckily I didn't spill any, but I got close. Apparently they have salsa bars on EVERY floor, not just the first floor; good thing they had a sign...NOT!

As we sat at the table, we made some bets on who would get their food first. Let's just say, good thing I didn't bet on myself! Finally after the other two guys were almost done with their food, I finally got mine. It definitely was not anything exciting, for a small $8 burrito, I would have expected A LOT better.

On the bright side, the salsa was really good!

I'll probably be back some day due to coworker peer pressure...
author: Elaine S.

description:
Hmmm . . . reviews like this one are the most challenging for me.  I am torn as there are many factors why Tlaloc deserves a bad or mediocre review.  As you read on, you will understand my point.  

My coworkers and I decided to go on a hunt for Mexican food for lunch since Pancho Villa closed on the Embarcadero.  What a sad day that was!  We had to look for a second option . . . therefore; my coworker did a search on Yelp and found Tlaloc.  

We entered Tlaloc and it immediately gave me a sense of a Tex-Mex type of restaurant.  Think Chevy's but nicer.  You order first and if you are going to be sitting in the restaurant to eat, they will give you a number.  Tlaloc has three floors for seating, which is GREAT!  You find a seat and place your number on your table so the waiter/waitresses can bring your food.  Tlaloc's salsa bar isn't anything to rave about.  Their selection of salsa was the standard unlike most Tex-Mex influenced restaurants.  There was no fancy corn salsa or roasted tomato salsa.  *boo*  The food was simple and you get what you order.  I ordered a super burrito with carne asada.  From a 1-10 scale, I would rate the burrito as a 5.  So far from my review, I bet you would expect me to rate Tlaloc a 1 or 2 star rating on Yelp.  Well, this is why I'm torn.  

Tlaloc receives a mediocre review because:
1.  The service was fast (which is a huge factor during lunch hour in the FiDi*)
2.  The workers were very kind
3.  The restaurant was very clean
4.  The ingredients were fresh
5.  There isn't a good selection of Mexican restaurants in the area

I would definitely choose Pancho Villa among other taquerias over Tlaloc, but since I'm on an "island" in the FiDi, I don't have much of a choice.  Hence, they will receive a 3 star rating as the "lesser of two evils" Mexican restaurant in the FiDi.  


*Financial District
author: Manton R.

description: Burritos. Lee like. Lee want burrito. Lee go to Tlaloc. Burrito make lee happy. Lee come back anytime.
author: Lee L.

description:
Despite the just average regular burrito and the absolute failure of breakfast attempt #1, attempt #2 went much better. Good enough to warrant four stars.

Still don't understand why I get surcharged for egg whites (unless you are using more eggs), but that they offered them was great, especially when stuffed into a whole wheat tortilla with black beans and salsa. Size (not too big) and price (also not too big - $4) were just right.

It was a delicious start to the day.
author: Jason B.

description:
When I told my friend that I had lunch at Tlaloc yesterday, he gave me this puzzled look and asked "Why?"  You see, he loves Mexican food, and the company he works for (rhymes with Schmoracle) is located in the building right next to Tlaloc.  He said: "if it were any good, I'd eat here three times a week."  He doesn't.

As soon as you walk in, you learn that Tlaloc food is "natural" and "organic."  Yet, there's something unnatural and non-organic about its ordering process, prices, seating and service.  Let me elaborate.

First of all, we came in right around noon, and the line was literally out the door.  We grabbed a menu and began studying it.  The menu offerings looked pretty typical for a Mexican restaurant, the prices were not.  The cheapest burrito on the menu was $7.95.  Ouch.

There were three cash registers open, but the line was still moving slow.  One of the cashiers was working from a spot behind a pillar, and people had a hard time locating him.  He had to yell "next person in line!" a couple of times to get someone's attention.  After 5-7 minutes in line, I ordered my chicken super burrito and a small Diet Coke.  I was charged $11.68, including $2 for a small fountain drink.  Again, ouch.

The cashier gave me an order number stand to put on my table, since at Tlaloc they bring your food out to you.  I heard that Tlaloc is known for its salsa bar, so I knew I had to try at least a couple of varieties.  I grabbed two small salsa cups, my soda in a paper cup and the number stand; it was time to find a seat.  Actually, there were three of us at lunch, and my friend had already grabbed a table, so it was time to find him.

Tlaloc has three tiny seating areas, each on its own level.  It looks like balconies in a theater or tiers at a stadium.  The only difference is, the Tlaloc tiers are only accessible by walking up a steep, narrow staircase with obscure signs while tripping over people along the way.  The tables on the balconies are scarce, and the space between the tables - virtually non-existent.  At lunch we were talking about what a fire hazard this place must be.  I wonder what the fire marshal would say about that . . .  By the way, you know what they have on each seating level?  A salsa bar!  Do you think they could have put up a sign saying "tasty salsa available on each floor?"  At the very least, we wouldn't have had to carry 37 things up the stairs, like a gypsy at a train station!

Anyway, we sat down at a table and set our 3 number stands on the edge.  I got my chicken burrito first and one of my friends got his pork torta (sandwich) a minute later.  Our other friend, however, wasn't so lucky.  She had to wait at least 7 more minutes before someone finally showed up with her whole wheat, no rice burrito.  No apologies, nothing.  At least I made $1 at lunch: I bet one of my friends I'd get my food first.  Call it a hunch.

My burrito was very bland and tasteless.  I had to add a lot of salsa (which was very good, by the way) to make it marginally better.  The burrito was pretty small with just a little bit of chicken, rice and beans.  The tortilla was very thick and doughy.  NOT a good value.

In the city where good, inexpensive Mexican food is abundant, there is just no reason to go Tlaloc.  Its overpriced, mediocre food, coupled with confusing, frustrating customer experience, will not help them with repeat business.  I will not be back.

P.S.  The second star is for their salsa only, and nothing else.
author: Yan G.

description:
I just had the burrito with Pumpkin Seed Mole, Grilled Chicken, black beans, cheese, and rice on a spinach tortilla.  Put some of the medium garlic salsa on it.......   and it was fucking delicious

I don't remember how much it cost but I don't care.... totally worth whatever it was
author: kevin w.

description:
Tlaloc....  Ah yes - the Aztec god of rain, fire, and fertility.  We know that Tlaloc was worshipped by the Teotihuacan and Toltec civilizations of Mesoamerica, but did you know he is also creator of the mythical Pipian Mole Burrito?  (That's Mesoamerican for Pumpkin Mole.)
I read the first few sentences from their brochure and knew I had to go there: "Visit  our fresh salsa bar.  We've got avocado salsa and the cucumber salsa and don't forget the mango salsa... it's good shit."  Personally, I like the Infierno Salsa - it makes you see chicken-eating pigeons, it's that hot.  (That explains why the water is free, I guess.)  No, really.  Their salsa bar is very nice.  So are their burritos... and so is the bus boy/table mover.   You can sit outside or go upstairs...  There's like three floors... I know, because I went with the Michelin Man one time and we ate up there.  He spoke mesoamerican and tipped very well.  A big up to Tlaloc's joint.....  Sharyn liked it...  that's all I should have to say . . .
author: Kenny R.

description:
This place is really a 3 star place.  It has all the yummiest ingredients - meat, cheese, veggies, sour cream, guac, bread - however, they never taste as yummy as they could be when all put together.  

I've tried a quite a few of their things and they're ok.  I even tried the cactus burrito, it's ok but the cactus was just too weird textured or something for me so I ended up picking it out in the end.  Cactus flavored ice cream though is delicious (I don't think they have it here though ):  

Not bad if you want a burrito in the fin dist and annoyed of chipotle pouring too much salt on everything.  (the fin dist chipotles do that sometimes, not all the time, it's weird)
author: F K.

description:
Their burritos are pretty good although they could use more meat. I could always use more meat. And yes, their burritos are the perfect size - not too big, not too small, juuuust right. ;-) 

Not a big fan of avocados but I absolutely love their avocado salsa. Very refreshing indeedy!

I can't believe I've never eaten here before today - my office building is right beside this place!

PS - The automatic paper towel dispenser in the women's restroom is super stingy. It dispenses only about an inch and a half of paper towel at a time. You need to attack it! :P
author: Aim E.

description: Some of the best mexican food I've found in the Bay Area - comparable to what I've had in Austin and Phoenix! Amazing Fresca's and Mexican Coffee to drink. Amazing salsa. Lunch line moves quick. Carnitas are fantastic
author: D S.

description:
Ate here for lunch today... still full. Stuffed actually and its dinner time. Ugh. And all i had was the Carnitas Salad. 

Carnitas were dry and not very flavorful but abundant. I rate a New Mexican spot by the Carnitas so... 

They serve a big bowl of chips when you're seated and 2 nice salsa's (red and green), both medium spice which I love. But there are so many places with Great salsa in SF its still on the average in the scheme of things. Lunch prices were in the dinner range ($11-17 per plate). No lunch specials here.

Server was wonderful. But cant give it all more than 3 stars. Good but not great or excellent.
author: Adam X.

description: No debate about the best burrito in America can start without the inclusion of the Super Burrito from Tlaloc. I have spent my entire life in the Bay Area/Los Angeles/SanDiego and this burrito is no doubt about it, The Best and extremely consistent. The Chip Game they have here is off the charts...they have the most perfect chips, no joke. The salsa bar is by far the most impressive display of fresh vibrant  and flavorful salsas I have ever seen... and it gets recreated everyday. It's not just the burrito that is out of this world, it seems to be everything on the menu is top tier. The freshness and flavors of their meats and vegetables are unbelievable. The ambiance takes the whole experience to another level (literally, chose your vibe: outside, or one of the three dining levels. Awesome cool architecture with sweet aztec murals on the walls. Recommendation is to arrive around 11:50 or after 12:50 to avoid a long line and find prime seating, but even if you do get caught up in the lunch rush, the line moves quick and any wait is definitely worth it.
author: Stephen L.

description: This is what will happen when you visit Tlaloc. You'll read the menu and it'll sound really good, but then your realize you don't really want to spend $10 on a burrito. So then you look at your remaining options under $6 and you end up ordering a taco (because that's all there is under $6). And there's so much sour cream, guac, and meat drippings in it the whole thing falls apart after two bites. That's when you drown your sorrows in their amazing salsa bar, and you'll discover the legendary pineapple salsa.
author: Kathleen M.

description: Tasty and surprisingly authentic, given the organic vibe of the place. I thought the healthy would scare away the mexican flavor. I was wrong. Quite enjoyable. Beware of the lunchtime douche bags on cell phones blocking the salsa station. A good jab at a kidney gets them out of your way. ;)
author: Paul C.

description:
As the aztec name suggests, this is not your normal taqueria mexican fare.  Owned by the same people who own Cancun in Berkeley, they make a mean mole and have great fresh ingredients.  I enjoy their nopales chicken mole burrito most often.  They also always have a great selection of aguas frescas to choose from; sandia (watermelon for gringos like me) is my favorite.

I usually grab mine to go, but they offer three stories of seating, which sounds like a lot more than it really is, as the floors are all about the size of someone's studio apartment deck.  

What really sets this place apart though is the salsa bar, which offers a good 7 or 8 choices of salsa: everything from the sweet mango, to the spicy inferno (which is really hot, not taco bell "hot"). 

When I belly up to the salsa bar and try to determine which salsas I should choose, it is a complicated affair not unlike wine and food pairing.  What kind of salsa would go best with my tacos con pollo abodabo?  Would the mango salsa mask the flavor of the abodabo?  Would the avocado based salsa overwhelm the mole in my mole burrito?  And seafood?  Don't get me started on the mariscos.  

Que lastima!
author: James M.

description: A little expensive but not a bad option for a Mexican lunch. Their ingredients are fresh and they have a good selection besides the typical regular burrito/taco/quesadilla vs. super burrito/taco/quesadilla. A good selection of meats and salsas always makes these places more interesting. I am a big fan of the carne asada; it is sliced thin and not diced up into marginally larger burger meat. The texture there makes a huge difference and you feel like you're eating steak and not ground dirt. Lunch time is hectic here.
author: Ed L.

description:
Well... I readily admit that I like traditional burritos.  But these ones are really not good enough to warrant both the price and the small sizes. 

Yes, I may be comparing apples to oranges but I really only come here when I get outvoted.
author: Calvin N.

description:
Located on a nice LITTLE alley, chock full of other restaurants like 7 Pleasures, Gio's and Mixt Greens, this is the BEST spot to go to for a filling LUNCH. Tlaloc has good Mexican dishes for all appetites, herbivores and carnivores a like. Cannot pronounce the name of this place. And when trying to enlist the help of the counter person. Still butchered it!

Ended up ordering the plate of Mole soft tacos. Get two LARGE tacos with all the helpings. Well if all the helpings are some MEAT, tomatoes and other stuff. No cheese to spoil the tacos. Plate comes with some chips. Remember to take full advantage of the salsa BAR. One upstairs and downstairs. The avocado salsa is for the weak hearted. NOT spicy and one of my favorites. You can get a few salsa to go or dine in.

Once you place your order, head upstairs and await your food. Space has enough places to sit on a crowded lunch hour. Watch your DRESS pants! Seats are metal and can rip them with the greatest of ease. And not the most comfortable seats in the world.
author: Ryan G.

description: My original review was rather vague. First off, I love the new seating option. Probably one of the best places in FiDi just because there is so much seating. The food is awesome. Every dish I have had (and I have had quite a few) always pleases. The carnitas are my favorite. The salsa bars add a little fun and variety to any dish as well. I definitely love coming to this place for a quality Mexican meal.
author: Andrew M.

description: Overrated and overpriced. Don't bother.  Chipotle's better.
author: Jamaal C.

description:
Note- this review is for breakfast only.

I came here this morning for their breakfast burrito because I saw the menu on the street. The first thing I noticed was the lack of potatoes but the inclusion of beans. The second thing I noticed was the lack of cheese. Both of these are good qualities, as those are usually what makes a typical breakfast burrito much to greasy and heavy.

I had the nopales con huevos... the prickly pear cactus, eggs, beans and white corn salsa. I love nopales and to have them in a burrito this morning was so great. They substituted the refried beans that usually come with the burrito for black beans without any hastle, and everything came out quickly and fresh. The flavors went perfectly together without being overly greasy or drippy.

More than that, the salsa bar is AMAZING. The breakfast burrito came with a side of chips and I got something labled as "hot" that really wasn't (still tasty) and a mango salsa that was too mild but so flavorful and complimentary to my cactus burrito. Great, filling, and not too heavy feeling breakfast experience. I'll have to come back for lunch sometime and decide further on a review then, but for now it's 4 stars.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I should have known better.  I should have stayed the course.  I should have went with my gut and order what I normally order....but I didn't.  And now it's ruined.  RUINED, I TELL YOU!!

Have you ever had a huge disappointment while out dining?  You leave the establishment with steam coming of your ears, furiously thinking, "YELP WILL HEAR ABOUT THIS!!"  Well that's how I felt today when I left Tlaloc today  with my DISASTER of a crispy prawn taco.  

The taco looked as if someone cumpled it up like a peice of paper, threw it in a plastic container and dumped grease all over it.  Bad...bad bad.  But I still ate it.  Now I feel as though I took $6 and set it on fire.  I'm pissed because I WANTED to order something else, but the lady at the cashier INSISTED that I order the crispy taco....even though the crispy taco only comes with ONE whereas the soft tacos come with TWO.  

All is not lost here.  One bad taco can be forgiven I suppose.  I still wouldn't recommend getting it though.  I think this is the go-to place for Mexican food in the FiDi and probably as good as its gonna get around these parts.  I usually get a side of chicken and a side of rice (hefty side portions that end up feeding me for lunch AND dinner) and drench it in mango salsa.  Tlaloc's mango salsa is the only mild salsa I like.  The carne asada quesadilla is also pretty fabulous.  

Tlaloc's location is ideal on Commercial street and provides outside tables for both customers and passerbys.  Just be careful what you order.  Go big or go home.
author: Kerry D.

description:
Good, solid food, not unlike its sister restaurant in Berkeley.  Their chicken quesadillas are absolutely the best.  I don't know why we stray and try new things.  What a waste of stomach space!  The ceviche appetizer came out when we were halfway done with our meal.  With the starter dish coming out after the fact (second restaurant in a row), Roy and I are vowing not to order appetizers anymore!

Yay strawberry agua fresca!  I liked the outdoor seating on this beautiful day.  I believe Roy enjoyed the eye candy walking around.
author: Lynnie P.

description:
If you work in the Financial District and you crave Mexican food, you gotta come to Tlaloc! It's quality food, big servings, and at a pretty good price.

Don't be intimidated by the lines at lunch time... They move fast. Grab a menu from the cash register (the menu on the wall is kind of hard to read). And send a member of your party to scout out a table in the sunny alley way where all the outdoor seating is located.

Chow down hard, but don't forget to take time to mock all of blue shirt / khaki pants crowd milling about (one of the perks of being downtown at lunchtime).

Oh and definitely stock up on all the salsas (the mango one is standard fare here).
author: Trey F.

description:
The place I work gets lunch catered every Friday and every time they decide on Mexican and order from Tlaloc, they mess up the order.  They're pretty incompetent - I mean, I ordered fajitas but they didn't give me any tortillas.  

I've never really been impressed with the food and have gone only because it's there.  But I will probably never go here again.

**UPDATE** they called me back to tell me that "fajitas" is just the seasoning or how the dish is prepared and that I needed to have ordered the tortillas separately.  SMALL SUGGESTION - why don't you put that on the menu so people would know?  I've never been to a Mexican establishment that did NOT give me tortillas for my fajitas.
author: Claire C.

description:
It's January and I'm trying to do my body a bit of good so I ordered the ceviche thinking it would be a healthy option. Well, it definitely was healthy - 3 pieces of lettuce, 2 slices of tomato, and a mound of 'ceviche' which ended up being nothing more than diced mango, cucumber and possibly 2 shrimp (and I think that's actually a generous assumption). There were seriously no more than 10 super small chopped-up pieces to be found! And it was over $13 just for this (no drink)!
