The stars are for: their salsa bar and their service (the fact that they had no problem substituting corn tortillas for corn tostadas; the people bringing the food are very sweet).

***Keep in mind that this review is based only on what I ordered. I'm sure it's mainly because I should have just ordered a burrito or tacos. But note my friend got a burrito and drink and it still came to over $11.
author: Jen N.

description:
I love chorizo.   Yeah baby....you know what I'm talking about.

It's hot and meaty...mmm.  

Chorizo is the best meat I have come to know.  Nothing beats chorizo in the morning.  It gives me the pep in my step!!

Throw in a couple of eggs and you got a yummy morning start.
author: Jay H.

description:
BEST SALSA BAR EVER! 

I heard about this spot because of it's sister spot in Berkley that I used to go to WAY back in the day when I was visiting friends at Cal.

Keep this in mind, however: you are in the Financial District. The rent for this spot must be ridiculously high. So, expect to pay the price.

They have seating in the closed off alley or inside. Pick the alley. On a sunny day, you will get enough rays to keep you going the rest of the day!
author: John Eric S.

description:
When I was in junior high I went to Taqueria Cancun in Berkeley a lot.  This place is a lot like it. Probably because it's the same owners.

But Tlaloc has two good things going for it. (1.) the interior is like a sweet-ass loft you could live in, and (2.) the agua fresca is slammin'.

Seriously, the aguas frescas are insane. And unlike other taquerias, a large is LARGE. Like 7-11 large. And chunky. Full of fruit. It's rare you get so much value from your dolla dolla bills, especially in this neighborhood. (Well, you don't get as much value from the food as the juices, but I've found a little extra cheese makes everything at Tlaloc better.)

The food is fine, but can pale in comparison to the salsa bar, which is like a cornucopia of tastiness. I like to mix the mango salsa with the avocado salsa. I call it "Mexican Chutney."
author: Megan W.

description:
Breakfast burritos before 9:30 AM - $2.50 and includes a bag of chips.  I'm all over the huevos rancheros with light beans on a wheat or pesto wrap.

But the best part of this joint is the salsa bar.  I really like the avocado salsa, but the mango and the strawberry salsa come a very close second.  

I usually call ahead because its never faster than 10 minutes.

Remember, after 9:30 AM the prices go up.  Aye ca rumba!
author: Isaac L.

description: If you work downtown and are craving that lunch time burrito, look no further than Tlaloc.  They use all fresh ingredients and have multiple salsa options to change up your meal every time you go.   Their prices are a little above your normal mission burrito place but you are definitely paying for quality / fresh / organic ingredients. Their portions are definitely competitive and you won't leave hungry.  The only reason I dropped one star is I've had better burritos in different parts of the city, but for downtown purposes, there is no better.
author: Greg H.

description: I had bought the fish tacos earlier this afternoon and it was absolutely freakin' good!  I'm picky about my tacos and even though it was hurting in the pocket, I dove right in and ordered (2) prawns and (2) fish tacos.  It was worth the money!!!  Note:  Beware of the salsa...could be tempting, but unless you love hot salsa, even the mild one could be muy caliente.
author: O ..

description:
The burritos here actually aren't too bad.  But the prices aren't quite to my liking.  I guess you can't expect to get a cheapie burrito in this area, anyway.  As everyone's already mentioned, the salsa bar is a highlight.  There's a few floors of seating, though, they're all taken up with the wrath that is the FiDi lunch crowd.  You're forced to take it back to your desk or eat outside with the pigeons.  For breakfast, they offer a number of breakfast burritos.  

Aside from the traditional meat and veggie, the menu is varied, with specials, plates, a low-carb menu, and a lil something to satisfy the seafood lovers.  Don't fear the line out the door--it moves quickly.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Don't get the burrito, boring city.  

This is yet another case of if only I'd read the yelp reviews on this place first I could have saved myself from boring lunch type situations.  Upon return to my office, and before I ate said chicken burrito, I read the yelp chain on this one.  Note number one: do not get burritos, get the specials.  Sweeet.  I feel like a real dork now.  Who's the elite here? Not me....wahhhhh!  

I hate shitty burritos more than I hate shitty sex.  Cause I'm the only one in control of that boat you know what I'm sayin?
author: Claire C.

description:
I do enjoy Tlaloc, even if I can't pronounce the name correctly.   I had a plate of wonderful chicken enchiladas, black bean and rice.  I took some forkfuls of my dining mate's mushroom quesadilla, and it was also full of tasty goodness.  I rounded it off with a large horchata, and all was good with the world.

What is holding Tlaloc off from five stars is the crazy way of ordering and then finding a place to park yer butt and then hoping the server will find you before your food gets stone cold.

There has to be a better way.  Someone help them figure it out.
author: .Hon H.

description:
This is a good place for a quick lunch during the work week.  Because of it's close proximity to lots of offices if you listen closely you may hear insider trading secrets, privileged client info, who's boss is gay, how much people make at other firms, and how people exploit their expense accounts to the benefit of their mistresses.

The food is good.  The big menu is kinda hard to read.  Service can be kinda slow during the rush hour.  If the weather's nice you can eat it there in the alley.
author: Nikki c.

description:
So so good!! Fresh salsas, yummy burritos, fast service. A little on the pricey side to be going here on the regular but I do make it over there. 

Should we be lucky enough to get these ordered for work lunch, it's guaranteed everyone will be at lunch that day.
author: raychelle c.

description:
Crispy fish tacos! Probably the best fish tacos i've had. a little on the greasy side, actually its pretty greasy but once you bite into it, you forget all about it. Their burritos are really good too. I usually stick with the chicken burrito. A lot of my co-workers love this place too. Their selection of salsas are awesome! The hottest one is HOT! i mean HOT! and i love eating spicy stuff. the green one is the best even if its not spicy, i forget what the ingredients are. 

I'm willing to walk the four blocks to have lunch here to take it back to the office.
author: Bevo T.

description:
This just in...there's more to Mexican food than burritos!  In fact most people in Mexico assume you are talking about little donkeys, not the fast-food bastardization of their cuisine, when you ask where to find a good burrito.  Why does that American want a little donkey they wonder.  This is pondered until they come to the only logical solution - you are a pervert.

That being said, why is every review about Mexican food a discussion of burritos?  Yes Tlaloc (and Cancun in Berkeley) serves a pricey donkey, and probably not the best one at that.  So what?  

What Tlaloc does have is a very nice daily special,  usually featuring a regional or specialty fare that you don't get at Taco Hell or from a truck in a parking lot.  They have delicious Aguas Frescas: I go for the Horchata and Strawberry offerings.  They have a fresh salsa bar too. 

I love Tlaloc; I go all the time.  The specials range from Sopes (my favorite), to Birria (so good), to specialty tacos and much, much more.  I've never regretted ordering a special.  

If you want a burrito, go to a burrito shop.  If you want to try something that approaches authentic Mexican cuisine, have the daily special at Tlaloc.  It's not the best Mexican food you'll have in SF, but it is the best you'll have at lunch time in downtown SF.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Had a burrito. So delicious and meat cooked nicely.

Great salsa bar. Favorite part.
author: Simon W.

description:
Tlaloc is not a burrito joint.  See?  Tlaloc is not a burrito joint.  Please do not order a burrito there in order to compare it to other burrito joints.   Their burritos pretty much suck, and most people who eat there regularly  would not order one.   

Tlaloc is solid, primarily organic, and tasty.  Tlaloc excercises considerable creative licence with traditional dishes, and does not hesitate to concoct questionable specials like tiny sopes and tamales devoid of meat.  That same creativity makes Tlaloc a joy.  Tostada Costena, any of the meat plates (unlisted, but you can have Carne Asada, Chile Verde, and Chichen Mole on a plate for not much more than the price of a lame burrito), and the Torta particularly shine for me.    Order anything other than a burrito.   The sangria rocks and is composed of a ladle full of each of the aguas fresca, the remainder being box wine.
author: Jared L.

description: Ignored the bad reviews and decided to take a chance on Tlalc for lunch today. I ordered the pollo adobado burrito and it was delicious. Good flavor, tasty pollo, a And of course very filling. Food is yummy but 4 stars because $10 for a burrito is a bit high.
author: Savanah M.

description: If you go here get one of the specialty burritos, liek the seafood burrito that has shrip, fish, and squid; sooooo delicious.  Also their green vege burrito, or the red one with cactus in it:  they're very good and not something you can get at other burriot places
author: Michael E.

description: Mole poblana burrito was good, but a little flat. Did not taste the depth in the mole sauce. Good burrito, but not did not knock my sox off. Pasilla has more flavor and spice.
author: Gary W.

description:
I admit i come here for two reasons.. its right down stairs from my work, and the breakfast burrito... 
they make a simple chorizo and egg burrito, its not too over the top, its the perfect size, it fills you up with out leaving you with that feeling of "I ate wayyyyy to much and want to die"
Its delicious
they have an awesome salsa bar... when they say inferno they mean it... my mouth is currently suffering from a tasty five alarm fire at the moment... but its delicious damnit. 
oh and this place, for being in the middle of the financial is dirt cheap.. breakfast burrito under 4 bucks, breakfast plates under 6 bucks cant be beat.. 
the girl behind the counter is always super sweet too...
i have heard they have good sangria too, maybe ill have to come check this place out for lunch and follow up this review...


to be continued. . .
author: jamie z.

description:
Things I love about Tlaloc:

Fresh salsa
Pineapple Agua Fresca, complete with mini pineapple chunks
Catcus burritos 
Salsa
Mayan-esque painting on the walls
Three floors of seating
Friendly and helpful staff
Salsa
Pozole
Good music at lunch in the fidi
Trying to pronounce Tlaloc, Tlaloc, Tlaloc
and umm salsa...

Things I don't  really like about Tlaloc:
Food could be taken up a notch
Walking down blustery commercial alley.
author: Rhiana M.

description:
Yah, just an A-OK plus a .5 star. The lunch hour rush was ridiculous and super unaccommodating. Upon entering, you must know which line to hop in and what exactly you want. it's quick and very impersonal. I feel really bad for the waiting staff too. They have to run up and down these shitty stairs just to figure out where you're seating to serve you. I gave my guy a tip.

Anyway, they screwed up my very simple order (adobada not the special!) and it took days to make that order. My food was pretty good, tasty but way too pricey for lunch. I'd come back again a little early and a little more prepared for the price. 

It's sister restaurant, Cancun in Berkeley has hotter salsas and quicker service. If you're in the east bay, visit this place first.
author: katie k.

description:
My sister moved to a new area for work so I was sad that we couldn't meet up at our usual spot B44 on the other side of town.  Instead she told me about her favorite taqueria on Clay street.

I'm supposed to eat light because I'm a bridesmaid this upcoming Friday (lucky 8/8/08) and my butt totally decided that a burrito would be healthy.  My sister and my mom however ordered two delicious dishes called a Tostado Costena and my mom ordered something like that but with not as much seafood, I think it was prawns tostado or something.  I think I picked off their plate more so than my grilled tilapia fish burrito!

Actually thats a lie because I ate 3/4's of my humungus burrito and also drank one of their strawberry drinks with sliced floating strawberries at the top!  Very yummy to munch on while you are sippin your drink!  Reminded me of boba balls but real strawberries.

Oh back to the burrito..well if you have ever had a Chipotle burrito think of their burritos, but longer and not so thick.

Also, if you don't want to stand in any lines during the week make sure you get there about 11:50am before all the business workers come rushing out of their offices.  I love going to the city and seeing all the people in their work clothes at their lunch time.  Makes me envious to graduate already!

(well not really!)
author: Alyssa N.

description:
I went here with a friend on Friday for lunch and I was pleasantly surprised. I usually stay in inner Richmond because it's close and the lines aren't to long, but sometimes you just gotta get out. There was a pretty long line here, however it moved fast and no one was rude. Ordering process was straightforward, however when I asked for a cup for water the woman behind the cashier gave me some sass telling me that the cups were next to the water jugs. But whatever, they were busy. I ordered the fish burrito, pretty standard burrito with tilapia. Our two burritos ended up being just over $20. I'm used to cheap burrito places where the portions are a lot larger but the food was super fresh, and I'm a tiny person so the portion was perfect. We found a table on the third floor which was perfect because it was quieter and no one bothered us during our 2+ hour meal. I was surprised at how fast our food got to our table, considering the line spanning 20+ people outside the door when we got there. the food was great, salsa bar was great and the water pitcher was always full. 

I definitely recommend this place to someone who likes Mexican and works downtown. 

The only cons are the many, many stairs which are in a pretty tiny staircase and the long line
author: Laura F.

description: I think this place has decided that because it's so popular during the lunch rush, it can cut corners on the food.  The "super burrito" now contains trace amounts of guacamole and cheese, and is about the size of a small, regular burrito you'd find elsewhere.  They give you a baggie of about 5 chips with your to-go order.  C'mon.
author: Jen R.

description:
actually 3.5 stars, but you know anything over .5 round up.  got the grilled vegetable burrito with wheat rather than spinach tortilla....i have to say it's pretty tasty and fresh.  i was a little surprise, not sure why...maybe because i was skeptical that there could be good mexican in the fi-di.

they have good array of salsa with lots of flavor.  good place for lunch, but come early as it gets crowded!
author: Mao K.

description:
I am El Great Burrito King II . If you don't believe me, you can take me up on it some other time. As El King I give this place my Super Rico!(tm) award given for top notch flavors. I also give Tlaloc my Muy Grande(tm) for doing a good job filling my tummy. And lastly, I give them my Ay yi yi thanks for good service. 

If you would like to know more about my legacy or that of my predecessor El Great Burrito King I a.ka. Pizza Giorgio IV, Teriyaki Numeraki and Fillmore Fats who recently passed due to bad oysters he ate while training to be Mister World Oyster XI feel free to contact me.
author: Lee M.

description:
A little pricy,  but you're paying for fresh ingredients and not your run of the mill burrito fare.  Interesting salsas....fruit salsas....roasted tomato salsa.  Not just hot/mild/red/green.

Try the mole! (and i don't mean the guac-kind)

yum!
author: Pete D.

description:
This is a great place to grab lunch to-go during the work week.  I love the salsa bar, specifically the spicy chopped cucumber salsa and the chipotle mango salsa.  

Anything with the grilled fish and prawns is delicious!  They are generous with the seafood, serving huge chunks of it in burritos, quesadillas, salads, etc.  I love the slightly charred but juicy texture.  I also like subbing the burrito or quesadilla wrap with the spinach wraps to feel a bit healthier.
author: Jen Y.

description: I've wondered for a while about this place with a long line coming out the door.  Now I know - it's not worth the wait.  I had the mole soft taco - not terrible but definitly not worth $4.75 each and a wait.
author: B. Y.

description: Awesome place for Mexican food in the financial district. It's conveniently located right around the corner of my office building on Commercial St (think alleyway) with lots of outdoor seating. The line was super long but it goes by quickly. In fact, the menu is exhaustive that you can take advantage of the time in line to decide on your order. I really enjoyed my fish burrito (grilled red snapper adobado served with black beans and rice) with a side of chips and salsa. Tlaloc also offers your choice of tortilla: tomato, spinach or whole wheat and there's a wonderful selection of seafood and vegetarian dishes.
author: Helen Y.

description:
um... so i literally just got back to the office and have the uncontrollable urge to clarify to the chefs at tlaloc what is (or more importantly is NOT) a quesadilla. 

a quesadilla IS:
warm,
melty, 
soft (maybe a bit crisp on the edge but never in its entirety) 
served flat (either folded over or with two toritllas if you are feeling generous)
and most importantly, FILLED WITH CHEESE.

a quesadilla is NOT:
crunchy (aka totally deep fried)
cold
served as an over-stuffed taco
so full of other items that you can hardly find any cheese to speak of.

in short, i ordered (and paid $6) for a corn quesadilla and recieved a very expensive, very cold and damp, fried taco.

reflecting back on it now i am actually surprised i didn't send it back immediately... too hungry i suppose. with so many other mediocre and overpriced options on every corner of the financial district, i see no reason to favor this particular locale.

good day.
author: Lisa M.

description: Fabulous place for lunch, with great low-carb options. A little on the pricier side for a mexican lunch place, but the quality is there to justify the price tag.
author: Paul H.

description:
I like how the wax paper around the fried tacos turn super see through from all that grease.  Nonetheless, their fish tacos are pretty great, especially topped with the assortment of salsas.  Bonus, it's buffet style!  So grab a tupperware and start ladeling some for take home!  Spicy watery gaucamole and mango salsa are my favs.

Not too fond of their dining room set up... you have to climb 3 flights of stairs just to find an open table.  Do you think people who enjoy greasy tacos and fatty burritos can take such strain?  But in the warmer days, eating in the outdoor street court is the best.  Not the cheapest mexican place around, but for quality it's your best option in the Financial District.
author: Chris T.

description:
Why am I still undecided about this place? The food is good, and different, which is a plus. I think it's cool that they use different ingredients in their burritos, and that some tortillas are brightly colored (like the interior of the place), but I can't help but think that they don't taste too different from a burrito I can get anywhere else. 

But then they have the Mole Poblano burrito, which is wrapped in a bright orange tomato tortilla, dripping with mole sauce, which I think tastes close to superb. And their mango salsa is good too. So what's stopping me from giving this place another star? Who knows, but I'll keep coming here to find out. I highly recommend their specials, especially the Mole Poblano.
author: LM M.

description:
Very impressed--Tlaloc makes mean burrito!  I tried them for the first time today, and their chicken adobado burrito is great.  It was super flavorful and filled with fresh ingredients.  The restaurant was pretty cool too:  spacious and hustlin' and bustlin' with FiDi folk, and all to the beat of lively Latin music.

Ooh, I indulged in some horchata as well, and it was tasty and at just the right consistency.  Add a beautiful day and an outdoor table to the equation, and your lunch hour is pretty close to perfect.  Looking forward to coming back for more.
author: Andrea U.

description:
OMG I am in LOVE with their shrimp quesadillas. Super cheesy with pico de gallo and wrapped in a spinach tortilla. Also comes with chips. I eat it with the their mango salsa.
I like the idea of the kichen/ordering area is on the 1st floor and then there are 2 floors above for seating so you don't have a billion people around you while you're eating.
author: Britney C.

description:
I tried this place a long time ago and wasn't all that impressed so I never bothered with a review. I think I had gotten a Nopales burrito or something. Whatever it was, it obviously didn't make a solid impression.

Came here recently and got a grilled beef burrito off of their "healthy section" expecting another not-so-great experience. WOW it was good. It was basically beef fajitas wrapped in a whole wheat tortilla. Grilled beef and sauteed peppers. So basic, but perfect for my appetite and taste buds. The avocado salsa went really well with this.

Prices could be a bit cheaper
author: Sarah P.

description:
The food is good -- not stellar, but good. The fact that all their menu items don't have prices, though, and are marked "AQ" (market price) is obnoxious. Only seafood prices fluctuate enough to warrant that.

There's better Mexican food to be had in the Mission at a much lower price.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description:
The search continues for a great burrito in the city.

This is a little mushy small burrito at a somewhat exorbitant value proposition.

I'll eat here cause I love mexican and convenience, but I'm not happy about it.
author: jeremy S.

description:
Fantastic mexican/mayan food.  Any place that offers the option of spinach or tomato tortillas fits the category of  "mexican belonging in the Financial district and isn't on wheels".

The menu is huge and they're flexible.  If the weather is yucky, take it to-go cause there's no indoor seating.
author: Ariana N.

description:
Wow. My new favorite lunch spot! 

Got drawn to the tables and chairs spilling out in the sunshine on a closed street. And good thing too! This is the only place I know where if they say 'x-hot', you better really believe them. I take ALOT of spice and that thing still stung (although left me hankering for more). 

Everything I tried today just tasted awesome. I drowned everything in the x-hot sauce and guacamole (super refreshing). Even the chips were just somehow different from all the other places I've had them at. Yum. =)~

I had a crispy taco and the taco was nothing like I've ever had- I love how crispy and tasty it was! Definitely not just the usual fried dough. It also came spilling with carne asada and guacamole and all that good stuff. I nibbled off my lunchmates' salad bowl and the grilled pork and steak... oh so tender and flavorful! Even the crispy bowl was soooo good! It tasted like it was made of potato... dont know, dont care. Double yum. =)~

If I had one gripe though, it would be that the carne asada in my taco wasnt like the carne asada that was topped on my lunchmate's salad. Mine looked ordinarily grilled, but his was just gleaming in fancy juices... maybe cos he paid more?

Coming back for sure!!
author: Gobbledygook C.

description:
If you're looking an authentic tacos, this is not the place.  But if you're not looking for that, this place is decent.

I ordered a prawns soft taco and a carne asada soft taco.  These things were huge!!!  I ate these 4 hours ago, and I'm STILL stuffed.

The prawns one was really good.  They don't skim on the amount of prawns.  There was one in every bite.

Their salsa selection is great.  The garlic one was good.  They also offer a cucumber salsa.  That one is refreshing, with a kick.

Be warned that this place is small.  There's barely any tables for indoor seating.  If you don't mind sitting outside in the alley, there's plenty of tables there.... just be careful and watch out for all the pigeons, they're pretty ruthless, and will land right on your table until you physically push them off!
author: Maggie L.

description:
I work close to this place, but only been here a hand full of times, the other times I go because my colleague from work are going.  

Go ahead and skip this place, if you want good mexican food wait till you go home to your neighborhood mexican place.

This place gets good ratings because the fin district doesn't have many choices and the people are hungry so they will eat anything.

If you rank this 5 stars then you obviously don't know mexican food, I tried ordering different things but every time I'm so very dissappointed.  Poor servings, high price.
author: P H.

description: I really enjoy their fresh salsas!  Plenty of variety that complements the many dishes that they serve.  I think the mole is one of better ones around.  A nice blend of spices, not too much chocolate, that works well.  The place itself is large and has nice feel to it.  I think it's a great place for fresh, clean Mexican!
author: Dan S.

description: Prawn quesadilla is to die for! Love the lofty seating area inside and out -- and the open hours! However, the day's soup was not very exciting... Try again next time?
author: Angie C.

description: I eat here quite a bit because it's very close to my office.  I've only ever had the vegetarian super burrito there and I like it a lot.  Some of the other reviewers have complained about portion size and it's absolutely true that you're gonna be paying more than you would for a mission burrito for a lot less food but ask yourself whether you really need a fifteen hundred calorie burrito for lunch when you've been sitting behind a desk all day.  The line can be very, very long there so I tend to go either early or late.  The staff is very friendly.  The burritos there are good but I especially like the salsas they make which tend to differ day by day.
author: Joseph C.

description:
Their menu looks more interesting than it actually is.  I've tried the various Mole burritos, and I just don't think they're that good.  I'd rather go to Chipotle, or something half the price in the Mission.  The salsa bar provides interesting options (beyond mild/medium/hot, they have an avocado salsa, a cucumber salsa, etc), but I don't give extra stars for condiments, when the main meal is vastly overrated.

This quality of the food probably deserves three starts, but I'm subtracting a point for a) price, and more  than that, the indescribably annoying "A.Q." that resides to the right of every item on the menu.  What does this stand for?  "Ask Question?"  "As Quoted?"  Are prices being adjusted based on the current market value of the tortilla?  This discourages me from trying anything new on the menu, for fear that the going rate might be $23 for a Shrimp Mole Burrito.

Mixt Greens is in the same alley, and clearly displays a set price, no matter the seasonality or wholesale price on Arugula.
author: Joe K.

description:
I love this place and eat here at least once a week. It is always packed at lunchtime, but the service is really quick and I can always find a seat inside. I'm not a burrito guy, so I usually get the daily special, which could be chicken enchiladas with molle sauce, tamales, sopas, or some other dish. Always good. The tamales are best, and I wish they had them more often. So tasty! When the special doesn't rock my boat, I go for the carnitas plate. Some of the best I've ever had.

Can be a little pricy for the special, and I expect the burritos are a lot less. Special is usually 12 bucks. Add a drink and you're up to 15. A bit much for lunch, but OK for a once a week treat.

The cashiers are super cute.

One suggestion, and I've heard other people complain about them too: Cut off the little tabs on the top of the chairs. They are covered with rubber (presumably to keep people from impaling themselves) and if you brush up against them they catch on your clothes. In the tight quarters it means you are constantly bumping into them. If no one is sitting in the chair you tend to drag the chair in the direction you are walking. If someone is sitting in the chair you'll get a dirty look. REALLY annoying. Get some guy with a grinder to cut them off and smooth off the edges. Everyone will be happier!
author: Luke E.

description:
This is really 3.5 stars...it's not just A-OK and I'm not a huge fan...
What I like - the salsa bar IS really nice - the mild salsas are still spicey but the Mango is delicious. The burritos are pretty good - nothing to complain about. I had the Mole Prawns  and the Mole was delicious. 

However...the burrito's size can NOT compare to the amount of food you get at the nearby Orale Orale...and the price is more than other nearby burrito places also. Yes, you can sit outside...but Orale Orale is right by a bunch of outside seating at Embarcadero 4.
Their Vegetarian burrito still put me back 9 dollars (as much as the meat burritos?!) but it was tasty...just not the best I've ever had.

Considering the amount of people just LOVE these pricey morsels...I'll probably go back, but I won't be the one to suggest it.
author: Katy A.

description: I really dig this place.  Every time I've been, I have thoroughly enjoyed my food (which is more than I can say for other Mexican restaurants in the FiDi), and their grilled chicken and veggie burrito is DELICIOUS.  I would have given it another star if a coworker, on my recommendation, hadn't gone their for lunch and found a hair at the bottom of his burrito.  Not good.  Not good at all.  But even he admitted that he will probably go back because it was the best burrito he'd had in a while.  Aside from the hair, of course.
author: Jessica H.

description: I usually go to Chipotle but found this place to be very good and much more authentic than Chipotle.  The diffferent types of fruit juices are a huge plus and the tortilla chips are great.  I still go to Chipote more but i recommend this to anyone who wants something different than Chipotle.
author: Alex C.

description:
I guess I don't really need to add a review here since there are so many positive ones already.  So maybe something quick.  Relatively quick service.  Tasty guacamole.  Love love the chips that come with the order and the salsa bar.  I usually get the avocado salsa, but when they have the strawberry salsa I try to get some of that too.

It took me a while to figure out what I liked from there.  Trial and error.  I ordered the nachos because I like nachos but there's just so much junk in there and it's so huge.  So instead, I just get the crispy chicken taco and the size of it is perfect.  Almost half the price of the nachos but definitely filling enough and none of the extra stuff I don't even want.  I just scoop up the contents with the free chips and enjoy (because the juices from the salsa and/or the chicken make the shell too soggy to hold and eat as a taco anyway).  Muy delicioso!  Pretend nachos are much more fun to eat than a single taco anyway.  And oh, the strawberry agua fresca!  Awesome!
author: spiff e.

description: Very good food! Best Mexican in the financial district! I recomment the Crispy fish tacos and a side of the  cucumber salsa.
author: jen b.

description: Super overpriced Americanized Mexican Food.  I don't know, I feel like they do too much with their burritos, but the salsa bar is good.  I lived in Oaxaca for a bit, so I'm picky when it comes to mole - but they do an ok job.
author: Rayna A.

description:
I'm a little embarrased by how much I love their breakfast burritos. I never go for lunch, and I never order anything other than the same thing over and over and over and over again. 

Rancho Huevos burrito, with two plastic containers of their cucumber/lime/tomato salsa, and one of their green salsa. $3. Happy girl. 

It's soft, a little crunchy, with that citrus hot taste of the salsa. The best breakfast downtown for under $10.
author: Misha M.

description:
Two words for you when it comes to this place:

Mango Salsa!!!

I have to be honest, I have never ordered a dish from this place. I usually brown bag my lunch to work. But my co-workers always eat here and they love this place. If you work downtown and are craving good mexican food, Tlaloc seems to be the place to be.

My co-workers always bring me back a stash of the fresh mango salsa with an extra bag of chips. It has thick, fresh chunks of mango with a lot of kick and spice. I haven't had mango salsa anywhere like I have had it here.

If you do decide to hit this place up for lunch, I suggest you call in your order ahead of time so you can bypass the long ass wait. Phoning ahead allows you to just pay for your order, pick up your food and go. Trust me, I have had to pick up food from here several times for my co-workers.
author: Kathleen N.

description: Their burritos are yummy! Yeah it's a bit pricier than other taquerias but that's already expected with its location in the FiDi. I absolutely love how they have sooooo many different salsas to choose from and their fire salsa one is actually really spicy! On a nice day, you can also sit outside in the alley and enjoy your food.
author: Linda C.

description:
(edited)...I am done with this place.  It still has a pretty decent burrito.  I am over the salsa they have.  I'm also over spending 12 bucks for a burrito and coke.

This place makes a very good burrito.
At noon the line is long, but moves very quick.
It is loud inside when crowded.
On Tuesday 2/27 some fat ass (who was bald too) made a nice lady move, so he could join his other tool co-workers - adding to the hectic vibe of the dining areas - by jamming up a walk way. IDIOT!
The salsa bar has VERY HOT salsa, and a great avocado dip.  I wish they had a standard pico de gallo.
Still, it is a great lunch spot!!!

The salsa's in the burrito kind of sticks with you, it is so hot.
author: Mike A.

description: Best Mexican in SF: It's fresh, well-made using high quality ingredients. Mole is outstanding, the salsa bar is the best in town and the salsas really have spice. This comes closer to the great restaurants of Mexico City than any place I've found in the US.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I finally tried this place with my coworker. Line was out the door. My almost $10 burrito came and it was a little small than I was used to but very tasty. They have a salsa bar which I love, all kinda of salsa from salsa verde to cucumber salsa to fire salsa. I tried the fire salsa and it burns man!

Anyways, their nachos are pretty damn good too. Again, it's almost $10 but it's good for a treat now and then.
author: Leena C.

description: oh that was good. Chicken mole burrito in a tomato tortilla... & it comes with a side of chips. Yum.
author: Ellen C.

description: The salsa bar at this place is wonderful!! The best i've ever seen and tasted in fact! I'd like to drink it by the bucket (in fact sometimes i do). Burritos are excellent too!! I love the fact that it's so close to my work!
author: Rak P.

description: If you're looking for a yummy low-carb burrito with some taste this is the place! They also have great tacos and quesadillas.  I must say their salsa bar is one of a kind.  I don't think I've ever seen such a tasty selection.  They give you a bunch of containers too to fill up.  Love this place.
author: Christina O.

description: Does this place think they are located in Zimbabwe?  I have never seen a casual restaurant with the entire menu have "AQ" for their prices.  I was with a group and didn't want to hit the same place twice and this was the only option.  I found out my chicken burrito was $9.50 after tax.  It was pretty good and the salsa selection is nice.  I had the Garlic which was labeled as "HOT!" but totally was not.  It was good, though.  Spinach tortilla, I got no beans.  I can't say I was disappointed, but I will say that I enjoy a Baja Fresh burrito for $2 less (and $4 if you get their survey discount) and a lot more meat (and it's steak) AND has Guacamole included, which this place didn't.  Chips were nice.  In all, I think I'd give them a 4, but the AQ thing upsets me.  Also, their menu is hard to read due to the glare.
author: Marc S.

description: Hands down my favorite spot in the FiDi for a burrito! Try the nopales chicken mole burrito with a large horchata! You will not be disappointed. They also have a great salsa bar; my favorite is the green tomatillo. I always take two so I can finish off my chips with a little spice!
author: Tashina G.

description:
Met up with a friend here. She wanted mexican, I wanted to try this place out. Since it's so close to my work.

I, of course, had to read the reviews prior to eating here...

I ordered the chicken quesadilla...for 10 bucks, I think the food was lacking in size and a tad off on the chicken to cheese ratio.  But I digress, it was still tasty.

The saving grace for me was the Mango salsa.  OMG....so good.

This will be the reason why I return.  And to be honest, the food was pretty good.  I hate to write off a restaurant until I've been at least twice.

So yea. I'll be bah-k
author: David H.

description:
Just passing by, I see this place with a slew of empty tables in the alley, a handful of people waiting for to-go orders in the back, and no line. Decide to check it out anyway. By the time I decide what I want and place my order, there are 20 people in line behind me. Must have just beat the lunch rush...

Anyway, I got a tasty Fish Burrito with grilled red snapper on a tomato tortilla. Very clean, fresh taste and a surprisingly filling portion. Agree with others that they could be a little less stingy with the tortilla chips, especially since they have a pretty awesome variety of salsas available. Coworker had a Chicken Quesadilla which had a nice grilled flavor folded in an equally fresh tortilla. Ooh, bonus points for having Horchata (cinnamon-y rice milk). Fresh, fast, yummy, tasty.
author: Alex C.

description:
As far as FiDi burritos go, Tlaloc doesn't suck.

The ingredients are fresh and not scary and the combinations are not just your run-of-the-mill standards.

Check it out if you're in the 'hood or if you're up for a walk, seriously.
author: Kyla B.

description:
The lunchtime crush was overwhelming!! There are 3 stories of seating as well as outdoor seating, but the place was buzzing. I wouldn't normally mind sitting outside, but it was especially cold today.  

I had the corn tostada, which wasn't especially wonderful, but my co-worker had a burrito that looked great!  If I go again, I will certainly try one of the many burritos on the menu.

Word of advice, avoid going from 12-1pm during the week!!
author: Charles B.

description:
I miss this place.
Its hidden downtown on Sansome and Commercial.
The best nachos and tortilla soup a girl could dream of.
I ate there nearly every day when I worked downtown. My ass is two sizes bigger to prove it.
And a side note, the most attractive men ate there as well. Like moths to a flame I tell ya.
So if you are looking for good lunch and eye candy for dessert, this is your place.
author: mandy m.

description:
Decent mexican food in the financial district.  However, it is horribly overpriced for what you get.  If it were not for the outdoor seating I would be tempted to give this place two stars, though I would likely keep it at 3 stars given that the food is fresh and healthy tasting.  
Nothing spectacular, but God knows when it is sunny out I find myself there a ton.
author: Blake W.

description:
When I have made lunch plans with a friend --- they usual add to many vowels to Tlaloc-- like they say T-a-La-loc-- folks it is an indigenous word learn to use different sound combinations and dipthongs - yes that is a word.  

Good and expensive for the format-- seems to go up by one USD each time i eat there.  this three level taq is great.  usually some of the grub my peeps serve up-- sometimes mole or nopalitos.  their salsitas are really good.  lots of them MBA and consultant types-- you know -- the loud ex fratjock guys who go here in clans. 

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Good Salsa makes me weak in the knees.

Tlaloc garlic salsa made me weak in the knees. 

And so did the watermelon juice.
author: Bhumika K.

description:
They have pretty yummy salsa and their food is good. I recommed the tacos, just because they seem to have the most pizzaz. I got a tostada that was good but not delicious. I got a burrito once that was good but not packed full, you know? The tacos did not fail to delight me, especially with loads of mango or avocado salsa!
Good aguas frescas too. Pricey for Mexican in this city, but it is in the Financial District.
author: Elsa E.

description: Expensive Mexican food for white people. Bland.  Save your $10 and get a burrito in another neighborhood.
author: owen l.

description:
I wasn't impressed with their mole chicken burrito.  But then again, the only other time I've had mole was in Oaxaca, where it originated, so it might just be that I don't like the way they make it here.

However, I have had some of the carne asada burrito (one time they catered for an office meeting) and it was pretty good.  Their horchata is awesome too.  I give credit to Tlaloc for serving traditional Mexican ingredients like cactus, mole and seafood.  Might go back and try some of their specialties and see if it can't change my mind.
author: Serena Y.

description: The vegetarian quesadilla w/ flour tortilla is amazing! Get the avacado salsa and it somehow gets better. I also like the cucumber salsa with my chips - so spicy and good.
author: CC M.

description: PS The service is terrible. Their workers are extremely rude. Last time I place an order there.
author: Hannah O.

description: My Carne Asada burrito was filled with thick cuts of grisle, fat and chicken.... for a $10 burrito thats pretty low quality.  Very little flavor and watery for some reason. YOu can definitely find better burritos in the area.
author: Anne R.

description: Prices have gone up. This is still a go-to, but I have to come up with alternatives to keep up with my lunch budget. Bummer.
author: Paloma B.

description:
I agree with Wendy.  This place should get 3.5 (but I'm going to round down)  Its good food.  My friend Diana took me out to lunch a few weeks ago here.  I got a vegetarian torta and i think she got a vegetarian burito.  We played halfsies so we swapped halfs and got to try each.  

So the food was good, can't really comment on the service because you order from a bar.  

There are lots of choices and the prices are good.  Unfortunately for them, there's so much competition for Mexican in the city.  And this place is good but not amazing.
author: Angela S.

description:
It's Americanized Mexican food but fresh ingredients. Very long line but the wait isn't too bad. They have Sangria and Margarita at a decent price.  Food was OK, my grilled steak torta has real steak in it but it's bland, bread tasted like sourdough but there's one good thing - lots of fresh avocado in it. 

It's nothing awesome but the outdoor seating brings in extra points. Although it has about 6 kinds of salsa to choose from, they are stingy on the chips. 

Pros: Indoor/Outdoor seating, yummy salsa, big menu, good service

Cons: Taste more like American food, a little over-priced.
author: Maggie C.

description:
SALSA  VARIETY HEAVEN!!! 

This is the next best thing to a real taqueria out in the mission, and probably a LOT healthier then the taco truck near the Gap building.

They offer more then the normal burrito and quesadillas (which are awesomely yummy too!).  But what makes the food even better is the salsa bar!

Avacado or cucumber salsa!?!? where else could you get that?!
author: Deanna T.

description: Fi-di yuppie Mexican. I ordered the nachos which were $9.80. They were nothing special, overpriced, and weren't served hot. The salsa bar had a good salsa verde, and silly one called salsa infierna that was all fire and no flavor. My co-workers liked it, but they may not know any better.
author: Adam Z.

description: Burrito w/prawns and nopales: yum. Garlic salsa for the chips.
author: Maximillian M.

description: A little pricey, noisy and busy at lunch time, but the food is great!   A highlight for me is their pozole special (sometimes green, sometimes red), which is one of my favorite lunches in downtown SF!  Great agua fresca too.  As many others have said, the salsa bar is awesome!  The Cascabel pepper salsa, when they have it, is probably my favorite.  They are usually quick and courteous, so the crowds don't necessarily mean you wait too long.  One other note - this is not your typical inexpensive SF Mexican food--it is a cut above.  They do have the staples, but you can get non-typical cuisine and the ingredients are generally fresh and delicious.  Overall, thumbs up!
author: Nick K.

description:
Four stars? Five stars? You're seriously kidding right? 

HIGHLY overpriced, bad food! 

If there is anything to rave about, its the convenient location. That's it.
author: G J J.

description: As previous yelpers have said prices are not cheap. Carne Asada plate was very good. Crowded at lunch time but not really a factor with it being a nice day. Salsa bar is outstanding, garlic the best
author: Vic S.

description:
The ONLY thing that earned them two stars is their salsa bar; screamin...just wish they had something more interesting to put it on...

Overpriced, at best mediocre Mexican food..save your money & head for the Mission (hell, hit up the taco truck on Pacific bet. Battery/Sansome; it's better than this here!!!); there's too much BOMB Mexican in SF to waste your hard-earned coin here!!
author: Amoura B.

description:
I would give this place 5 stars because, it is good. BUT, $9.50 for a veggie burrito? Really? $9.50? It was good, but it wasn't THAT good. 
With this economy...no more.
author: Susan Y.

description:
the food here is pretty consistent. tasty offerings and great fruit drinks. the carne asada or steak super burritos are always good. had the crispy tacos the other day and those were also very good. what is especially good about this place is that the food is not greasy - which you can be an issue with mexican food. they have a nice salsa bar - i am partial to the salsa verde - which has a hint of heat. 

the drinks are also yummy - i personally like the watermelon but the strawberry is pretty good. it can be a bit pricey especially if you go for the seafood, but it is well worth the treat. it gets busy during the lunch rush - so get there early around 11:30 to secure your seat!
author: Joy A.

description:
Wow, This place gets crowded at the lunch hour, but I guess that is a good sign that it is good and it was delicious. The menu gives you plenty of options and the salsa bar gives you more than enough salsas to choose from. The meal comes with a side of chips as well as a huge entree. My burrito was almost too much, but I managed to eat it all. After all I didn't want to waste food. 

Yes, this place gets crowded, but they have enough seating for everyone. They have a second and third floor full of seating and they also have seating outside, which I recommend if it is a nice day. When you come in you order at the counter and they give you a number to put on your table if you are eating at the restaurant. They will come find you no matter where you sit and they have the salsa bar on every floor, so their is no need to carry all of your cups of salsa up the stairs. 

This was a little more on the expensive side, but it is a tasty treat every once in a while.
author: Carly W.

description: 2.5 stars. I was super disappointed. I am newly working in the Financial District and had wandered aimlessly for about 15 minutes before I found this place. From the outside, Tlaloc looked pretty fabulous - touting their use of all natural ingredients including farm fresh produce and Niman Ranch meat. But the chips were meh - straight out of a bag and the guacamole was seriously watered down. The burritos are predictably large and messy. The part that I REALLY didn't like was the seriously sinewy and flavorless meat. I am getting a little sick just thinking about it.
author: Jen L.

description:
Awesome Mexican food...Anything with fish is a 'Highly Recommend'...Great selection of salsas too.

Business hours so it's not available on the weekends but otherwise a great destination....Gets a tremendous lunch crowd and they flock the seating in the alley on warm weather days.

Biggest complaint is that it's a breeding ground for vulture/pigeons if you are seated outside...Extreme nuisance is understating things
author: Barca F.

description:
Yeah, yeah, the food is good, but squeezing your way through the unrelenting FiDi lunch hordes that frequent this place feels too much like waiting with scores of other deranged people for the doors at Wal Mart to open the morning after Thanksgiving.  

And they've also made the wise decision to furnish those metallic surface tables for alley seating, which are great for sitting around, if you have a pair of working eyes, during a period of midafternoon sun.
author: Sam M.

description:
I don't come here for lunch as often as I'd like because I'm not crazy about long lines, but the lines are there for a reason.  This place is GOOD.  Reallyreallyreally good.  The ingredients are fresh and they don't drown everything in cheese and sour cream--they have their proportions down just right.  Great salsa bar.  I dream of their pineapple agua fresca.  The folks working here are also especially nice and engaged, which is something that goes a long way with me. 

Two thumbs 'way up from me--four thumbs up, if I had extra thumbs.
author: Earline A.

description:
I was planning to meet the hubby for a nice lunch in the city.  Having not been for awhile, I was about to open my mouth and suggest E&O, when he opened his mouth first and suggested we try this taqueria he had mentioned before.  Taqueria?!?  I am not planning to take a long lunch and Bart into the city for tacos!  That thought and the long trek from the Bart station was enough for me to dislike the place even before arriving.

When we did get there, we saw that the line to order was already out the door.  That was enough time for me to check out the large menu on the wall.  We ordered the tostada costena, mole burrito with prawns, and a horchata.  OMG, that was the yummiest seafood salad (with a tostada buried beneath it)!  The mole burrito was good too, I am not much of a burrito fan, but this one was nice and tasty.

One thing we found interesting was that the lady who took our order at the counter also ended up bringing our food to us.  Why?  I haven't a clue, but I wish she had just stayed behind the counter taking orders, because she ended up dropping the basket of chips on my lap.  She said she would bring us another, but as soon as she disappeared down the stairs, we pretty much knew we would not see her again.  My hubby flagged down another server and asked for chips.  He brought us back this tiny little basket.  Too bad, because the salsas were really good.

This place is pricier than your average taqueria.  Each of our dishes were $10.  But as we got up to leave, and I brushed chip crumbs off my lap, I had to admit it was well worth the trek.
author: Angela O.

description:
Well I LOVE this place is the best concept ever and the best quality !!!! 

If you like this restaurant and if  you are in facebook  join this side and make your comments too.. 

" TLALOC, CHILAYO AND CANCUN " Sabor Mexicano
author: Judith L.

description: Oh how I loooove the crispy tacos at this place!!! I haven't tried anything else but if you want a rad taco with yummy salsa and sour cream then try Tlaloc!
author: Candace M.

description:
I have a sort of love/hate relationship with this place. 
First, my loves:
-all of their ingredients are organic and sourced locally, and they even use Niman Ranch meat. As a girl who only eats "Happy Meat," I love that I have a lunchtime option that's not vegetarian.  
-they know what the word "hot" means. I love me some spice. Seriously, if my face is not melting by the time i'm done eating, you have not done your job. Thanks to their xxhot salsas, I can say "mission accomplished.
-they are right outside my door. It's a 35 second walk from my office to Tlaloc. Can't really beat the convenience. 

Now, I have to hate a little:
-Tried the crispy tacos today and, while yummy, they were so messy and greasy, there is no way to eat them without knife and forking it. Also the taco shells tasted really stale. 
-But the #1 kicker for me is always the price. I mean, really. $12 for 2 tacos? Surely, you jest. This is mexican food. the whole appeal is that  cheap cuts of meat + cheap beans + cheap rice = cheap food. I realize we're paying a premium for ORGANIC cheap meat and beans and rice, but still. Give me a break. 

If the prices were lower i might be back here more often than i currently am.
author: Kathleen D.

description:
I have some good and bad but more good with two bad experiences.  Lets start with the bad.  One, they don't have the prices up on the menu board and sure that is some type of volition, or maybe not but still annoying.  Two, the tortillas they use are only steamed and not grilled or put on a fire, that is more like what taco bell would do.  Three, the salsa cups seem to always be gone and have to wait and ask for more or use plastic cups.  The worse part is that I got a very bad upset stomach from this place a few times.  Not sure if it's the salsa or what three time knows.  I was not sure if it was this place but now I'm sure.  I usually get the carne asada burrito and different salsas.  Past three times I've been there, I've gotten an upset stomach.  Thus, I'm not going here as I think it's the salsa and I'd need to use it on other food I'd eat there.
The good part was before I was getting these issues, I'd enjoy the food, minus the steamed tortilla, as well as the good price for the mean.  It was fast, no real service but I have to tip the people running around three floors and outside to deliver the food.  The workers are nice and accommodating.
author: James H.

description:
What can I say?  A place that sends me back to work blissfully buzzed...awesome.  
On the walk here, my husband got a call with news that he was getting an amazing job offer.  We had to celebrate.  I'm glad they had margaritas!  The salt on the glass was orange, not really sure what that is all about.  But I can't complain.
Good crispy tacos and a really great salsa bar.  And three levels of seating.  I really like their space.  Yes, it's expensive.  But can you expect anything else from FiDi?
author: MJ E.

description:
I have been coming Tlaloc since they opened in Financial District and before that I have been a regular patron of their Berkeley location, Tacqueria Cancun, both locations have a terrific salsa selection of salsa.

The ingrediants at Tlaloc are fresh and healthy unlike the other places in the city

Whenever I come here for lunch, I usually order their Chicken Quesidillia on a flour tortillia, the best I ever had. They also have great selection of burritos and tacos.
author: E M.

description:
Yeah, i dig this place.  Everything is fresh and delicious, pricey but worth it.  For the financial district it beats "El Barfo Faro".

Viva Horchata!
author: erica u.

description:
One of the best mexican place in the city. I went there by accident. I wanted to try Mixt Greens (right across the street) but it was so crowded, I ended up going to Tlaloc. That was a great decision. I love mexican food and this place makes great burritos. 

I am vegeterian and they have pretty decent veg menu. Food seemed to be fresh and their salsa bar is the best I have seen so far. They used organic ingredients. Also, I loved the seating area.

I would definitely recommend this place. I have been going there once a week for past month and I have not been disappointed.
author: AJ P.

description: Yummy.  I had a mole poblano burrito and a Pacifico today at lunch.  It was beautiful outside, so I and my colleagues sat at one of the outdoor tables and enjoyed DELICIOUS Mexican food (hey, standards don't get lowered, just because it's across the street from the office).  The line moved quickly, our food arrived quick, and the food was good. Really.  Not cheap, admittedly, but it's good.
author: Adam T.

description: The line was really long at lunch, but the veggie taco I got was really good, and the horchata didn't have too much cinnamon. I could stand to be a bit less expensove, but it was really delicious.
author: C D.

description: Soooo good but always busy at lunch.  It's just like Cancun in Berkeley.  I just graduated, so it's like getting a taste of college in my grown up life.  haha
author: Laurice G.

description: ok. This is another place I don't get.  They have good salsas, but man, 8 bucks for one dripping-wet-fall-apart-when-u-pick-it-up fish taco???  Eff yall!  And they don't even post the price for the fish taco on the board.  It's listed as "AQ"!  Seriously???  This is an order at the counter type of joint!  Seems like a lot of peeps dig this place though cuz it's always packed, and i've had to climb the stairs to the third floor to find a table each time!  Ok, i've been here more than once...their burritos suck too.  Weak!
author: Peter M.

description: Best nachos in town.  Garlic salsa is to die for...
author: Jeffrey R.

description: If nothing else 5 stars for their wicked salsa bar. You want spicy? Try their habanero salsa, it ummm so good!
author: Vivek N.

description: I had the super chicken burrito and it was just ok.   Come to think of it, it wasn't big enough to be called 'super', maybe just 'medium'.   I got the impression it was an over-priced place too.   Personally, I've had better for less in the Mission's.   Also, the tortilla chips were kinda stale.   On the plus side, we ate outside in such nice weather...
author: Jeff H.

description: I was warned by a co-worker not to eat the crispy tacos and type at the same time. I forgot to listen and ended up with chicken chorizo and carnitas juice on my ASDFJKL; keys. I came close to licking my keys, but then realized I was in a cubicle and not a private corner office. Sombreros off to the chef. This place rocks.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Are you really giving me that measly pile of tortilla chip crumbs with my $11 burrito?  Would a chip allotment that correlates to the price be too much of a choking hazard?  Give me a break.

Yes, the food here is good, especially the seafood, and the salsa bar is top notch.  But the price is ridiculous, there's usually a line, and there are just too many other good burrito options out there... even downtown.  You've gotta ask yourself, is it that much better than Chipotle?
author: Adam B.

description:
The first thing on the menu, Mole Poblano Burrito is awesome.

They also have a great salsa bar including an amazing Mango salsa.

Definitely worth a visit.
author: Eric T.

description: Sure it's a little pricey but the food is very high quality and the staff is friendly. Another huge plus is that they have great seating upstairs and outside. Considering how busy this place gets they do an excellent job of getting the food out to the customers quickly.
author: Pan P.

description: I love this place for the crispy tacos, the good breakfasts, and the delightful staff. My very favorite place to go for a meal when I'm at the office. Worth the twelve-minute walk each way!
author: A P.

description: Awesome breakfast burritos!!!  As a matter of fact, I can confidently say that they're the best breakfast burritos i've ever eaten.  A real cure for hangovers!  HOWEVER, they recently decided that $5.50 isn't enough for a simple breakfast burrito with cheese and jacked up the price by another 2 bucks.  That's enough to lose me as a customer.  Now not only is their lunch menu overpriced, so is their breakfast!!  Also, this place closes early.  Go to either Cafe Venue or Bistro Burger for a more reasonably priced breakfast burrito!
author: AJ B.

description: If there is one thing that is sorely missing in my neck of the Financial District, it's a fantastic burrito joint. Tlaloc is meh, okay; a-okay is a bit of an overstatement but it's not quite 2 star worthy either. When I think of great Mexican food I think of giant, stuffed to the brim burritos with the works. Give me heaping spoon fulls of guacamole and sour cream; give me large handfuls of cheese and mounds of carnitas. Tlaloc just doesn't have the same "taco truck" feel that I love. Maybe it's unfair for me to compare because clearly that's not what they're going for here... but it's my money and I'll cry about how it's spent if I want to. So there.
author: Julia N.

description: I was there last Friday with two of my coworkers for lunch. Not a bad place near work and I liked my fish tacos. It IS a bit on the pricier side compared to other Mexican places, but because of its location- they can charge more. I haven't tried anything else on their menu, but my fish tacos were pretty good and there was a crowd there - so it can't be sooo bad. I like their cucumber salsa, slightly spicy and cool. Seating -outdoors on the street and two levels inside .
author: Julie L.

description:
I'm working my way through the menu...so far I've had the chile verde and the carnitas and I've been very impressed - they use organic ingredients and it's all-around high quality [Mexican] food.

The line gets long during the lunch rush but it moves pretty quickly...especially if you order to go and eat on the steps of the old federal reserve building across the street. If you can time your meal outside the rush, there's never a wait.

As others have said, it's on the pricier side...expect to pay $9 for a super burrito and another $2 for a soda.
author: Benny B.

description: The food is OK but the prices are outrageous, I just paid $11.94 for 2 tacos!  They actually recently removed the prices from their big menu board, probably trying to trick people into paying their insane prices. (what the hell does A.Q mean anyway?)
author: miguel v.

description: Oh delicious - yet pricey - Tlaloc.  Like a mean older sister, I love unconditionally, despite the name I cannot pronounce or the weight you have helped me put on.   I love you on sunny days when I can sit outside.  I love you on rainy days when I dash the 10 feet from my office to your door.  At around 11AM, I start to yearn for your mango salsa and carne asada quesadilla.  Sure, you tease me by only giving me 14 tortilla chips, but I love you just the same.
author: Sho O.

description: I met a friend here to lunch today and had what I believe is the best grilled vegetable burrito.  I especially liked the fact that the veggies weren't the ones you don't normally want to eat (carrots).  The great selection of salsas was spot on.  My lunch mate actually traded half of her selection for mine!  I will be back for more.
author: Reyna M.

description:
The fish tacos here are my favorite fish tacos of all time.

Granted, they're probably not truly authentic, what with the aioli-type sauce in them, but they are so tasty! I always get crispy.

Wish the prices weren't so high, is all.
author: A. M.

description: Haven't eaten here for ages.  I am glad this place is still open.  It is a fabulous place to pop in for a fun casual lunch on a weekday.
author: apple r.

description: Who knew there were so many salsa variations? So many salsa options and a majority of them are BOMB. Love this place! Yummy in the tummy. A lone gem in the crusty FiDi.
author: Hanan H.

description: This place has pretty decent food.  It's flavorful, fresh and the atmosphere is fun and inviting.  I usually go here with my coworkers when we want to sit and chat since they have a decent seating area (3 floors of it).  Anyway, I usually get their salad bowl and their quesadillas are also pretty good.  They have a nice salsa bar as well -- their cucumber salsa is no joke.  The only thing is that it's pretty damn expensive.  I usually end up paying $12 bucks for my one item...definitely not worth it, I think, considering I could go to Rubio's or Chipotle and be just as satisfied.  But, my coworkers like it and I work in a small group...what can you do?
author: Jen N.

description: Ordered the taco salad in a crispy flour shell.  Very salty and kind of dull.  Not sure if I'll order it again, but chips are good!
author: Joseph C.

description: I only come here for one thing and that's their Mole Poblano burritos.  You better believe that this is a 4 star burrito all unto itself, minus the salsa and with some sour cream.  The rich mole sauce just permeates though the entire burrito so you get to taste this savory sauce in every bite.  I'm sure the other mole dishes on the menu are just as tasty but I just haven't had the urge to order anything but the Mole Poblano burrito.
author: Luis M.

description: I've had great food here before, but yesterday lunch's cactus + asada burrito just wasnt that good.  There was no spice in the burrito itself, so i had to heap on the salsa.  While the salsas here are quite good, thats just inexcusable.  Also the beef was somewhat gummy.
author: Andy G.

description:
had a friendly lunch date here just last week. 

had the carnitas super burrito and left satisfied and full.  great ingredients and a satisfactory burrito, but for a price.  nothing to write home about. 

fun salsa bar - variety's the spice of life [pun intended]. 

some of the employes addressed the patrons first in spanish and adjusted the linguistic note of the conversation in line with their personal response; i thought it was a nice and welcomed touch to the vibe.  overall, a fun place.
author: Mason S.

description: Right next to my office and awesome. I get the seafood/shrimp tacos. Also they have a great salsa bar!
author: amit s.

description: Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm....Mexican!  One of the better quick Mexican places in the city.  They even have cactus.  I don't know wtf it tastes like, but you can bet I'm going to try it.  They have 3 levels to eat here--orchestra, mezzanine, and balcony.  I highly recommend this place.  Great nachos, burritos, and quesadillas.  And they have the hottest f-ing salsa I've ever had--infierno!
author: Vanessa Z.

description: Why pay $5 for a burrito when you can pay $9?  At least, that seems to be the philosophy behind Tlaloc.  Don't be fooled by the fancy-sounding ingredients, like nopales or your choice of mole sauces.  Everything ends up tasting about the same.  That taste isn't necessarily bad, but it's not even as good as, say, the San Buena truck that's just a few blocks north, on Sansome & Pacific.
author: Ben A.

description: 3 stars is perfect for this place, it is "a-ok" in my book., but the salsa bar deserves its own star, so alas 4 stars it is.  Nothing too exciting or too bad - much like the Goldilocks's story this place was just right. The food is fresh, the salsa bar is good (hello avocado salsa), they have a good menu selection, the chicken burrito was a good size and tasty. One downer is that It gets PACKED at lunch, so if you want to sit or not battle crowds then get here before noon. A solid FiDi Mexican lunch place.
author: Jessica R.

description: Great lunchtime Mexi in the Fidi!  They have a nice and varied menu selection, and the salsa bar is on point!  yum....mango salsa!
author: C R.

description: Featuring the most amazing selection of freshly chopped salsas ever! Tlaloc makes an awesome burrito. On my first trip here I had one with mole poblano, chicken and nopales. I want to eat dinner here too, alas it seems they close at 8pm each night :(
author: P H I L H.

description:
I would have given it four stars if not for the consistently loud music that makes lunchtime conversation all but impossible.  The tacos are fabulous and I go here frequently for take-out.

But please, please turn the music down.  The food is fantastic but the atmosphere is impossible - I'd love to sit down to eat with friends but we can't... or maybe it's the loud music that keeps the tables turning?
author: Zoe F.

description: Every item here is merely a delivery vehicle for the kickin salsa. Maybe the burritos are $10 because someone has to pay for my salsa habit. Fresh, delicious and tangy. That's the mango salsa I'm talking about, the food is also delicious; but really, it's all about that salsa bar.
author: Jennifer O.

description: This place can really suck sometimes, like when the cashier girl says they have shrimp burritos and then charge your credit card only to tell you a minute later that they are out of shrimp burritos.  Seriously, people stop eating all the shrimp burritos.
author: K N.

description: As far as ordering from these guys to have your corporate lunch catered you better pass! I ordered from these guys four days in advance to have lunch catered for my company and they were 40 minutes late.  How difficult is it to find One Market?! I will never order lunch from this restaurant again!!! Unprofessional and too laxed for corporate lunch.
author: Catina S.

description: Definitely overpriced for lunch, (go to Alex's) but they make the best damn Breakfast Burritos ever. I believe if you're in before 9am they're only $2.50. Plus you get free chips and they have that kick-ass salsa bar. If you haven't been here for breakfast yet, you have no idea what you're missing.
author: Justin B.

description: Food is good, but overpriced for what you get.  I paid about $9 for a vegetarian burrito and was surprised how tiny it was.  If you walk a few blocks on either side, you can get a much better burrito deal that's just as good.
author: Katie U.

description: Yum Yum and yes one more because I just like the way it sounds, YUM! A good friend took me here ( same friend that took me to Henry's Hunan) and I cant get Enough. Just had the Noples w/ Prawns Burrita ( that's BURRITO for all you all ) Not only was I full but happy in belly. And if you get the chance try the Ceviche De Camaron. ....... yum. Go early it gets crowded fast. And they even do breakfast.
author: Tony P.

description: This place is awesome.  Sure it's a bit expensive but come on, you know that suit sitting next to you is making twice as much money as you so suck it up and live large.  The burritos here are killer.  They even have cactus in them.  The salsa bar is great too.  The topper is the nice, sunny outdoor seating area where you will be attacked by pigeons.  All part of the fun, my friend.  I am eating lunch here today and am already salivating.  Mmmmm, salivating.
author: Tony B.

description: Bomb. Biting into the carnitas taco is like biting directly into the side of a swine.
author: Kevin L.

description: Great tacos!  I come here at least once every other week for lunch.  They have a wonderful selection of salsas that actually have some kick!  The mango salsa and the cumbuer salsa are very tasty.
author: Lenee F.

description: I've eaten lunch here a number of times, and I never walk away thinking, "Wow, that was a damn good burrito."  Nor do I ever walk away thinking "Ugh, I'm never eating there again."  Typically, I think "That burrito was pretty damn mediocre for 10 bucks."  But their salsa bar (mango salsa, avocado salsa) makes you feel a little better about spending so much on the burrito.  And they do have outdoor seating in the sun.  If only they could get rid of those disgusting pigeons that attack the tables when people leave.
author: Erica G.

description:
It was a beautiful day in the FiDi last Friday and what perfect way to enjoy the lunch hour?  Head over to Tlaloc with Ritasha L., snag a seat in the cute alleyway of Commercial and Sansome, order a pitcher of sangria for two, and enjoy a yummy lunch while basking in the sun.

We arrived a little after noon, and the line was already out the door.  We were glad we left the office a little earlier because the line doubled within minutes.  While I wasn't too thrilled about my low-carb grilled beef burrito, Ritasha L. loved her carnitas quesadilla.  I loved it too, and cannot wait to try it again.  And goodness, the salsa bar at Tlaloc is amaaaaazing!  Mango salsa, garlic salsa, salsa verde, tons of variety!  I absolutely love it.  Our pitcher of sangria only set us back NINE dollars.  I was so shocked at how inexpensive it was, but after tasting it, we understood why.  Tons of juice, and not much alcohol, but we really enjoyed the fresh bits of strawberry and watermelon.  Although no lunchtime buzz, it did leave me with a very full bladder!  Overall, despite slightly higher-priced Mexican food, I would undoubtedly come back for the carnitas quesadilla and delicious salsa bar, and if the weather gets warmer again, you'll definitely find me enjoying a nice lunch outside Tlaloc.

Funny story: While picking up my pitcher of sangria, the nice lady asks me, "How many cups? Three? Four?" and I sheepishly say, "No, just two" and her eyes bug out and she exclaims, "Two?!?! Haha, okay.  I'll give two big cups."  Then she proceeds to hand me two chilled beer pint glasses from the refrigerator, instead of the typical dainty glasses they give customers for sangria.  Yeah, I'm not ashamed to say I like to drink during working hours!
author: Diane L.

description: Despite the thrill of the fine fish burrito I just devoured, I feel like a donkey for paying $10. I like my mexican food at mexican prices.
author: Ferol G.

description: The line before 12:00 is manageable. Once 12:01 hits, the flood gates open and the entire financial district is in here. I ALWAYS get the steak quesadilla with a small strawberry agua fresca. The strawberry agua fresca has real strawberries floating around, and probably has a pound of sugar but is too good to pass up. I tried a burrito once and it wasn't nearly as good as "Big City Wraps" (extension of Chevy's) in the Embarcadero center, so I just stick with my quesadilla. They take Visa which is nice.
author: Sandi Q.

description: Basically a high-end burrito/Mexican place.  Nice decor.  Many salsa choices... strawberry, inferno (this will burn your tongue for sure), avocado and others.  Plus they place tables on the lane outside during lunch.  This works most times in summer in perpetually chilly SF.  I had the Torta Vegetariana - Mexican grilled sandwich w cheese, refried beans, avocado, sour cream, tomatoes, lettuce and onions.
author: ITesh J.

description:
Tlaloc, how do I love thee?  Let me count the ways...

1. Your salsa bar blows my mind.  Your hottest salsa also blows my esophagus -- with a blow-torch.  Watch out!

2. Your burritos are like a summer's day...somewhere besides San Francisco.  I guess I should be more specific.  They're like a summer's day in a place that has summer, and delicious, fresh ingredients.

3. Your service is quick even when you're busy.  Thanks for that.

4.  Outdoor seating, which is great even on those not-so-summery San Francisco summer days as long as you're wearing layers.
author: Alice T.

description: The service here is inconsistent and I have had some not so great experiences. However, the food is always consistently good. I love the tostada so much that I can't stop myself from ordering it every time I go. This place gets really packed weekdays from 11:30 am to 1:00 pm. It is a popular Financial District eatery. The salsa bar is good too, especially the cilantro and guacamole salsa. Bottom line: food always good. Service needs improvement.
author: Kim J.

description:
yes i will pay the little more it costs for a decent burrito!  the prawns burrito is my favorite here, and everyone i bring seems to enjoy their food too.  they serve beer, sangria, and those mexican fruit juice things.  outdoor seating is nice (just don't feed the pigeons) and their indoor seating is spread over 3 floors.  the food assemblers work fast to get you your food without compromising tasty ingredients and neatness.
it's too bad they're not open in the evenings for a nice after-office happy hour.
author: Monk R.

description:
Why can't other taquerias make their salsas like Tlaloc?  The mango salsa is the best I've had.  The burritos are a little small compared to other mexican joints (but still good) and they've cut back on their chip portions which sucks cuz then I am tempted to eat the mango salsa with a spoon.

revised: why does tlaloc's inflation rate increase at a faster rate than any other place in SF?  They can't even keep up with their own prices because it changes so quickly...The menu fixture doesn't even have prices on it.  They painted over it w/ "A.Q." whatever that means.  Burritos are smaller, chips are less, and the mango salsa tastes different.
author: LT B.

description: Did I read right or is this place really opened to 3 A.M. O crap food here is good! So far I've had a the prawn and fish burrito and they were delicious. Be warned here and now. Taco's as I've been told are addictive and cost 7 bucks. Also, they have a wide variety of salsa. I found the mango just a tad bit spicy while the avocado a bit chunky for me. Tables all around but it's to accommodate the lunch crowd around the financial district. I came here once at 12:30 and was bothered between escaping the line and the drool in my mouth. Naturally I stayed and will come back ever so often. And the now I pray that in return at the A.M hours that I would not vomit out their pricy taco's.
author: Harry L.

description: $8.19 for a very, very bland, meagre bean and cheese burrito. The line out the door doesn't mean the food is good. If you're a vegetarian, you're better off getting a chain burrito from La Salsa, or Rubio's or better yet, walking down to Pancho Villa's, where a burrito 50% larger will cost you about $3 less. First and last time.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description:
Trudging through the morning fog to station yourself at whatever soulless job you're working in the FiDi is a little rough on any given day, but when you're still hiccuping up your last "Happy Hour (turned when did it get to be midnight?!)" cocktail there is only one solution: Tlaloc's fantastic Burrito con Chorizo.

The girl who works the register, as mentioned below, is also just about the sweetest person on the planet. Or at least in the FiDi. 

All breakfast burritos now cost $4, which is absolutely worth it because you probably won't need to eat lunch. Which is good - because the only reason I can't give Tlaloc 5 stars is that I can't afford lunch here... Ohh overtime, when will you come back into my life?
author: Katie C.

description: I went here today with some co-workers.  I like Tlaloc.
