It's very reminiscent of Cancun, which is in Berkeley - same aguas fresca and same salsa (less selection of salsas than in Berkeley, but still great).  It's owned by the same folks, I hear.  It's not "authentic" Mexican food, but it's Cal-Mex, and pretty good, I might add.  I ordered the prawn tostada and it was delicious.  The food also came pretty quickly, which is a plus in my book.  With an aguas fresca and one dish, you'll be paying around $10.00, but that's okay.  The interior is enough to cheer you, and the food is enough to have you coming back for more!
author: Quyen T.

description:
zerO STARS.

one word:  OVERRATED.  big letdown, waaay overpriced ($13 for a shrimp ceviche with NO shrimp!)  not authentic. NO star for this joint.  i'm still pissed...
author: Carmel D.

description: Breakfast review:  Great price, 5 bucks for a nice burrito.  I get the eggs and chicken chorizo on whole wheat tortilla.  Really nice salsa bar with some great variety and flavors.  Try the cucumber salsa---excellent.
author: Raman R.

description: Overpriced for a burrito shop, but the food is good. Solid salsa bar, which has become the new barometer for burrito shops.
author: Juan R.

description:
I love love love the salsa bar here!  Mango, sometimes even strawberries, and the tomatillo are all super tasty.
The prawn, napales, pipian mole, regular mole burritos are all my favorites.  The salads and the tortilla soup are great lunch options too.
Breakfast is perfect for hungover days--churizo burritos and agua fresca...yum!
author: Amy C.

description: Pretty good crispy taco (prawns). However, they did overdo it with the pico, guac, and sour cream. The highlights here though are the outdoor seating and one of the best salsa bars this side of Mexico...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Just went back today for the first time in many years. Unfortunately for this place Los Socios is a mere 2 blocks away so I never make it to this place unless it's a nice day and I want to sit outside like today. They make a solid chicken burrito (they use breast meat which is key). The spiciest salsa really is spicy so be careful.
author: Michael K.

description: Completely delicious!  As a Cal student I would frequent Cancun on Allston for their amaaaazing chicken quesadillas and fresh watermelon frescas (that they happened to be across the street from the only tanning salon in Berkeley didn't hurt either).  Anyway....now that I am in SF I rarely make it back over the bridge, and I was missing my fav Mexican food....until I realized that Tlaloc is the exact same place!!  Seriously, try this out - you won't regret it.  Plus, an oozing cheesy scrumptious quesadilla is so much better than a $15 salad from Mixt Greens, which is across the street.    p.s. if you're feeling especially naughty during a work day lunch, I hear the sangria is to die for...
author: Liz C.

description: Mmmm I love their salsas.  Especially the mango salsa.
author: Jen Z.

description: Decent food but nothing special or spectacular...Baja Fresh quality with Financial District prices. The major plus is the outside seating on Commercial St...which is great to go and catch up with friends during lunch on a decent day.  Wouldn't mind going again if a friend suggests it but definitely not somewhere I would crave on my own.
author: Tanger T.

description: Mexican food that doesn't leave you feeling gross afterwards. It's fresh and clean, and seems healthier than some of the mission joints. MUST HAVE: prawn burrito. it is a hangover cure AND it's sooooooooo good!
author: Marina K.

description: Great lunch place in the financial district. Probably my favorite non authentic Mexican burrito place. The two mole burritos are awesome. You can choose from several different tortilla types.  I like that you can choose from a variety of salsas at the salsa bar plus sit outside on the occasional nice day. The only problem is that their spicy salsa isn't hot enough.
author: Keith R.

description: Tlaloc has some really good freakin' burritos.  If you're around downtown SF in the Financial District, you should really stop by and give this place a try sometime.  The burritos are juicy and fat and filled w/ all usual goodies found in burritos.    They've got some very interesting (and tasty) salsas to go w/ your burrito and chips.  The restaurant's location is great to enjoy some sunny weather, and it's also right across from Mixed Greens, so you also get to enjoy the eye-candy that gets their meal from there as well.  I'm sure it's b/c rents are crazy expensive in this area, but burritos will run you around $7-$10, depending on what you order.  But it's well worth a shot.
author: Minh V.

description: I love the chunky breakfast burrito with ham and potatoes only 4 bucks in this area is a score.The only cheaper alternative is yucky.The people are very nice in the morning and a bit in a hurry at lunch.and it gets crowded at lunch but,oh well.The salsa fresca is good and not to MUI CALIENTE and works for gringos.
author: Tim G.

description: 3.5 stars.  not an authentic southern california taqueria or anything, but good place to get tex mexy lunch in FiDi.  the salsa bar has a variety of fresh salsas that are both on the mild and spicy side.  the avocado salsa is a good mild one.  watch of for the inferno salsa, it's SUPER HOT!
author: Wendy S.

description:
The food is good...not outstanding...just good. The one star is for these jackasses overcharging my credit card and refusing to address it after I contacted them 5 times and even met with the manager with my receipt. It was a take out and I scratched out "tip" and wrote down the exact amount under "total" clearly. Why'd you go and charge me a 28% tip? I hate it when restaurants do sneaky stuff like this and think people will forget or have lost the receipt by the time the credit card statement arrives. It's dishonest.

My only option was to dispute it with my credit card. It's crazy how the manager just kept ignoring my complaint rather than apologizing and issuing a refund immediately. It shows you they are bad business people, meaning you shouldn't be doing business with them. 

Food is overpriced and portions are small. And they do this other sneaky thing where the prices on the big menu boards are either missing or so faded you can't see them. So people feel bad asking prices when there's a long line and just order. Then they're like "wow, I just spend $18 (before tip) on one lunch for myself and I'm not even full." You and me are done Tlaloc. Boycotting your ass.
author: James W.

description: This is my FAVORITE burrito place in the FiDi. So yummy. I ordered a vegetarian burrito and it was amazing, so light and filled with fresh lettuce salsa, cheese...I just can't describe it, the taste was amazing. The decor on the inside was nice and I was impressed with their use of space. They even grow and farm some of their own stuff. Very yummy Very good, and I am very much a fan!
author: Jenna K.

description: I like this place and usually eat lunch here once a week. Their specials are quite tasty and I'm a fan of their mole. The carne asada plate is damn good. They seem to be missing a sauce that is just 'hot' though. There is one that is marked 'hot', but it is mild at best. Then there is one that I can only describe as stupid which unfortunately sacrifices flavor for heat. The outdoor seating is very nice though. It is on the pricey side. Then again, it is in the financial district.
author: Jordan M.

description: Meh, average Mexican food. And a little pricey at that. My burrito was decent, but the salsa was nowhere near as good as other reviews had me ready for. The two overlooking stories and chill outdoor seating are worth a star on their own. Also, our food came surprisingly fast for how busy they were. All in all, it was a worthy place for lunch, but doesn't warrant a trip back or recommendation.
author: Keith K.

description: Before I only new this place as the place in the alley by the salad place and now I know it as the place for a great place to get a shrimp quesadilla. The variety of salsa's here is crazy. They go from the mild mango salsa to the XXsalsa, which will make your head explode. The chips are good and tasty. But still the best thing here is the shrimp. Huge perfectly cooked shrimp in a green tortilla with all the great tastes that a quesadilla should be.
author: Jacob T.

description:
for months, i didn't venture here because people said they were overpriced. then, a friend told me they had the world's best breakfast burrito. after a few months, and a really hard workout, i was craving *something*, so i decided to give it a shot. OM MAH GAWD. heaven! on! earth! absolutely scrumptious! super fluffy rich eggs, creamy refried beans, chopped tomato salsa, and a buttery tortilla, and topped with their casera salsa from the salsa bar, and this has been my breakfast every day for the last month now. i also tried the chorizo one, the chilaquines (tortilla chips) one, and the potato one, but the basic "frijoles con huevos" is perfect for me. the best part is that when i nom on one of these, i'm not hungry until 2:30! then, i grab a light salad at mixt ($6.95 for the simple ones), and i'm set until dinner with enough energy for a yoga class beforehand. and- the best part- no late morning or late afternoon slump. it's miraculous. and i'm a really healthy eater, and feel sick if i don't eat light foods.

seriously, all. world's best breakfast burrito. can't believe they don't have a line out the door for it.
author: Cyn K.

description: I haven't been able to get past the crispy carnitas tacos and the mango salsa, so i can't say if anything else is any good.  But when i worked in the city and had enough money to spend $4/taco, i went here.  I'm salivating now just thinking about the slightly crispy corn tortilla, juicy flavorful crunchy pork, sour cream and guacamole with some mango salsa dripping down my arm while i eat the taco.... ah heaven on earth!!  the best $4 tacos i've ever had.... the only $4 tacos i've ever had.  They are a little pricey, even for being in the financial district.  Oh yeah, they have good breakfast burritos too... forgot about those.
author: esther h.

description: Amazing selection, fresh ingredients, good prices, and they are lightning fast. I never leave hungry! I've also ordered catering from them, and it's delicious, but they never provide sour cream. Tlaloc, please start giving your catering customers sour cream! Mexican food without sour cream is like Italian food without tomatoes!
author: Jessica P.

description: Automosphere is really nice. The workers aren't very welcoming. i had a Carne asada Burrito and it was not very tasty as i imagined. The meat had alot of nerves so i couldnt really eat it. should of played it safe and got something veggie. The burrito was about 7 bucks.
author: Brigitte G.

description: I've never eaten at Tlaloc's locale, but our office gets lunch catered from there all the time and everything is great.  We love it! I particularly like the chicken or vegetable fajitas, the mango salsa, the chips, and the grated queso fresco they provide for the beans.
author: Dee I.

description: The best Mexican food in the Financial District / Embarcadero area, although expensive compared to joints in the Mission.  Their carnitas is some of the best I've had in the city.  You'll also be rewarded if you stray beyond the burrito menu, particularly when they have pozole.  Load up on the roasted tomatillo salsa.
author: Tyler N.

description: THE CARNITAS ARE THE BEST.  Overall, i really like this great lunchtime spot, but you must try the carnitas and the avocado salsa.  mmmmmmmmm. If you want something sinful you should get a crispy taco - yummy and cheesy and greasy and guacamole and yum.
author: B R.

description: The tacos are pretty good, but the REAL reason to come here is for the array of spicy, tangy, fruity, savory, delicious SALSAS. Wow, they have awesome salsas.
author: Sahra H.

description: This place is perfect when I'm craving a burrito, especially since it's on the same street that i work on.  I especially love the salsa bar for your chips!  A variety of salsas that you can pack up in little containers & there's no limit.  The prices for burritos are a little more expensive than other places, but what do you expect for the Financial District? I've heard the breakfast burritos are good & cheap, but I've never tried it for myself.  They set up tables and chairs in the alley so you can sit & eat, but watch out for the pigeons and bums that like to hang around there.
author: Val L.

description: $10 burrito? Yeah it was expensive, but it was damn yummy. Probably the freshest burrito I ever had. Which one did I order? I had the chicken breast burrito - grilled veggies and chicken on a whole wheat tortilla. Kickass! They also have a lot of salsa, I liked the mango and the avocado salsa best. Those were like a party in my mouth!
author: Lester L.

description: They have a pretty impressive salsa bar with some interesting varieties like pumpkin and mango. But it's super hard to justify a $10 burrito with a small amount of chips. I rather walk a couple blocks to Pancho Villa.
author: Gladys C.

description:
Went here for lunch for the first time in a while.  My coworkers and I were underwhelmed.  Recognizing the economy's effect on everyone, and making allowances, still doesn't help this place.  

On the plus side, the service is good, quick, and pleasant.  The food comes quickly.  However, that was where the good news ended.  Everyone's portions were smaller than before (making an allowance here), but $10 for a half plate of nachos is ridiculous.  My lunch (chicken taco, beef taco, horchata) came to $15!!!  Two tacos and a drink.  Sheesh.  My other coworkers had similar reactions to the reduced portions and higher prices.

We sat up on the mezzanine, and the music was turned up so loud you literally had to shout to be heard across the table.

The breakfast burritos are $4 (I've had them before), but they are about half the size the were as well.

So, if you have about $15-$20 to drop on a couple of tacos, this is the place for you.  Just be sure to get it for take-out, or you're likely to go deaf (or hoarse!) trying to talk to someone inside.

My lunch crew and I will not be back here anytime soon.  So disappointing.
author: Julia J.

description: Get the Prawn Quesadilla - it's amazing, the best in SF!  Tlaloc is premium, their ingredients are top notch.  Their salsa selection is great, with their mango salsa front and center, I dig their alley way seating too.   Did I mention the prawn quesadilla is freakin' ridiculous.
author: Ken F.

description: I agree with Kathleen.  The food sounds really good, but it is awfully expensive for what you get.  Salsa bar is definitely worthy of praise, though, as is the outside seating, which is bathed in sunlight during the summer and not so much in winter.  And watch out for those pigeons.
author: Kerry L.

description: This place is great! I love their burritos! They are very clean and fast. However, they are a expensive. If you are coming during lunch time be prepared to either eat outside or wait for a table. This place is always crowded! Their sister restaurant in Berkeley, Cancun, is just as great!
author: Christina O.

description: Above average mexican food, but the salsa bar is what separates this tlaloc from the others. The chips are fresh, crunchy and flavorful, combined with the wide variety of salsas they have and you better have a large beverage of your choice ready to go
author: Russ C.

description: Three stars because it's the best mexican option in the Fidi.  Yeah, it's overpriced, but have you been to Mixt Greens across the street? Salads can get up to $15, which is absurd in my book.  I think the burritos are just fine, the mole sauce is yummy, and the outdoor tables are perfect on a nice day.
author: Michelle L.

description: Not good at all. The burrito was soggy and dripping. The tostado was basically iceburg lettuce with a few beans sprinkled on top. Go to Orale Orale if you want good Mexican food.
author: Emily A.

description: My coworker picked up some stuff for the office from here the other day, and it was ok.  The hot sauce doesn't mess around.  In the end, a pretty good lunch, although i would've liked it better if my burrito didn't come so close to ten dollars.  But then again, I grew up in an area where you can get much bigger burritos for $4 and might've ruined my expectations price wise.
author: Joel J.

description:
The food is mediocre but if you are craving tex-mex at lunch it is a good bet.

I gave them one star because on their menu board every item is marked as "AQ" ...   It''s fast food - there is no excuse not to post their prices.
author: kathy l.

description:
I went there, excited that I could get something besides Mixt Greens (across from there) for a change, and because they had a bunch of vegetarian options! I ordered the Grilled Vegetable Burrito to-go and stepped aside and waited...and waited...and waited.... I probably waited for a good 20-30 minutes, while everyone else that came after me was getting their orders.  I asked the woman on the counter, who politely went and asked the cooks about my burrito, and then told me to wait some more because grilling my  veggies takes a long time (seriously?!)
Anyway, I walked back to my office, eager to end my starvation, and enjoyed the first three bites in.  Soon however, I  bit into something that didn't taste right - it tasted like flesh, and I spat it out to see a 2.5" piece of meat, chicken, most likely.  I was disgusted.  That's about the worst thing you could do to a vegetarian - include bits of meat, hidden in a burrito, that is taken to-go! I was pretty disappointed, but was starving, so looked around, and picked out some other random pieces of meat.  Thinking that my burrito was now vegetarian-friendly again, I continued eating, only to find about half way in that there was another piece of chicken. Yuck!
Needless to say, I threw the rest of my burrito :( And drank tons of water to wash down the taste of grilled flesh.  
I'm not sure I'm going back to Tlaloc again, or ordering food to go!
author: Nini I.

description: I really like this place for a quick lunch in the financial district. Their mango salsa is to die for. They have good chips and a great salsa bar. I have enjoyed their quesadillas and their burritos. Not the cheapest mexican place, but good food!
author: Cat F.

description: Great breakfast burritos, especially with black beans.  Pretty good for  a quick lunch too.  Lots of inside and outside seating.  Try salsa verde with your chips!
author: Nellie L.

description: Loved this place in the beginning but have found the quality to slip in the past year.  don't get me wrong -- still serve up a decent burrito but very pricey for what you get.  Waiting for La Salsa to open on Battery so I can get the same quality food for a reasonable price.
author: Marnie C.

description: I do really like their food, but it does always seem like I'm paying to much for it.  Maybe I'm just really used to Cancun in the Mission or maybe I'm just cheaper than I let on.  Either way good food, but they need to check their prices.
author: David P.

description: So here is my take on Mexican/Central/South American food.  A lot of it that actually makes it North into that states tastes the same as the next.  Perhaps my pallet is flat when it comes to this, but thats how I feel.  This place seems a refreshing change, and a good option for the downtown lunch crowd.  The mole is decent, prawns and chicken are both tasty and good quality, the salsa bar is sweet with tons of variety, strawberry juice with yummy chunks mixed in, and the latina working the counter had nice eyes and her coworkers were all stoked and happy = BUENO
author: Porfirio R.

description: Another over-priced taqueria sporting mediocre food for exorbitant prices. I've been there 3 times so far and have been impressed by only one thing; their salsa's. Their salsa's kick ass---seriously exceptional. But a super carne asada burrito will cost you $9 plus tip and it'll be small and my personal pet peeve, cold. Why are the vast majority of burritos lukewarm at best? If you order cream in your burrito, forget it, you'll have to hold it with mitts. If you're in the FiDi go to Orale Orale. It'll cost you the same but the meat will be more tasty and the burrito will be the size of a baby---not the size of a baby's forearm.
author: Mario T.

description: The salsa bar is awesome.  I particularly recommend the cucmber salsa and the avocado one.  Mmmmm.  Like others said, the portions and prices leave something to be desired, but seeing as how I can't get out to the Mission and back on an hour lunch, it'll do.  I'm probably being too generous with the stars, but I'm having a good day.
author: angela k.

description: My favorite mexican in the Fidi.....quick and quality.
author: Adrienne G.

description: Amazing salsa bar, and decent burritos. It's just a shame they steam their tortillas (instead of grilling them).
author: Chadwick M.

description: A bit pricey for burritos but it is San Francisco and in the midst ofthe Financial District. A good place for lunch - I like bring out of towners here. The burritos are good and the agua frescas are yummy.  The salsa bar is a nice touch. Indoor and outdoor city - which is a must in a city where the weather can go from sunny warmth to misty chills in a heartbeat.
author: Sandra P.

description: Yummy! I come here once a week for lunch. My favorite dishes include: their low carb shrimp salad, crispy fish taco or their mole burrito. YUM! I can honestly say that they have the best strawberry agua fresca i've ever tasted. I love how there are slices of strawberries in it. Delish!
author: S N.

description: Love it.  Great food, it's consistent & they are quick.  The only reason I gave it four stars is because it is quite pricey for a Mexican Food joint and they don't have enough indoor seating sometimes.
author: Nathalie C.

description: Everyone has their secret shame.  The breakfast burrito fully equipped with tortilla chips, eggs, avocado is one of mine!
author: Miss T.

description: I finally ventured away from my usual and was very pleased with the chicken and veggie burrito. We happen to see this being made as we waited in line and it looked great. I was a great alternative to the prawn tostada. It was surprisingly light and wasn't weighed down with rice or beans.
author: Samantha H.

description: We cater for work from Tlaloc at least once every year and they always do a great job. We order a whole mess of varieties as they have traditional tacos soft and crispy and the burritos, choice of meat, pork, fish or veges. From the quesidillas to the plates everyone seems to enjoy the fiesta of food. Oh we love their salsas I think they have at least 10 different types from spicy to fruity. The price is right too. Go there before 11:30am or after 1:45pm ish otherwise there is a line. The wait is not too long as the line goes purty fast but planning ahead works bestest.
author: Angela R K.

description: Not a mission burrito, but a great burritos in this downtown location. What really makes it amazing are the incredible salsas. A selection of 8-10 of different spicy variety, all very fresh.  As far as atmosphere, on nice days they even have a little outside area to sit, which makes it very appealing. Overall, my favorite burrito place downtown.
author: Franco R.

description: This place is the hangover helper!  Massive burritos and horchata always do the trick for me.  They have an extensive menu and a great outdoor seating option for warm days.
author: Jessica V.

description: Hot damn this place is good!  5 giant stars for how good the food is - the salsa bar is the best around!  Everytime I'm in there eating my lunch, I'm always pondering ways to steal the mango salsa.  Do you think they would notice if I brought in an empty glass jar and filled it with mango salsa and just walked out the door with it?  I seriously want to do that.  That being said, there is a reason I can't give this place five stars, and here's why:  over the last year that I've been coming here for lunch, I've noticed that not only have their prices gone through the roof, but their burritos seem to keep getting smaller.  I'm starting to feel like every time i go I am paying more for less.  Maybe I really should start stealing their salsa...
author: Katie J.

description: Decent Mexican food here - big burritos and awesome salsa bar!
author: Amy L.

description: Best mexican for lunch in the Financial District.  From the awesome burritios to the crazy greasy yummy crispy tacos.  High quality salsa bar to top it all off.
author: Nagoo N.

description: I frequently come here for lunch and I am never disappointed. The array of salsas at the salsa bar is impressive (and some are definitely on the fiery side of the capsicum scale). The fish burrito is always tasty and not too heavy.
author: Anthony B.

description:
recommendo!

i hesitate to compare this to other taquerias because of the relative high fidi prices and small fidi portions

my standard order is the mexicano burrito featuring nopales and queso fresca.  it's not very big, but it's consistently good and with some chips and avocado salsa, i never go away hungry.  really it's a responsible lunch size for a dude with a desk job.

the offerings at the salsa bar are quite good, leaning on the sweet side (which is fine with me).  i love the avocado salsa.  cucumber (spicy!) and garlic are also good.

it can be quite crowded during the lunch rush, the outdoor seating in the closed alley is a nice perk.
author: brian r.

description: I work nearby and stop here for lunch once every few weeks, just for the prawn taco, which is delicious. Prices seem a bit steep ($7-9 for a taco?), and what I've been charged varies based on whether I take the food out ($2 more) versus eat in ($2 cheaper) - I don't really get that. The salsa bar seems just okay, but I'm not a salsa connoisseur. Orders come out fairly quickly and I haven't gotten sick here yet.
author: A M.

description: Nice alley seating for a sunny day. THe interior of the restaurant was cool too. Pretty good gourmet burritos, but nothing spectacular (I had chicken adobo in a green tortilla). It was different, but I guess I'd almost rather just have a traditional old burrito. And it bugged me that the menu only listed "AQ" for the prices (it looked like there had been prices, but they'd been removed). I mean, "AQ"? Do they have to price everything daily based on what the market is asking for beans that day? Hrm. That made me wary, but I was there with friends so I went ahead.... and ended up with a $10 burrito. I'm cheap, I know, but it wasn't really $10 worth of tastey. I think I'll stick with the low-brow burrito places.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Its a bit pricey. But great when the weather is nice. Super busy around 12pm. Try and go around 1pm so you can sit where you want. Mole Chicken burrito is my order of choice.
author: Scott T.

description:
I like this place because they have sauces - "salsas" down ! They have great taste and a variety for every palette. Their service is quick. Order, take your number to any of the 3 levels or outside seating and it will soon arrive at your table. I find that their descriptions are sometimes a little different from what people might be used to so you have to experiment until you find the thing you like there. The portions are not overly large but they taste good and that is what gives them value in my book.
See a video of the place @ http://sf-lunch.com/2008/03/12/tlaloc-taqueria-salsa-galore/
author: SF Luncher z.

description: The really yummy burritos and excellent salsa bar keeps me returning to this overpriced mexican restaurant. The food is fantastic and after 20 years in the financial district I continuously struggle to find inspiration at the lunch hour.  So far Tlaloc has kept my interest.  That being said, a vegetarian burrito for $8.75 is ridiculous.  If not for the inflated prices, I would have rated it higher.  The only other thing is that in the winter, this place is COLD.  You will not find any coziness in coming here for lunch and trying to enjoy a warm meal. The space is good, but the windows and doors are open and it's FREEZING.  Be prepared to eat while wearing your jacket or to take your food to go and eat in the warm comforts of your office. Summer is great. There are plenty of seats inside and out.
author: RK G.

description: Best mexican food in financial district...including most of the sit down restaurants.  only reason people would give this less than 4 stars is they are looking for LA taco stand prices.  Salsas, carnitas, tamales (daily special only) are the bomb.
author: Raj D.

description: This place has breakfast burritos for 2.50 super good deal especially these days the sangria's are really good  to for sunny afternoons. The lunch dishes are all pretty good and fresh. Everything is pretty tasty. Their salsa bar is fresh everyday and has wonderful selections of yummy salsa's prepared on daily basis. I'm a fan of this place, they also deliver for lunch.
author: Olga P.

description:
too pricey for my taste.  i'm fine with busting 12-13 bucks on a lunch...personally, i just don't find this place worth it.

i would call the food "healthy mexican" which is a nice mixup from the usual sandwich or thai.  so i guess i find myself coming back once a month, because it is different.  but it's just not that good.  and you have to spend 10 dollars to feel full.  meh.

also, somehow, the last two times i've come (in the last two months), my food has come out eons after everyone else got their food.  the first time i got two crispy fish tacos with guac (cost ~13), and they lost my order.  they did not comp me (the place is super busy, so i suspect that this isn't a place that does such things, but still, i was kinda pissed, that i was spending ~13 on a lunch and they lost my order, and then just made it when i finally asked because i noticed that people way after me were getting their food.  i had to wait forever!  and so did my coworkers cause they're nice).  

the second time, i got the seafood tostada.  they did not lose my order.  they just took a long time.  this time, one of my coworkers got the seafood quesadilla, so i thought i'd be safe in ordering a seafood dish, cause i wouldn't be the only one holding everyone up.  nope, again, my food took a long time to come out, it came out long after his.  i'm not sure what it is about what i order.  but it's just a little irritating to be waiting for what feels like forever.  sure, my sense of forever isn't quite the dictionary definition.......but it totally feels like it when everyone you're with has their food, and you're all alone with no food, when you've ordered your food at about the same time they have, and you feel this guilt for holding everyone else from their work and involuntarily extending their lunch break.

whatever is causing the delays, no matter how much it isn't tlaloc's fault, the end result for me is an unsatisfactory dining experience.
author: J R.

description:
OMG. Not crazy about the name (don't Wiki it!), but scrumptious, well-seasoned food. The burrito adobado was finger-licking good. Warning: divide your portion in half before you start eating, or you will overeat, as the food servings are large. Fresh chips as well. Oh, and the fresh fruit juices -- get an extra large.

Staff was also very friendly.
author: Nathaniel S.

description:
This is the financial district, so it's five stars.  In Mission it would be four stars, but it could still hold it's own.

Everyone raves above the salsa bar.  Yes, it's possibly the best salsa bar in town (although Guadalara is probably better.)  They've got lots of mild salsas for the gringos as well as some spicy ones.  The cucumber salsa is amazing, but is too spicy for my friends. Too bad for them.  SALSA TIP: Mix the hottest salsa with mild salsas to give them a kick.

The burritos are very good, although on the small size for a San Francisco super burrito.  The meat is very fresh and juicy.  The beans and other toppings are standard, while the rice is below par.  Still, when it comes together, it's delicious, especially with their ridiculous salsa bar.

Chips are included. They are freshly made.  Sweet.

This place is three stories tall and they deliver the burritos to your table.  I love this part of the place too because you can relax at your table while waiting for your burrito instead of nervously standing in the place.   It's probably San Francisco's only multi-level salsa bar, although the one on the first floor usually has more variety of salsa.

The only cons about this place are 1) price and 2) hours.  Burritos are financial district prices, which means it will run you $10 for a burrito and soda.  The hours are NOT until 3:00 a.m., that is just plain wrong.  This place isn't even open for dinner; I think they might close at 3 pm. I've tried to get dinner here and worked in the area -- believe me, they aren't open.

This place also serves Margaritas, which are both cheap and strong. You don't see that much in burrito places. Good place to get hammered at lunch.
author: Dean A.

description:
It's a bit of a walk from my office but it's worth it. Their Nopales and Carne asada burrito is excellent. It's hard to find people who make Nopales right around here but they manage it both for the burritos and by themselves in a salad. Line can get long line at lunch (like any other good place in the district I guess).

The menu is brown on brown (they went for an "oxide on oxidized metal" look or something, weird), which makes it kind of hard to read.
author: David M.

description: Excellent veggie burritos.  Try the Mango Salsa from their extensive salsa bar.  The chips need work.  Tlaloc is pricey,  $8 or more for a burrito, but the food is tasty and fresh.  This may explain the line going out the door during lunch hour.
author: Mr. N.

description:
Good food, for the most part, but overpriced and poorly run operation.  Yes, they have those GREAT salsa bars but they neglect to get the tomato peels out of the red chunky hot one.  

My biggest gripe is their "Super Burrito".  Bullshit.  The thing is tiny.  If I pay for your overpriced "super burrito" there better be no way in hell I can walk away from it still hungry.  That is messed up.

Too expensive, good tasting salsa that will give you stomach trouble, and a laughably small "Super Burrito"?  Learn how to run a mexican restaurant.

Oh, and have you clicked on their website?   They've obviously stopped paying to have it hosted, as its now some travel-site BS which has nothing to do with the restaurant.

This place could have been great.  Sadly, its run very poorly and its not worth the horrendous prices to eat there.  The very pleasant gal who was a regular behind the take-out cash register appears to be gone now too.  She was great, always remembered my order, even gave me a small price break for being a regular.  I have no reason to return.  Save your money and eat someplace competently run.
author: Weldon D.

description:
pricey but worth the extra pennies

a short hop, skip & jump from the office, though i find myself wishing it were further so i could justify eating there.

hmmm,  no need for justification.

i heart this place even though i loathe myself after scarfing down crispy fish/prawn tacos and or merescado burrito weekly. 

the salsa stand is great for those who don't mind spitting fire, but my delicate taste buds can't handle the heat.

complaint: no delivery & beans have found there way into my meals more than once when i requested NO BEANS.  thankfully i do not have food allergies and i don't have the time patience or interests in walking back to correct their mistake.

clean establishment, yummy food, nice staff, lil outside seating area equals 4 stars

+++++++++++++
now five stars b/c they have amazing customer service. i was given the wrong order, yet was hungry so began my meal.  they realized the mistake and made my order to go!

yay!
author: r p.

description: The grilled veggie burrito actually has big chunks of super fresh, super grilled vegetables, the salsa choices are spicy and flavorful, and I really do think they make the tortilla chips from scratch... it's always a good time when the sun is shining and the alley is packed - people watching paradise!
author: Anjali K.

description: Actually, the food deserves 4 stars but I have to take off a star for being way overpriced.  Hello?  Mexican food is not supposed to be expensive!  But I do come back because their food is tasty and they're very quick during the lunch rush hour.  All ingredients are fresh and you can tell that everything is healthy.  But damnit....$9.95 for a burrito?!?!  $6 for a tiny a$$ crispy taco?!?!?  Ahh well...at least they're tasty!
author: Lori A.

description: the cripsy taco is delicious. the salsa bar is intense.
author: Anita C.

description: I went here for lunch yesterday with my co-workers and this spot definitely lived up to my standards when it comes to a solid chicken burrito and fresh, flavorful salsas. I have always had trouble finding delicious mexican spots in financial and Mercedes is one of the few that I find to be decent... I am happy I found Tlaloc because this place is now my quick fix for mexican. Charming location down the alleyway to have a bite outside and really embrace unwinding during a busy business work week. Burritos were incredibly flavorful and just the right size. I appreciated the variety of salsas they offered- avocado salsa was tasty. A fabulous menu, with a wide array to pick from including many items for vegetarians and also for meat lovers. Shrimp burrito intriqued me and I will be back to try. Great spot, highly recommend for a casual bite if you appreciate sustainable food and fresh taste without the grease.
author: Michaela w.

description: Decent burritos for the financial district, but after I ate it I was kind of disappointed... for that much money I expected a lot more than what I got (ok, its only a buck or two more than other places, I know, I know).  Its their fault really for giving me such high expectations - the nice decor, the various salsa options, and huge line that was nearly out the door - c'mon people, really.  I was happy to get my burrito though, they have this killer assembly line going so my coworkers & I didn't wait long at all, just enough time to choose our salsas and go.  Definitely a viable option if your in the FiDi and need a burrito, but I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to come here.
author: Margie N.

description:
good
- the crispy prawn tacos are amazing...  expensive, but worth it -- the corn tortilla is fried right on the grill with some cheese to make it crispy, like a mexican grilled cheese sandwich... soooo good
- other crispy tacos and (flour) quesadillas are decent:  I'd go with al pastor or carnitas if you're into the prawns

bad
- pretty everything else on the menu is mediocre or worse, and the prices are typical FiDi (i.e. overpriced)
- lunch crowd is a little overwhelming at peak times
- closes mid-afternoon, so dinner is not an option
- basically a more expensive, less good version of its sister restaurant, Cancun, in Berkeley
author: Anthony W.

description: I'm currenly on a crusade to inform all my fellow yelpsters of hidden msg nightmares. this place is one that no one would ever expect. i'm super sensitive to msg and this place has it. most people are probably unaware that mexican food is rife with msg. most people think it's asian food but i've gotten so sick from msg from mexican food. i'll admit the burittos taste great going down (although so frikin pricey, i once paid $15 for one of their burittos b/c i mistakenly 'customized' it--the lady at the register was no help and i think she could've told me to order it another way, saving me several bucks but of course not!) anyway, i got the worst msg mouth and couldn't get rid of it the entire day and my co-worker had the same experience...
author: Linda Y.

description: Okay food!  I'd rather have burritos from hole-in-the-wall places, but this is definitely a good alternative for our lunches.  I usually get a super burrito...all the fixin's please!  ^_^  One time I tried the carnitas burrito and it was really dry and overcooked.  But, I still like the food and the salsa bar they have....try the avocado salsa or the mango one.  So worth it.
author: Mary H.

description: i really love the fish burrito.  the salsas are really good too.  this is probably one of the only places that i don't turn down their chips.  their chips seem to be just the right amount of salty.  and their mango salsa is my favorite.
author: Anthony R.

description: 3.75 stars-a great lunch place, LOVE the salsa bar (must get mango salsa, unless you don't like sweet things), the pineapple agua fresca was delicious (don't get horchata - i had it last time and it was awful, much rather go to the Mission for horchata). Disclaimer, it's a bit expensive, but if I'm going to spend $10+, might as well get some shrimp soft tacos or fish tacos, eh? It's better tasting than a salad. However I won't lie, I do like Mixt Greens across the street (but why $12 for a salad?)
author: Jeannette L.

description: If you are in the financial district then go here.  This being the best lunch in the area deserves all the stars.  Yes, I think the burritos got smaller and the prices went up but  once you enter tlaloc paradise you'll forget about everything including the Dow 7000.  Salsa bar is a nice addition!
author: Sean B.

description: My fave of the FiDi burrito joints.  I dig the Mole Poblano & breakfast burritos.  But like all FiDi places, me hates payin so much for something I can make or get mas barato en la mission.
author: Lito S.

description: I love this place. I don't know why you wouldn't. I came here and i was so happy to find because they have nopales. I ordered the mole chicken burrito with nopales. It was so good. I have ordered here several times now, and i have never been disappointed. Their burritos leave you pleasantly full, which is the best.  Its just a shame that they are not open on the weekends, or past 3, or i would go there a lot more often.
author: caramel c.

description: I work near by and have eaten here a couple of times, but this last lunch ended with a near hospital visit. I with out a doubt had food poisoning from this restaurant, first and foremost because it was the only meal I had that day and at the end of the work day I was chained to the toilet. I would proceed with caution especially to the salsa bar, I think that was where I got sick from. It is exposed to the elements and sitting there all day so it is very easy to spoil. I would never want anyone to go through what I did last week.
author: Derek E.

description: Mexican food for gringos. Thats the gentle way of putting it, as evident based upon the type of people lining up out the door for the place. The flavors seem to be a bit dumbed down for gringos. The only good thing is they have a good selection of salsas. Other than that, they are too expensive for what you get, quantity, and flavorwise.
author: A W.

description: I am not sure how it stacks up with the many great Mexican restaurants around the City and Northern California, but in the Financial District it has to be one of the best (thereby entitling it to 4 stars). Their burritos are great and the salsa bar is fantastic (both in quality and quantity of the options). The only downside in my eyes is they do not give you enough chips to quench one's salsa thirst. The place has plenty of indoor and outdoor seating and is in a location that is slightly of the beaten path, but very accessible. If you work downtown and like Mexican food, can those inauthentic chain restaurants and head to Tlaloc.
author: Jeff L.

description: I love this little restaurant.  I love the location with the tables in the sunny alley.  I love the freshness of the food.  I recommend the carnitas soft tacos plate. Yummm...... I've changed jobs and am no longer within walking distance of Tlaloc......probably a good thing for my waistline!
author: Karen S.

description: I came across this hot spot by chance one rainy day during my lunch hour. There we people running to shelter, or so it seemed...but reallly they were running to get a delicious meal from this place. The frist time I went here I was overwhelmed with all the choices. Their huge menu board is cool, but i opted for the paper menu so that i could make my decision carefully, not over looking anything. I got the carne asada quesadilla. It was awesome! melted cheese on a flour tortilla(you have a choice either corn or flour, the friendly cashier recommended the flour for its size) rolled up almost like a taquito with lots of yummy toppings mounted above it. This was not only warm and soft but great with their homemade chips. I actually loved the chips so much that next time i got the nachos and boy was i in heaven. They give you just enough for a filling lunch and the carne asada is always fresh and never over cooked. This place is starting to become one of my all time faves. The only reason I gave it a four was that I think the prices could be a little cheaper...on that note...load up on the garlic salsa! its unique and addicting!!
author: Rhea A.
